review_title: Pay is not based on contribution, and Management lacks trust and integrity
pros: Upper levels of management take employee surveys seriously.  There is some effort shown to try and improve conditions based upon those surveys.
cons: Pay is not based on merit and contribution to the company.  Valuable employees who stay with the firm are generally paid less than new hires, who are given attractive offers to lure them from previous employers.  There is little incentive to stay for a long tenure.  In the last 5 years or so, there has been a marked increase in office politics and bureaucracy around technology project management.  There is an overall lack of trust between Line Of Business management and Technology and this has manifested itself in an attempt to assert strong control around projects.  Technology Managers try and "game the system" in order to work their way around the controls. This type of culture generally rewards employees who lack integrity and actual knowledge of the business domain, but are "political animals". With this cultural trend, along with the trend of major cost cutting measures since the Financial Crisis and additional pressures from the Regulators, very little productive work actually gets done.  Additionally, because of lack of strong management, some employees do very little work with minimal consequence, while others take on the burden of extra work.

job_title: Software QA Engineer in Newark, DE
pros:
Perhaps the greatest benefit of being at such a corporation is the size. Bank of America boasts hundreds of thousands of employees as one of the big  four banks in the US, and it's a place where there are many avenues for career enhancement, opportunity and enrichment, provided that you look for it. It is established, and there is a high demand for innovation, structure and future-proof frameworks.

As an employee rounding near 5 years, I've had the opportunity to be a part of some the most grueling tasks at the Bank: QA. This comes attached with some of the hardest and tedious work one may find, yet I found a niche in developing automated solutions to QA processes, which opened a massive door to innovation and automation in this industry. And with an industry such as Bank of America, the opportunities are endless.
cons: With the innovation though, there are legacy frameworks. Perhaps the biggest pro also happens to be the biggest con. With the industry at such a large state, it is extremely hard to port entire systems within the enterprise to something new and innovative, largely due in part of risk taking. Not only are we not willing to take such risks, many people (depending on the branch you're in) aren't willing to take the next steps in innovation and change.

review_title: Ideal for on a Management path
pros:
Great PTO and generous leaves for parents and those with disabilities. 

Diverse workplace, with corporate resourcing for various affinity groups to find your niche. High levels of women and minorities in executive and leadership positions, who are both competent and encouraging as mentors. 

As an individual contributor, I wasn't micromanaged and encouraged to take on independent projects.

Employees typically have long tenures with the company. Stable and reliable. 

If you are satisfied simply working a 9-5 and staying with the same role OR want to move up into a management track, this is the job for you. They have formalized training for managers, and you usually have to put in your dues as a team lead.
cons:
If you want an individual contributor position with a high pay grade, you won't get it unless you've been with the company for 5-10+ years OR if you have tons of outside experience. 

Inefficient work practices and unnecessary roles tend to fall through the cracks; i.e., management tends to turn a blind eye instead of doing the hard but necessary thing (cutting a position, firing an incompetent employee). 

This is not a fast paced work environment. Because everything is, or should, be highly regulated, it's difficult to get radical new policies or procedures out quickly. 

There are instances of nepotism but those that it favors tend to stay in the same positions because they can't get to the upper levels of management. 

If you don't see yourself retiring with this company and want something sexier, put in a good five years and bail.

review_title: Nice benefits and decent pay paired with nitpicking, favoritism, and unrealistic sales goals.
pros:
- Great benefits (part-timers are eligible for medical, dental, etc.)
- Decent Pay
- Tuition reimbursement
cons:
Please consider these before applying for a position:
- In my particular branch there is a lot of favoritism and shirking by management
- Many other reviews mention a "customer first" approach with that translating into "sales first"; they're absolutely right. Forget about the customer, its all about soliciting, selling, and borderline harassing the poor customers to open this account, or that account, or this credit card - all the while they're just trying to make a deposit/withdrawal. 
- Aggressive and unrealistic sales goals. As mentioned before, as a teller you're required to "sell" to the customer. If your goals are not met or you refuse to mention a product, you'll be written up.
- BofA is the epitome of a ground-level-corporate disconnect
- Many useless and pointless tasks such as repetitive training, "coaching" (i.e. disciplining colleagues for minutia)
- Waste of man-power hours (i.e. the "Lobby Leader")
- Flat out lying to customers about wait times, especially when the customer wants to open an account. For example, it takes about 30 - 45 mins to open an account, but the employees will say the process takes about "10 minutes".

4) Most people that come to the bank barely have two nickels to rub together and completely risk averse. Further, are just cd shoppers. 
5) You have to make cold calls on a record line which makes you completely robotic to a prospective customer and if you fail the call it will affect your compensation.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Bank of America provides decent pay and benefits considering that they tend to hire very average employees. The schedule is flexible and there are plenty of vacation days. No one is expected to work late into the night. Once hired, there is very little chance that you will ever be let go, even if you have trouble producing adequate results.
cons: If you are looking to work hard and advance your career aggressively, this is not the place for you. They favor experience and length of service over putting in extra hours, intelligence and business results. You will not be rewarded for doing an exceptional job. You will have to wait in line for your turn to be moved up, which will not come until everyone who has been there longer than you has been advanced. They never get rid of anyone. So if you happen to come into a group with people who can't perform their jobs adequately, expect your manager to simply shift that work to you and expect you to carry them. Everyone in the group will undoubtedly be compensated the same regardless.

review_title: A mixed bag, some good, some bad...
pros: Good salary package; good leadership 1-2 management levels upwards, but not above that; good on-site facilities; professional, hard-working team members and managers
cons:
Too much uncertainty over financial budgets which resulted in multiple waves of redundancies (of small numbers of people each time) and consequent worry amongst staff i.e. "who's next?". This was made worse by the sudden departure, typical in many financial organisations these days, of those selected for redundancy i.e. it often took several days, sometimes weeks, before the reason for someone's absence became clear and this created knowledge gaps on projects and also increased the nervousness of remaining team members. 

Too much bureaucracy, with approvals being required for very minor things - some managers are trying hard to improve things in this area, though.

The performance management process is too blunt an instrument to adequately reward good performance, resulting in a lack of confidence in the fairness of the overall process. Many managers and staff just go through the motions and pay lip service to an imperfect system. 

Work-life balance not good, with some people working excessive hours e.g. 12-14h per day on a regular basis.
Home working contracts are no longer available for some teams, but there is some flexibility on very occasional home working days if this is pre-agreed.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Honestly I worked for 6 different departments with this bank and I can truly say that from teammates I had and up to the management, I could say that it is the best place to work for. Great benefits from medical insurance to generous time offs to bonus regarding how much the company makes. I can tell you that there maybe some changes about retirement benefits few years ago but the bank tried to replace that with something comparable or at least good. I believe the decision was good for the whole company.
cons: I have moved around the bank in 6 departments but I hope the recruiters could give more weight on growing and hiring internally first to help associates grow in different lines of business. Those 6 departments are all within call centers and customer service. I was never accepted in other lines of business  because of lack of experience. Look, how will we have experience if they don't hire and train us in other lines of business. So expect yourself to be stuck within a line of business.

pros:
Learning - Very good. Lot of training sessions happen regularly and we have free access to several well known external learning sites like Safari, GetAbstract, etc.

Career Growth - Good. The management respects an individual's contribution and skills and they promotions are done fairly. On an average you will find several people who have been with the company for 8 to 10 years. It's a retirement company for many.

Yearly hikes - Good. Last year our team received between 15 to 21% hike.

Management - Mid level managers are not that strong but they will try to help.
cons:
Budget cuts - There have been lot of budget cuts in the recent years. Cheap team lunches, boring team events with no event organizers, no fun activities, etc. 

Transport - Free transport is available. From morning 6 AM to 6.30 PM, AC is available in the cabs. After 6.30 PM, AC is not available and you need to be lucky to get a good cab. Innova, Xylo are good but several times you got Tavera or a Tata Sumo and these surely make a horrible ride if you are going to have a longjourney. Also, routing is not done properly always. Several complaints have been made but the department weren't able to improve the situation.

Restricted environment  - Smart phones are not allowed to the work bays. You can only carry a basic phone. Internet access is restricted. Several sites do not open. Too many policy restrictions.

review_title: Fair Compensation and good way to gain experience

cons:
The systems you work in are not adequate to perform the job to the level the company expects you to - websites constantly crash which puts relationships with your clients in jeopardy.  

Inbound phone queue that you are required to be in for most of the day gives you a significant amount of work for clients that are not a part of your book.  You are expected to complete campaigns, call out to your clients for everything under the sun and know your clients extremely well so that you can win new assets to the firm but the inbound phone queue eats up the majority of your time with clients that you are not assigned to.

Vacation policy is quite poor.  You have to bid for vacation on a quarterly basis - don’t think you will ever get additional time off around Thanksgiving, Christmas, Labor Day, Memorial Day, July 4th, etc, etc..... Also, Mondays and Fridays will likely never get granted either.

The company pays more money for this role because you are run ragged with all of the things that they want you to do.  Your manager puts pressure on you to stay longer than your shift since you are salary.

job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Boston, MA
pros:
Bank of America is a very large, stable company and because of that jobs are generally secure. There are many opportunities to move into new positions and groups because of the wide variety of businesses the Bank is involved in. In addition, associates are encouraged to move around to gather new experiences which is reflected in the Bank's talent planning processes.

While pay is somewhat mediocre, the Bank's benefits package is pretty decent and covers many different aspects of the benefits equation from retirements, to better rates on Bank products. And as opposed to many companies, the benefits package seems to expand yearly rather than contracting.
cons:
Being a large company is both a positive and a negative and the same is true with Bank of America. The Bank's size leads to a ton of bureaucracy. This can be extremely frustrating and it means decisions are made slowly and via committee. Also, because the Bank believes in moving assocaites around, especially for senior executives, large organizational moves happen all the time, which disturbs work in progress and leads to constantly changing priorities.  All this leads to strained communication between businesses and their management teams.

In addition, while the Bank makes lots of noise about gathering and responding to associate feedback, I'm afraid most of it is just paying lip service.

review_title: The company is extremely unorganized and much more incompetent than I assumed it to be.
pros: It's certainly got the name recognition that many employers in the industry may be impressed with when you're searching for a job. That is to say, it's a good company to gain experience with in order to leave later. There are also a lot of internal tools for research at your disposal; you are certainly provided with the essentials that you need in order to execute your job well.
cons: This is the most disorganized, inefficient company I have ever worked for. The communication between departments and co-workers, from my experience, has been horrendous. The hiring process alone took several months, with weeks of time in which I could do nothing to speed it up.  What was made out to be a short and simple formality took so long that I had to search for another job while I was waiting on my "papers to be processed."

review_title: Good work-life balance, well-rounded people, but not strategic. Ambitious MBAs...be cautious in Consumer Bank
pros:
Generally, people are nice, family-oriented, well-rounded, and sociable. Collaborative culture. Also, the scale of the operations and diversity of businesses allows you to get involved with some high-impact projects. For most efforts, there are a lot of resources and partners who you can benefit and learn from.
There are some very good, experienced leaders who you can learn from.
cons:
The consumer bank doesn't know how to use MBAs. MBAs work on assignments that could be done out of undergrad (or even high-school).  It's also very political to get in a position to lead a high impact project. Many of the projects are fluff. So, the few that have teeth, get crowded with too many people. 

It's not an intellectual culture. Decisions are made politically, not strategically.  Major strategic mistakes are made because the people in charge are likeable and popular, but not business thinkers.  

Career advancement, especially right now, is limited. Leadership ranks are bloated after inheriting too many middle managers from multiple mergers. Plus, re-orgs twice a year have huge impacts on how you are positioned in the organization. You have no control over the reorgs.

review_title: This used to be a great place to work
pros: If you're the sort of person who likes to have EVERYTHING written down in the form of a global policy, this is the place for you. Rules, guidelines, rigid processes, and metrics continue to multiply. If it can't be counted and measured - ignore it. If it doesn't fit in with the one and only global process, either force the square peg into a round hole or ignore it. Best of all: you're not expected to lift a finger to help anybody until they fill in a form and raise a formal online request.
cons:
We are drowning in red tape! Our top executives like to think that it was a clever idea to centralize every conceivable function in order to achieve better oversight, so we now have to obtain approval from senior leaders for the most trivial requests. Jumping through countless hoops to get anything done slows us down at every turn and makes our work incredibly inefficient. 
Furthermore, there is precious little communication and cooperation across different silos. Lack of integration between business lines causes serious issues with many projects: critical business requirements fall between the cracks and only come to light post-implementation.

job_title: Business Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Huge company with a lot of resources
cons:
I worked as a contractor through an agency in a technology role (business analyst). The contract was set for an initial term of 1 year, after which they could extend the contract, offer you a full time job, or just not extend. The contract is specifically worded so that they strongly discourage you from breaking the contract and leaving before the term is over, however they are absolutely free to get rid of you any time they want. So it's already clear at the get go how they view you as a resource. 

Long story short my contract was suddenly terminated after 2 months. My manager was a downright unethical individual. He cited "performance issues" as the reason for my termination but I suspect that was a pretext for getting rid of me. I have worked for various organizations and have gotten nothing but excellent reviews so the idea that I had performance issues is laughable.

I understand that contracting is unlike full time employment but there is an implicit good faith component that companies don't end a contract prior to the term date unless there is a very good reason (i.e. gross incompetence, bad behavior, etc...). The harm to a contractor of getting let go after 2 months is significant as it makes it difficult to find work again. 

I would never recommend working for this bank. I am now hearing many things that I wish I knew earlier (like Bank of America having a high turnover rate, even my boss at BOFA told me this directly!). They don't value people as human beings and I will never work or do any kind of business with this company.

pros: The people you meet are like family and networking can be really amazing if you make yourself available as an employee. This can open doors to job opportunities, special projects, and a better understanding of the corporate structure.
cons: The politics make innovation sluggish and the top heavy structure mean low pay & combined job functions. Training/certification opportunities (notwithstanding tuition reimbursement) are seldom presented to upcoming enthusiastic associates even when they are top performing. pros: Bank of America is a gret place to be during the current economic siuation.  Long term benefits are great. Depending which banking center you land in, managers are willing to hear your opinion and work together, no matter what their position is, in order to create a wonderful and organized work enviroment. However, I cannot say the same for upper-management.
cons: Being one of the biggest banks, yes, we have had tons and tons of cut backs, including cutting back employees and a hiring freeze. They are doing away with a lot of employee recognition programs which made me proud to work for B of A in the past. It seems as through they are moving away from giving a damn about their employees, to being focused solely on force feeding products to customers. Yes, we understand that customers are suffering during this time, but employees are too. It seems as though all the joy has literaly been sucked out of this place and replaced with fear of keeping your job and meeting your goals. They straight up told us that if you don't meet your goals, you're the first to go. And that's supposed to make you feel good about waking up and going to work each day? There;s more to a bank than just selling products to each and every customer that they don't need or can't affrord . What about service?

pros: I worked at BofA for about a year on a consulting basis, but was there full-time and one of the things that impressed me the most about this company was that they really think out of the box when it comes to growth for employees. There is a talent planning team that acts like talent scouts, keeping an eye on employees that are going above and beyond and getting very creative about how to move them into new opportunities. As an example, where most companies would only look at people with product management backgrounds for a senior role within product management, they tapped someone from the business analytics group who had consistently exceeded expectations and who was up for a new challenge.  I also reconnected with a former college in hr who has moved into a marketing role. They are very innovative in this respect and it helps with retention, great way to keep good people happy.
cons:
Conference calls. I've never worked at a larger company before so this was my first true corporate experience and it was eye-opening. Much more structure and layers, and reporting. 

Also the company is decentralized so my supervisor was based across the country, my admin worked out of her house in florida and my recruiting partner was in Charlotte. It all worked fine, but sometimes it's nice to just walk across the hall and ask your boss or colleague a question, and I did miss that.

The downside of the flexible work schedule is that you are always on for your poor clients.  Over 50% of loans that are entered are declined.  That number dosen't even reflect all the loans that are withdrawn because they look shaky or the client is missing some documentation.  I would frequently put in loans they would get declined and then the client would turn around and get approved at another bank.   Everything said about doing too many things is true.  You are in a Financial Center and are expected to train Relationship Managers to make referrals.  Unfortunately the RM's don't report to you they report to the Financial Center Manager.  So if the Financial Center is making it's goals it's just too bad for you.

BoA's reputation makes it almost impossible to get new purchase mortgage clients.  Real Estate agents and brokers will do anything to stop their clients from using BoA because of its reputation for declining loans or taking too long to approve the ones they do approve.  The only way to be successful is to convince RE Agents  to work with you despite  the banks reputation.  Obviously something that is very difficult to do considering all the options available.

As an Analyst, the program struggles to maintain employees after the second year because pay becomes less competitive compared to other bulge brackets and they have a hard time with being able to effectively grow the professional experience of analysts. They make it difficult for Analysts to transfer within the bank so don't even think about trying to break into Middle Office and Front Office from Internal Audit. review_title: Bank of America is the absolute worst company I have ever worked for!

You are required to create "warm transfers" which means getting customers to sit down with a banker in order for them to obtain a revenue generating product out of them.  The target can be very unrealistic to achieve.  I work at a very busy branch with mainly low-income customers which means sales interactions are hard to come by.  I don't if it's just my branch's neighborhood but customers can be very rude more than likely because they have bad attitudes towards banks in general. It's something that you can't let get to you.

cons: While I worked at Bank of America, "Six Sigma" was the process flavor of the year, and didn't apply as well to service side lines of business. The continual "on" state where email were sent at all times of the night or over the weekend, put more pressure on associates to be reponsive  - by either checking email over the weekend or in the evenings. pros: Exposure to top investment professionals.  Many of the employees are well respected, very intelligent and educated.  People make the group.

Very slow moving, bureaucratic, and in many cases, misses the boat with tactical investment implementation.
Compensation has been very challenged over the past two years, and only getting worse.  Specific areas of concern are in Global Investment Solutions unit of Global Wealth and Investment Management (GWIM).  This is not a group that fosters salary advancement with promotion.  Instead your total compensation will remain relatively flat despite promotion, increasing experience and street value.  Sallie K, and others in leadership do not seem to attend to internal human resources issues that plague GWIM.  Turnover has been an issue and is expected to pick-up as the market improves.  MBA recruits beware....this is not a good place to begin your career, as you will be stuck at your initial compensation level for years to come, dramatically lagging behind your peers at JPMorgan, Citi, and Deutsche private banks by 25%+. pros: The great thing about being a RM is that you get to learn a lot about banking and finance in general. What you might not know is how much this position is driven by sales. If you are interested in just a customer service job, this isn't the right fit for you. If you are a confident, competitive, goal-oriented person, this job is a good fit for you. When you get in, you have two months without sales goals, the third month is minimal, then the fourth month, you're going to be expected to be fully ready to go, professional. You will have the same goals as the veteran RMs that you are working with, so you can either cry about it or just be a savage and compete. Depending on the branch you are located operates, RMs can be solely sales focused or split with servicing. All in all, if you get the position, you will need to learn quick and get results or else your sales manager will hunt you down. 100% of sales goal isn't good enough, do the best you can and be part of the pinnacle group.
cons: Audits. These stress everyone out, so make sure you learn operations properly.

review_title: Extremely micromanaged at every hour of the day, decent pay and benefits though
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Decent pay compared to the other big banks, but still not exceptional. Great benefits that are available to part time tellers as well. Opportunity for advancement if you want to work at it. I was promoted to Sales and Service Specialist within 6 months of becoming a teller.
cons: Constant micromanagement and sales pressure. Ever-changing procedures and policies. You are expected to hit your referral and DDA (checking account) goals no matter how busy the bank is. My locations that I worked at were fairly slow so without the traffic at times it was very difficult to hit sales goals. When you didn't hit them it was a constant lecture day by day, hour by hour on what could be done differently to hit the goals. Every single conversation with a customer is scrutinized, making you feel like a robot; eventually why I couldn't put up with it any more.

review_title: Slow computer systems make it aggravating to work there.
job_title: Home Service Specialist II in Marlton, NJ
pros:
Great pay
Off on all holidays
Good health benefits
cons:
I was told in the interview I would get between 25-35 loans to process. In the end they had me processing 60-70 loans. Some of the loans would be transferred and customers were pissed because of what the previous processor did to their file. There computer system and the way they processed loans was horrible. I spent more time trying to fix a file because of their horrible systems they use versus assisting customers with their files. They make it impossible to close loans. Their rules for expired documentation were what sucked the most. I had to keep bugging customers for documentation that kept expiring, which pissed off EVERY customer. If it wasn't their computer system that caused last minute delays, it was their time period of scheduling a loan closing 5 days out. Their processing time was unrealistic based on their slow computer systems and documentation expiration dates. They expect you to work overtime to make up the difference with their slow computers. Do not expect to take any time off from work. No one covers your work while you are out on vacation or a day off. They assign a backup person to cover your files but the backup person is busy doing their own work to keep up. Things can easily spiral out of control if you miss one day. 
. The pay was nice but the aggravation of working there is not worth it.

review_title: Great company with a commitment to improving a faltering reputation.
job_title: Home Equity Loan Officer in Plano, TX
pros:
Great benefits (dental is not stellar, but good if you don't really need anything serious). Up to 7% 401k matching. Excellent management team - there is some definite micromanaging, but this is a call center environment and you should WANT to be on the phones every second you can ($$$)! 

There is a defined career path with progressive benefits should you choose to remain in mortgage sales. Also, management takes the cyclic nature of the industry and sales forecasts into account on a rolling quarterly basis so that employees are not penalized during the slow seasons (i.e. Winter).
cons:
Takes six+ months to see any decent commission checks. Two months to hit the floor, a month or two to familiarize yourself with the systems and process, a month and a half for applications to close and fund, then one and a half to two months from that point to see a commission check. 

There is some concern about the layoff history with this company, though that is prevalent throughout and can be ascribed to being within the mortgage industry as a whole.

job_title: Small Business Specialist in Tulsa, OK
pros: I enjoy the work, I find it very fulfilling to help people with their financial goals.  It is challenging work but not hard.  We are very proactive to trends and changes in the marketplace. Bank of America loves to promote from within.  a substantial number of our associates started as tellers and are now in higher positions.  We recognize talent and reward appropriately. The benefits are fantastic and are implemented quickly.  In an age where many companies are removing benefits programs, Bank of America is expanding theirs.
cons: This job is demanding if you want to progress in the company.  But then again, what job isn't.  Because of Bank of America's size, it is impoosible to know all of our capabilities. review_title: Don't expect anything to be spoon fed to you.
pros: Large organization with lots of different areas to work in. Projects tend to be well funded and funds are rarely pulled at the last minute. The benefits are very good as long as you are talking about financial products. The bank provides discounts on loans, mortgages and credit cards that really add up. They offer telecommuting at some locations and for some jobs. The environment varies considerably by location and manager. I would not want to work in the Delaware location because it is all ex-MBNA executives. The NC offices are very nice and would be a good place to work. The Phoenix location is mainly a phone center.
cons: There is no employee directory.....really.....you have to network your way through any new issue in order to get things done. Job titles and department names don't give you a clue as to who you're dealing with either. The place has been double-speaked to death. The communications to employees about the company are clearly crafted by a PR department and are long on hyperbole and short on facts. I look to outside sources in order to find out what is happening with my own company. In the past there have also been some really big layoffs. They typically occur about a year after a new acquistion.

review_title: Amazing benefits, competitive pay, poor bonus structure, annoying office politics
job_title: Personal Banker in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I worked as a Personal Banker at Bank of America. The pay was good, better than most other similar positions within the competitors, the quarterly bonus' could be very substantial, and the benefits were amazing. Think 12 weeks paid leave for PATERNITY leave.
cons: While the bonus' could very substantial, they are ranked on many many many variables and then your bonus is awarded based on your percent to goal and manager discretion. As I was always above 100% to my goals, I still made good money, but I did not always get what I would have expected. Since there are so many variables when your bonus' are awarded and the management team that awards your bonus is actually the market team and does not work with you on a daily basis, you could theoretically get much lower than you deserve. I have seen it happen to coworkers. The brings me into the office politics. If you ever work for Bank of America, do everything you can to make friends with EVERYONE. As your ability to be promoted hinges on being friends with the right people far too much. Your numbers may not mean anything.

job_title: Small Business Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great perks! BOA sponsors a lot of events so you can usually enjoy them at a nominal fee or free. They offer many discount programs to its employees and their families. There are a lot of jobs available for reassignments in the company. Once you voice your plans for upward mobility they help you achieve your goal. The overall benefits are excellent! !
cons: The salary is low but the bonuses are paid monthly and are usually unlimited.  Some of the managers in the upper roles are found to have "special" relationships with outside vendors to "win" their business. Cutbacks in the company can come at anytime with no warning, and some people will be warned while others will not. Although BOA is a sponsor to Susan G Komen, there are no support programs in place for employees with Breast Cancer. Many of the managers who aren't affected by cancer will discriminate against the survivors and use their "time away" as an avenue to pass them up on positive reviews or promotions.

review_title: Flexible work environment with good benefits and a conflicted corporate culture
job_title: Intermediate Financial Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, generous paid time off, 401K match is decent. Most corporate workers get a laptop, so you rarely have to stay in the office after business hours unless your manager demands it. Also, even though the formal MyWork program is still frozen it's possible to work from home 1-2 days a week depending on your specific manager and situation. These "pros" are great for parents of young children and it's what keeps me at the company.
cons: There is a huge culture difference between groups that are BAC and Legacy groups (such as Countrywide); The mortgage side of the business (ex-Countrywide) is a boy's club and they run the business in a very heavy handed "get it done" environment that causes a lot of the young talent to jump ship. There is NO opportunity for advancement in that business, especially as a woman, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who is just starting their career. The consumer banking side, on the other hand, values being politically correct, and it's filled with professionals who (at least on the surface) respect each other so it's a better environment for women.

pros: Strong process management! Often something you take for granted...their focus on six sigma/process management and minimizing variation results in huge efficiency gains...they are clear on people processes, procedures, roles & responsibilities...they even have many types of internal document templates that are fully branded. Again, seems like not a big deal, that is until you don't have this at all.  Given their size, the fact they get all different lines of business to agree on many things is a huge feat.
cons: Constant movement at the top.  Seemed to have an "executive rotational program" like what we do with new interns....every 2 years a senior leader would be put in a totally different LOB and be expect to run it smoothly. Come on. This is OD/change management 101.  Of course this constant churn ripples and causes 4-5x per year re-orgs.  For you, potential hire, this means you will have a parade of bosses in a single year and therefore be in a chronic state of onboarding/proving yourself/building relationships with managers/adjusting to new managers... and where you really get hurt is in talent management because you will not be able to gain ground in your career as you would in a more stable environment.

review_title: Typical experience for a large corporation
job_title: Operational Risk Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Lots of different roles to take advantage of. At lower levels, lots of opportunities to make a name for yourself. In any given role, if you're in, you're good. If you screw up or tick someone off, you will have to work really hard to roll the boulder back up the mountain.
cons: Limiting your availability can also limit your ability to move no matter how great your accomplishments. Expectations exist in most areas that employees are actively available as needs arise or email responses are requested.  Trying to prioritize and get work done can be difficult in this kind of environment. Organizations are constantly changing management or structure so it's not unusual to have multiple successive managers while in the same role. It is also not unusual in the midst of organizational changes for priorities to change and current accomplishments to be wiped away by the goals of the new management.

pros: I recently left BAC in Plano after being there 5 years.  The physical site is really bad and not employee friendly.  There are mice throughout the building, bathrooms are disgusting, and they don't offer coffee or microwaves in the break rooms.  You're on your own there.  The benefits, however, are great with generous vacation time, maternity, paternity time off, tuition reimbursements, etc.
cons: There's no rhyme or reason as to how people get promoted over there.  There are some people who do really well, earn great salaries and bonuses, and others who are underpaid and not promoted.  They don't seem to care what your educational background is, and it's frustrating for people in the same job to have only a high school diploma vs. a graduate degree.  Its seems to be more who you know and who likes you as to your mobility.    Your job is your manager, truly.  I left due to all the layoffs, no opportunity to boost my income since I was already there, and a micromanager.  It's too bad when good people leave.  If you can come in at a salary you feel happy with, and you're lucky enough to report to a professional, decent manager, you can have a great experience at BAC.

pros: The benefits, overall company culture, and resources and products the bank offers are all good.
cons: Management in the Chicago area is a joke. Turnover is crazy, most branches are understaffed, and your market leader cares nothing about your development, effort, etc. You're a number, and nothing more. Do everything asked of you and have issues or poor performance beyond your control, and your manager will come around lecturing you about the minimum #'s to hit. Start hitting your #'s, and they will come around with high fives and smiles and act like "We knew you had it in you all along!" The bonuses are very low, and only decent if you manage to make it over several hurdles, including: audit errors, bad customer surveys that your teammates get,  and large deposits being made to the branch. If you're in a very busy center that's staffed properly AND get very lucky with surveys and large deposits, you will maybe come away with a few grand for the entire quarter. Incredibly low when you consider how it's taxed, and what your base is for this role.

pros: None at all to fill 5 word minimum

If you did not make a sale attempt on each and every call opportunity you were coached ( BofA) term for not deepening the relationship with the customer. If you as a customer decide to call in for any interaction that hold time is going to be used to set you up for a sale, BofA will cross reference all your relationship information with BofA to try to sell you something. Don’t ever call, visit a branch, or interact with a live person because they are no worse than the other bank that has been all over the news for there aggressive sales.

job_title: Banking Center Assistant Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits. You are offered health, dental ect almost immediately after you are hired. You can also add on your partner even if it is not a same sex relationship. They also offer discounts to several retailers such as GAP and Best Buy and you get discounted banking solutions such as accounts and loans. The hours are pretty awesome since they are only open a half day on Saturday and not at all on Sunday.
cons: The pay is terrible! I was told that the range was $40-45k for an Assistant Branch Manager. They just told me this to get me to interview. I was then offered considerably less than that but took it because I really needed a job and was desperate. I was told I wold be trained for 1 month in a branch not my own so that I would be prepared to take on the role when I went to my permanent bank. I got 2 weeks of training and was then dumped in a struggling banking center. In the 2 months I was there I had 2 different terrible managers. I never received any more training and was forced to blindly help customers with out really knowing what to do. Every customer who comes into the bank is angry and mad and they take it out on you. I asked for a higher salary and was denied. I asked for more training and was told I was to be demoted. I quit immediately. Oh and I was there 9 days before the bank got robbed during my shift.

pros: Large corporation with a solid reputation.
cons: I did not feel appreciated at all regardless of my efforts there. Management only cared about their bottom-line and I have 3 examples to support what I'm saying. 1) I injured my back moving a box one day. I couldn't walk and was waiting for my friend to come pick me up to go to the doctor. Not once did my manager check on me or even say a word to me before I left, but I overheard him say to someone else, "Why is she still here? Why doesn't she just go home?" Apparently he didn't like the fact that my inury seemed to be a "distraction" to the rest of the staff.  2) My time-sheet wasn't turned in on one occassion (due to management's error, not mine) and I was originally told that I would have to wait until the next pay period. They treated me as if I didn't need my paycheck just because I was single with no kids. I STILL HAD BILLS TO PAY! 3) I was hired as a part-time teller but forced to work overtime weekly. Obviously this was their way of not having to give me full-time benefits but still get the hours out of me. I will never work or bank there again...

review_title: it's banking... don't expect anything different
pros: big company which gives you opportunity to move around, good benefits, sales goal are not as aggressive as in other banks.
cons:
-they keep on downsizing the staff. some branches have gone from 6 teller FTE to 2.5 FTE there is literally more managers than tellers.
-work week begins on saturday; so if you get a saturday off, you will have to work mon-sat without any overtime.
-you can only take vacation in 1 week blocks (no more or less) and you are forced to choose all of your weeks at the begining of the year and picking order is based on seniority, new employees pick last (and the the crappy weeks).

-and the one that almost made me quit: commission for retail banking is 100% discretionary (meaning they can take it all away) last querter i sold 124% to goal and made $1600, my manager took $750 away for not executing all the right behaviors (yet a hit 124% to goal) then when my check comes i only got $140. 
-my manger and his manger said that this was a mistake and it would be fix. after 3 weeks of waiting and being told that "it had been escalated" the market manager came and basically told me i was SOL and there was nothing they could do to get me the rest of my money.

review_title: Absolutely Amazing Employer and Incredible Teammates!
pros:
The environment is so supportive.  I could not imagine a better group of people to work with or for.  My management team both inside and outside the branch are dedicated to developing employees and helping them reach their goals.  You put into this job what you get out of stand they definitely make it worth the effort. 
The benefits are fantastic.  There was no waiting period before benefits kicked in, they offer maternity and paternity paid leave, they match a certain percent of 401K contributions, they offer financial advice, adoption and childcare reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, etc.  This company does care about its employees and it shows.
cons: The only negative that I can think of is that BofA is not competitive in terms of spiffs and bonuses.  Other companies offer spiffs for sales from the teller line but while this would obviously be nice, I wouldn't leave my job for this aspect. I have worked for this company for a little over a year now but I have banked with them since I was a child.  As a consumer, I always received excellent service and as an employee I receive all of the support that I could ask for.

pros: Scale of company allows for broad exposure to different area of the banking.  If your interest change, at a Bank of this size you will have the opportunity to gain additional experience without leaving the Bank.  The Bank strives to be inclusive (women, color, diabilities, etc...).  The Bank does a great job of rewarding top performers.  Top performers are taken care of financially and through promotion opportunities.  The Bank is one of a few companies which still offfers its associates a pension plan.  Moreover, all associates including those at lower-levels have an opportunity to earn a bonus based on the performance of the company.
cons: Change, change, change.......the organization is largely driven by the economic cycle.  The Bank is driven to meet quarterly expectation of the "street".  In order to accomplish this goal everything is on the table, including lay-offs.  Change does not only include "head-count" but also includes shifting of mid and upper management to accomplish these goals.  In the past 9 months, I have had 4 different managers/directors which can make it difficult to achieve a level of continuity and can make it difficult to advance.  This is the norm at the Bank as it attempts to provide management with a broad banking experience...so times at the expense of other employees.

review_title: Retail Banking.. Glad I got out when I did!
job_title: Senior Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent compensation and benefits, work/life balance and you'll have to be a complete idiot to be fired!  Retail banking is not a good career move unless you're looking for something stable with slow upward mobility or you're fine with doing the same job for years on end.
cons: IMPORTANT THAT YOU READ THIS IF YOU'RE THINKING ABOUT RETAIL BANKING!!  The culture of BofA was great for slackers who have worked for the company for years.  Newer and often younger employees with more intelligence and drive typically get stuck (used) in lower level positions in retail banking units because there are many "lifers" in the company.  Do the math.. each major retail market has a least 30 banking centers, that means there are roughly 350+ Tellers, 80+ Personal Bankers, 30 Assistant Managers, 30 Managers and only one or two Market Managers and only ONE Executive Market Manager role!  To move up there's a tremendous amount of politicking, favoritism and luck.  Furthermore, BofA's scorecard for each role is almost entirely nonsensical when comparing one banking center to another.  Let's face it, BofA's retail banking is broken due to a combination of poor management and cronyism.  Needless to say, if you are looking for a career then stay away from retail banking at BofA!

review_title: Lots of Data to work with, Org Structure can be improved
pros: A large company with lots of data to play with if you're into analytics. Some of the acquired orgs such as Merrill, MBNA, CFC, etc  have pools of solid talent and knowledge that is a blessing...though attrition is occurring more recently.  Decent benefits.
cons: Culture varies considerably within org given the many company acquisitions.  Org structure and who real decision makers are is difficult to navigate as a consequence.  The benchmark of what is acceptable/quality work is quite varied, so you my find yourself having to pick up the slack  for subpar output from other groups to do a decent job.  VERY Bureaucratic!!  Lots of overcompensated middle managers that function as  'project managers' , yet lacking the needed depth to lead on projects.   Charlotte culture historically seems to reward talk over walk, with incompetent  work passed off as good by smooth talk and power point decks.  This may be changing as there is a centralized effort in org to standardize methodologies, and have independent groups review work from other divisions...we'll see.

review_title: Be prepared to get pooped on in consumer banking
pros:
Paid Holidays

people are generally nice and pleasant to be around (on the days they take their pills)
cons:
While I generally was comfortable during my 5 years with BOA, the amount of changes that occurred seemed to take a turn for the worse. i.e. harder to meet  goals thus harder to receive incentives, more structured processes, middle level management telling you when you can take your vacation. I understand this is a for profit company, but if you want your business to run, you must take care of your associates or should I say robots...

While many people are competent at what they do, it  does not necessarily make them a good leader thus they have a hard time communicating and leading their team. The only type of training provided is on regulatory and procedural policies but learning how to harbor relationships and develop your associates lacks greatly. Coaching is a joke. 

They try to promote diversity and inclusion but they tend to hire sheep from the same flock thus making work feel "cliquish". With this company it's not about WHAT you know but about WHO you know even if you aren't good at what you do. If you like to kiss ass and don't care about taking on more responsibility, then this company is a good fit for you.

review_title: Marketing Product Manager at Bank of America

cons: Buying up troubled companies in an effort to remain the biggest.  They buy up these problem companies such as Countrywide, then they decide the practices of the company that is going bankrupt are better so they change the entire company to those practices and systems.  Then they look at reducing redundancy and lay off loyal Bank of America employees that have been there 10, 20, 30 or more years and know their stuff like the back of their hand in favor of keeping employees from the problem company at all levels from executive management to entry level positions  If the practices and employees of the problem company were the right way to go why was the company failing in the first place?  No one takes the time to take these things into account.

review_title: A nightmare that never goes away.

CEO and DR's generally have good and sustainable vision for company and most strategic decisions / strategies are strong from a company performance perspective.
cons: References to 'industry standard' in Pros also indicates certain limitations relative to emerging, venture, or more progressive businesses.  Opportunities for advancement have become more limited in big banks over the past ~10 years, BAC included, and cost reduction or downsizing efforts impact all levels and have been 'a thing' for ~5 years (since bank turned corner on the impacts of financial crisis and somewhat reduced requlatory load).  Organizational stability is still a challenge with ongoing reorganizations and 'transformation' which can seem like change for the sake of change.

You would think for a company with over $1 trillion in assets, it would at least be able to offer more opportunities for growth (without corporate politics and stability but I guess you can't expect too much from a publicly traded company who makes a bulk of their money charging fees left and right.

review_title: Call-center environment, one call after another, very goal oriented every day, high pressure to succeed.

Unless a high stage of deliquency no account ownership. If customers need to call back they have to speak to a completely differrent account manager who is not familiar with theit situation. Promotions are done on achievement only, no considerations for leadership skills or ethics. High achievers who are promoted generally were ethically challenged themselves who now have to manage to a set of ethics and standards.

pros: Company has many different positions with flexible hours.
cons:
-This company will do cosmetic changes (new floors,  break rooms, etc.) but wont upgrade simple equipment needed for work efficiency like scanners, computer screens, etc. 

-Only company I've ever worked for that will set 10 hour shifts for employees and give 30 minute lunch breaks which half of that time is used getting up and down the elevator.

-Also lower level management in certain operations departments will do unethical things like give employees answers to required testing like business policy/ethics/HIPPA

-Lower management/Team Leaders  also do not distribute daily work fairly which will have certain "hand picked" employees with good work stats and the rest fighting daily to meet requirements which makes for a very stressful work environment with high turnovers

review_title: They are going in the wrong direction

At point they had a slogan that said they wanted to be the most admired company in the world. They were never and will never be that... The new slogan, we are better when we are connected..... job_title: Video Teller Agent in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Fun theme days, potlucks, awesome teammates, most management is very nice and supportive,  somewhat recognition for hard work(even if it is just a peice of laminated paper.)
cons: IMPOSSIBLE metrics and goals to meet. Constant emphasis on customer experience when the changes they are implementing negatively impact said experience which in turn makes our goals even harder to meet. Unhappy employees will result in unhappy customers. Extreme high stress environment with ever changing dizzying expectations with no change to compensation. Horrible staffing issues (no one there on high volume days, everyone there on low volume days...why?) Absolutely no opportunity for advancement. System issues, IT problems and software redundancy that never gets fixed. All employees are discouraged and unhappy. This job is depressing and will take the strongest happiest person and break them. Office politics, nepotism and favoritism are rampant. You can't win, no matter how hard you try.

pros: Location.  Being a member of the travelling team we had great meals only!
cons: It's Who likes you that makes a difference not how well you know your job,the self training programs stinks, management hasn't a clue if you don't understand. The LAID offs are Unbelievable, with so many locations they could try to offer employment opportunities in other departments, to keep dedicated Employees. If you are 55 or older you can FORGET about getting another position once LAID off. I have applied to at least 50 positions some well below my experience level and to this day have heard nothing, some positons applied for are still pending over 6 months on my profile. Age discrimination is very much the case, none of the 55 and older laid off were welcome back. We have families, obligations and need to survive just like the young candidates. The benefits are slowly being reduced. Most of management are below 30 years of age and keep their buddies well informed about up coming positions in order to keep them employed. The salaries and increases are very low compared to medium to high managers. It's all about nepotism and favorites, No degree is important.

review_title: It’s a job, but not a company I’d refer friends to work if they don’t have to.
pros:
Benefits are great. Love holidays off.
Pay is decent, but not worth the stress.
cons:
Required to work every Saturday.  And have to explain why you are taking a Saturday off with your vacation. 

You get wrote up monthly if you miss a goal no matter how rough the traffic flow is, and yet you are paid incentive quarterly. So you could get wrote up two months and still fund for incentive. Then others could skim through as minimalist not meet goal or fund but meet minimal number to skirt by without a write up. 

If you want to move up good luck. You get hired and are pegged to be in a specific spot and never move. It is a “friends” game to move up anywhere.

pros: great beneofts and pay without having a degree

pros: Developing customer relationships was a plus
cons: Never get off on time

review_title: Overall, BofA is a great place to work
job_title: Senior Vice President in Tampa, FL
pros: Lots of diverse opportunities within different segments, geographies, roles, etc. for career growth and advancement.  Stable franchise with great breadth and reach provides some certainty of employment. Great benefits package and strong associate focused culture.  Pay for performance philosophy and an organization that operates as an inclusive meritocracy.  Senior management seems to take great pride in communicating with 200,000+ associates.  The bank is very image conscious and operates events with a high degree of class.  Management is generally focused on ensuring that there is an appropriate work/life balance and encourages employees to donate their time in the communities that they serve.
cons: Lack of investment in the operational infrastructure leads to complicated workaround solutions that aren't always scaleable.  Focus on bottom line contribution leads to nominal investment in non-revenue generating activities even though they may improve operational effectiveness.  Very conservative culture that values consensus decision making, which can frustrate Type A personalities that like to make decisions without waiting for all the information.  Centralized command structure and hierarchial management approach causes there to be many layers between front-line personnel and senior executives which can slow the flow of information throughout the organization.  Six sigma discipline sometimes causes managers to be overly analytic leading to decision paralysis by analysis.

review_title: Still holding out hope for BAC
job_title: Senior Vice President  in Boston, MA
pros:
Work life balance
Benefits package
Good people
An organization that takes into consideration the needs of others.  BAC has consistently allowed associates to be fliexible in terms of going for further education, some times working remotely if need be and other measures that take into account the needs of the associate.  
People at the bank are nice.  BAC has a good culture.  The culture is not the same throughout BAC but does have a strong presence in Charlotte, CA, Florida, TX and some of the other well known AC foot print markets.  The core value are critical for success but not enough to get promoted.
cons:
Darn right difficult to move up in organization
Company has a good career search tool that finally has gotten better with staff responding to inquiries.  However, the down side of the response back has all been no job for you.  Performance reviews have consistently been meet, meet but no career change in several years.  Feel stuck.  Difficult to move within an organization of a quarer of a million people without a strong, strong sponsor.  Sponsor needs to be some one that cares about you and your career.  Otherwise, high risk of being loss in the shuffle, especially after merger after merger.

review_title: Great place to work, if you are a robot
pros: Great Benefits, 401K, medical, etc
cons: Merrill Edge asked that you memorize a script to use with each and every client.  You are not allowed to keep notes at your desk to remind you of the script.  Calls are often monitored and any deviation to the script is a strike against you.  Your customers satisfaction, additional investments brought in, etc does not matter to management- only your ability to memorize the script.

job_title: Centralized Small Business Banker in Tampa, FL
pros: The compensation is good, and the work hours are great! You don't have to source your own leads.
cons:
Management thinks that sales is a process that can be same for everyone. Individuality is not encouraged - barely permitted. The managers will encourage you to help other associates who are new, but not compensate you for that time lost. The crazy part is that you will show up negative in reports for doing it, and the answer given is "you didn't have to do it".
In my opinion, the worst part of the organization is that it promotes based upon who you know. Leaders actually came in to talk to us telling us that our merit (what we actually do) is not nearly as important as who can tell the story for you. Silly me, I thought that's what a resume is for.
Nope! They will tell you quite plainly that they would rather have a sales person do 100% of goal than 150% of goal (and be "well rounded", and they will also tell you that your compensation will change based upon the performance of others, Beware of that! In an "individual contributor" role you should never be compensated based upon what others do.

pros: Great company benefits, 401k match, great health insurance... That's it
cons: Too much stress for the pay. Boa is short staffing every center and is micromanaging rm's. Sales goals are unachievable-almost laughable. Rm's that reach their goals have someone shadowing them and get credit for everything the other person opens. It is ridiculous! Short staffing leads to longer wait times and hard time selling to a client that has waited too long in the lobby. They expect you to do client intros - so you stand behind the teller line, behind the one teller and introduce yourself to clients. When you have only 3 people working at the line out the door it gets pretty chaotic. And rm's are expected to migrate clients to ATMs or mobile app, achieve sales goals, make 30 calls per week, do intros and also make sure all your paperwork is correct. Micromanaging is to the minute from who you met, what u talked about and when you will follow-up. Takes too much time.

pros: VPN access to work offsite if needed.
cons:
HUGE LABOR LAW VIOLATION!!! Pay is below minimum wage per hour. This is only position where the bank is willing to break labor laws to force you to bill 40 hours on timesheet yet in reality you work 60+hrs/week. They won't pay you for the difference.

You're assigned to a senior loan officer and supposedly work in their team with them getting 20-30% cut of your production for "supposed" coaching and mentoring. Bad team leader, you fail from the get go and they still get a cut of your production.

Lots of bad politics where management gives all the PE discounts to only 2-5 individuals who are his moneymakers. Everyone else are treated like idiots needing to write essays just to get their clients 0.25% PE discounts.

When you get competitive loan estimates to bat for your clients, management doesn't want to make money and doesn't want to do business.

Need to do branch coverage with really bad referral leads. PBs who give you the leads only get incentives for effort to sent you garbage referrals.

If management wants you to do too much branch coverage to deal with garbage referrals, you will fail at job ASAP.

Before I left, policies got changed where incompetent management prioritizes branch coverage instead of having you actually go out and get real business leads. This sets you up for massive failure.

Management only cares about nepotism in bring in their immediate family members(kids) into management positions.

pros: Great Benefits and incentives payouts
cons: working on the weekends, workload can be heavy

pros: The department I worked in was somewhat flexible with respect to leaving early for doctors appointments, long lunches on Friday, etc.  The benefits are quite good for those who have children but, of course, just status quo for people who don't. However, it should be noted that there is no onsite day care facility and the cafeteria is not subsidized.  I realize these are fairly superficial reasons to rate as the best reason to work for the company; however, there are so many reasons NOT to work for this company that this is all that I could come up with.
cons: There is still an "old boys club" that continues to persist.  There are some older men at the Company who do not see women as equals and worthy of respect. I have seen instances in which women questioned  (bone-headed) decisions were summarily dealt with. Managers still manage 1950s by belittling you and browbeating you to make you feel inferior.  As someone who dealt with customers and the public, the company has gotten so big that the level of service that I could provide would not justify the fees we charged. No one knows what is going on and with the US Trust and LaSalle Bank mergers--this has only gotten worse.

pros: Great insurance plans, and if you perform well as far as referrals and daily balancing, you could be given awards to recognize your performance. With each award, you accumulate points, and you can use those points to redeem them for gift cards, electronics, appliances, etc. Lots of opportunities to grow, if you want to move up in the company.
cons: Staffing has drastically been reduced in many banking centers, and the work load has steadily increased. Therefore, you might find yourself feeling overwhelmed with tasks and not enough time to get things done. Hardly ever a free moment at my old banking center, my poor supervisors were always stressed out and overworked, and as a result, there were many mistakes in the way the banking center was managed, from cash management to the way the work was processed, to tellers being out of balance at the end of the day. If you're looking for a job in banking, I recommend working for a smaller bank, not a major national bank like BOA

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in Plano, TX
pros: Nice benefits, vacation, 401k matching, dental, vision
cons: Managers don't want to manage. You ask for help on an issue and they pretend to be doing something else or simply give a bs answer to get you out of their face. The pay isn't high enough for what you have to go through honestly. Promises of advancement, but every move is a lateral move. Titles change without pay. VERY HIGH turnover rate. Several people being wrongfully terminated. Some managers actively looking for reasons to fire associates and managers as well.

review_title: Great benefits, grueling work at call centers.
job_title: Small Business Priority Service Team in Tampa, FL
pros: Well paying, straight forward work, paid training, employee recognition, sick days, vacation time.
cons: Customers, systems used to perform different tasks, scenarios where there's nothing you can really do, but still need to listen to people's issues. The work itself is repetitive and can be frustrating. You are micro-managed to the fullest extent. Needed to take a minute to grab a drink of water? Someone will ask you about. Needed to use the bathroom outside of a scheduled bread? Someone will ask about. Even if it's a few minutes, the anxiety and depression that stemmed from this position is what led me to eventually leave despite the good pay and benefits.

pros: tuition reimbursement, child care reimbursement, green vehicle reimbursement, adoption reimbursement, discount programs.
cons: Goals are tough and usually attainable but are usually ok as long as you're above 90% to goal. Otherwise, expect a verbal followed by a written. They'll leave you alone if you're meeting goals but as soon as you fail to meet them they are on you about how you need to improve. Expect lots of role-playing scenarios and constant checking in on your numbers throughout the day. Aggressive sales environment.  Some locations have the traffic for the bankers to meet goals. Other areas, not so much. If customers aren't coming to the bankers they want you behind the teller line or walking the waiting line engaging with customers to commit to sitting with the banker for a "financial review".  This results in some upset customers who are already waiting for a banker for a non-sales transaction.

pros: Consistent hours and some wonderful co-workers (who quite frankly deserve better).
cons:
Training was downright silly. I learned a script, I didn't learn product. We were rated, during training, on our ability to follow a script without sounding like we were following a script. 
Post training and starting the job - we were shamed every day via group e-mail, several times a day - always doing poorly (in fact before I was even allowed on the "floor" I was doing poorly).  It was completely demoralizing to the point where even before I was doing the job I had a terrible pit in my stomach telling me how horrible this place was.  
Long story short, after surviving the training and after only a week "on the job" I quit. I knew I wouldn't be able to stomach the feel of a company who treats its employees so terribly and only pretends to care about its customers.  My decision to quit was validated (first by a thumbs up from my direct "stuck there" co-workers) and second by the fact that the my regional manager entered my status as "terminated" so as not to let my quitting look bad on him, which quite frankly made me chuckle.

pros: Good Benefits, building in good condition.
cons: Wages are below the average.

review_title: Bait and switch/Loan Officer Salary at Bank of America

job_title: Team Lead, Loan Review Analyst in Westlake Village, CA
pros: If you are working in the right department, where things don'g run based on favoritism, friendship and family, then you should find your self being a successful employee. The benefits are reasonable, some departments do give bonuses and if you work hard, you will be successful.
cons: There is no HR high overview on how some departments are being run by managers. If you complain to advise and counsel, they take note of your complain and will address it very lightly, but you will be gone before you can take any further action. They get rid of the people who are hard working, knowledgeable because they are not part of their "click" or group. There is no HR involvement on who they hire as long as the manager likes the person and they pass the background, they get in. So people who are more qualified will never get the chance if they don't know them. You don't even get a chance to be interviewed.

pros: The office is located in the best  possible area of the city, opposite small park and close by nice cafes and places to have lunch. Most of the people I met in the company were great at what they were doing and also good fun. The atmosphere was definitely a big advantage. The social committee was very active and there was office event at least once a month, such as wine tasting, quiz night. To be a member of the social club you had to pay around 5 Euro  a month but it was very worth it. With regard to the work itself - you could learn a lot and really from the best people; the systems they use are high tech and the customer service they provide is really high so definitely great place to build your experience and develop your skills.
cons: Can not think about any major cons but probably all depends on the department you are in and the people you are working with. It is not really a cons but perhaps it could be good to have more internal  training, such as cross team training, so people can understand better what is happening in different teams/departments.

job_title: Video Teller Agent in Newark, DE
pros: The atmosphere is great and everyone I worked with was extremely friendly, I made some great friends there. Call volume is low Tuesday-Thursday. When I was there, there was plenty of voluntary time off, so you could leave unpaid for hours if you needed to do something or just, ya know, didn't feel like working. Management was pretty good from my experience, and the man in charge of the site cared about his workers and did what he could to help. Since it is a large corporation, there were many opportunities to move to another position after you had been there for a year. But oh man, what a year.
cons: Mondays and Fridays were BRUTAL. Back to back calls, it was hard to even catch your breath sometimes. Management did what they could to help but volume is volume. On top of that, more and more things were being added all the time for you to fit in a call, I was a top performer but was constantly annoyed with all the things we had to say. It's also customer service, so you had to deal with people.. Which is never really a good thing.

pros: They have very in depth training
cons: I was basically demoted on my interview from the position that I applied for and was interviewing for. When I got to training, there were people far less qualified than I was that were filling the role I had applied for. That was the beginning. The training is extensive, as expected for a large corporation. However, the location I was sent to essentially just turned me into a glorified teller who was heavily micromanaged. The manager was promoted which left the assistant manager (or whatever position they call it) in charge, who had her own motives and desires that were outside of company policy. She didn't want me to leave until everyone "left together" when I was done with my work 20 mins prior, but then criticized me for being over my hours at the end of the week. Overall, it was a very poor working experience. I am glad I wasn't relying on that job as my sole future. Also, the opportunity for promotion is extremely slow. It would have taken me 2 years just to move up to the original position that I applied for. The purpose of applying for that one was to move up within a year to a Financial Adviser role which is where my qualifications would indicate I should have been.

pros: the company provides great benefits

review_title: Overall Great Place to Work. Good People, Great Benefits, Flexible Hours. Good Promotion Opportunity.
pros:
Bank of America is the Nations Largest Banking Company. They Offer a Comprehensive Benefits package that includes everything from health insurance, to discounts on credit products, to retirement packages (401K, Pension), to discounts at affiliate companies such as Verizon, AT&T, 1800-Flowers and much more. Other Benefits include, Paid Vacation Leave, Paid Tuition, Down Payment Assistance, Paid Maternity/Paternity Leave, Paid Jury Duty. 

As Far as working for Bank Of America, I have thusfar had a good experience. Everybody is happy and peppy. The tone is always that of exuberance for life and a desire to help.
cons: My personal banking center is very busy and there is absolutely no down time, EVER. This can become draining on the mind after the 5 or 6 hour mark. There are many rules and regulations that often get confusing and seem pointless. However we do deal with large sums of cash and there need to be checks and balances. Managment can be a little unorganized which can lead to stress on other employees.

pros: For a senior person with a lot of mojo and interest in working on a variety of efforts with little/no management, I'd highly recommend it; good benefits.   Communication from senior management is excellent when it comes to bank performance, industry issues and the competition.  They really go above and beyond to keep their associates well informed of these areas.  In terms of career opportunities, I'd again recommend a senior person apply rather than a junior person - someone who has a vision for what they want to accomplish it and the drive to accomplish.  You could otherwise get lost in a 300K+ associate organization.
cons: I would not recommend for those who are not very senior; junior folks I suspect would feel lost due to lack of onboarding.  The organization is extremely large as you would imagine and therefore extremely complex.   I have found work/life balance, despite the reports by working mother on this organization to be lacking and not well supported by management.  I have also found compensation to be a little less than the industry average.     I have found that employee morale is also lacking for many of the reasons I have mentioned above: lack of crosstraining, onboarding, knowledge transfer, and work/life balance.

pros: High traffic volume, which means sales opportunities. Large support system - 800 numbers to call for help if you need help. Latest technology. Opportunity to learn a lot, and then move on/up. Very diverse - associates and customers from all over the world. Good benefits. Costs will go down in 2011 for low paid associates.
cons: Sales driven environment. Aggressive goals. Complicated bonus structure which changes every year. Constantly busy since the centers often are under staffed. This makes it very hard to train new staff. Existing staff is overworked and longer wait time for customers. New staff who have not received enough training and associates who are rushing make more mistakes and do not deliver the best service. The staff is expected to help customers, do follow up calls, training, make sure policies are followed etc.

review_title: Very consuming and extreme demand from senior management.
job_title: Sales and Services Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros:
Health care benefits.  
Child care reimbursement benefits.
Ability to find few understanding coworkers to handle the day to day life at the bank. 
Call center managers willing to help associates in difficult situations.
cons:
Management pressure to handle every situation with making customer delighted, even when customer is defrauding or doing illegitimate transcations.
Limited networking channels, limited feedback reception from management.
Having to do the right thing for customer and the company, even when both interests clash, putting the employee in an awkward situation, which might cost employment status.

pros: The benefits are great for those who have children. And are in need of great medical.
cons: The reason why people are because the benefits are so good. The management is ridiculous they have no concern for their associates needs and wants.
