Don't get me wrong, there are those who are concerned about their associates , but for the most part they hire stupid people with absolutely no people skills and put them in management, just because they have a degree. Trust me a piece of paper does not account for taste. They also do pay fairly. they try to make you work for next to nothing and tell you be happy you have a job. And when you try to voice your frustrations you get shut down quick and treated like a problem child. This company thrives off of mediocrity.

review_title: Strong company with focus on growth and employees.
pros: As a long-time employee of Bank of America (over 30 years) I have had many opportunities. I have used the tuition reimbursement to obtain my degree and continue to look for growth opportunities to further my career. Bank of America has a strong commitment to the communities and I am proud of the work done through our volunteer activities. While not broadly advertised as other companies/corporations, Bank of America is very involved with many facets in communities throughout the United States. Affinity groups and other avenues for growth are available to help employees in their own development.
cons: Bank of America has great career growth opportunities in major metropolitan areas such as Charlotte, NC; Los Angeles, CA; Houston, TX; but in other areas it is very difficult to continue to grow in your career once you have achieved management level. You end up in the same position with little opportunity to move up unless someone retires or moves on.

job_title: Centralized Small Business Banker in Pasadena, CA
pros: Great benefits, vacation, sick and personal time off are awesome. Great employee networks and community volunteer programs. Room to advance, but only if you know the right people. If you get involved and play the corporate game, which you have to everywhere in order to advance, you'll go places.
cons: If you have been here for years, then you are in the clique and will be embraced, but if you are new then you are an outsider and will not be embraced or supported. Senior Executive and Site leader were the absolute worst people I have ever worked for. They talked down to us and said things to us that I never expected from an executive at Bank of America. Luckily, they have both been removed but the damage has already been done. Managers and employees have all left and they are not being replaced. This leads me to believe that the department will be transitioned some time soon. DO NOT ACCEPT A POSITION AS A CENTRALIZED SMALL BUSINESS BANKER IN PASADENA.

pros: The phone rings, that is it
cons: Horrible management, higher ups are so disconnected. Use you for customer service calls. No programs, high rates.

job_title: Telephone Sales Associate I in Dallas, TX
pros: Managers are genuinely concerned with how the associates are doing and with solving problems we run into. They are also concerned with helping associates move up within the company and with getting work experience. The building is very nice, and covered parking is wonderful in the heat. Associates have more than enough training with the technology and programs to be able to preform the job. Managers provide feedback at least once a week on the quality of calls and how you can improve (but this also means they're always listening, so you can't screw up!). The incentive is worth the time required to get it.
cons: Customers, like at any other job. We call customers who have past due credit card accounts, and no one likes being told they owe money. Most of the unpleasant customers will just lie or hang up on you, but occasionally one will yell and swear at you. Nothing you can do about it. Sometimes you can tell which ones will do it, but most of the time it's a surprise. Sometimes you get some really nice customers, though. The work can get horribly monotonous, like leaving messages all day, but you still get paid for it. The incentive is set high, but isn't unreasonable.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: The benefits package is very good here and lots of vacation time
cons: The managers treat the employees pretty bad. I've seen people get reprimanded publicly in front of everyone, like how a coach yells at their football team in the locker room. I've seem some of the "star" employees act like monsters-channeling the same rudeness and disrespect to other coworkers, especially new hires. The training is horrible, leaves you very unprepared for the floor. It is also sad to say that you have to use 8 different programs to do your job; Merrill Edge refused to pay the money to integrate the systems. You also have a list of over 100 numbers to transfer phone call to. Most brokerage firms can handle their own clients portfolio, from redemptions to purchase in one phone call. No, not at Merrill Edge. Since they don't want to integrate BOA's systems with ME, you have to transfer calls for everything. If you need to do a redemption check, you must transfer to department x, but wait, if it's a wire, it needs to be transferred to department y, and if its a bank transfer, needs to go to department z. Forbid if it's its a redemption from a retirement account, as that is whole additional set of call transfers!

review_title: The Demise of a Great Corporation (the Original Bank of America)
job_title: Vice President: Consulting Systems Engineer in Concord, CA
pros: Bank of America is a large company with enormous investment in IT, a wide assortment of equipment and roles. Benefits and pay are decent (used to be very good, although pension and retirement contributions continue to slide, as have several other benefits). Management is uneven (largely due to reorgs) but if you can find a strong manager,  it can be a productive place to work.
cons: For a variety of reasons, the Bank has been reducing staff dramatically, especially contractors. Many roles were offshored several years back (for example, most of the developers) and many that stayed onshore have been changed to contract positions. While the Bank used to have strong training programs, the current trend seems to be bringing in contractors with the required skills, then replacing them when new skills are needed. Reorgs are frequent (as the Bank keeps trying new tactics to stabilize costs). Staff (especially contractors) are constantly in a state of fear of being let go, and remaining staff have to add additional responsibilities to make up the difference.

review_title: Female VP -- the pay disparity is REAL
job_title: Senior Tech Manager, Vice President Level in Charlotte, NC
pros:
> Decent amount of opportunity... if you're male or from India
> If you like to be busy, this is a good place to start.  Lots to do, not always the most realistic approach or timelines, but lots to do.
> MyWork was very beneficial while it lasted.
cons:
> If you're female it's very difficult to move up, not impossible, but very difficult.
> If you're female, expect your salary to be below par and increases/bonuses to also be below par.
> If you're white, expect to be outsourced or replaced by H1B workers.
> Somebody with poor managerial skills decided to start retracting MyWork... so much for flexibility and reasonability, but oh, we still need you to cover things at all hours and you can still "work from home" after hours.  It just won't mean anything.
> Overtime pay?  What's that?  Oh, you thought full-time was 40hours a week. Ha! We'll expect at least 50 but only pay you for 40 at a rate below what others pay for the same work.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Pot lucks, benefits and volunteer opportunities. You get to use the brand of the company when selling and a lot of existing customers with the bank.
cons: Very stressful, you're not a employee that is known as a person; you're just another number, unstable and unpredictable commission structure, greedy bank; they always want more from your performance measures and don't want to pay your worth for the production, unorganized, operating tools are very poor to perform your job effectively, many IT issues with systems, upper management do not communicate with you on company changes or why; they just sporadically change requirements and goals, micromanaged, your voice is not heard when you voice your concerns, you always feel threatened to keep your position or easily replace you, typical corporate environment, strict and unreasonable expectations.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: I have no pros to report
cons: Incompetent management, biased, its who you know

pros: Medical Benefits, the ability to relocate within the company and the ability to move forward with the company.
cons: You can move forward with the company as long as it's good for them, but if they don't have anyone to replace you then you lose.  You lose employee after employee and take on way more positions then even manageable and do well at that working harder then you get paid for, then get reprimanded for any overtime you may accrue for making sure your center runs the way that it should.  I currently work 3 positions in my center and barely get paid for one. And get no recognition at that.  They always tell you that you will be "taken care of" and then nothing happens.  It makes you wonder who your trying for anymore since you never see compensation for all the effort you put in.

pros: Great position for someone who is a career changer - you get paid a salary, which is either under 50k, or 50-70k, the salary level you choose will decide what your production hurdles will be.  So you can elect a higher base but you will have higher production hurdles.  They pay you to study, get your 7 and 66, and Health/Life Insur License.  The prospecting and acquiring clients is BRUTAL!  Do not kid yourself, the failure rate is extremely high.  I have plenty of experience in marketing and it is sooo hard.  Looking back I would not have started in this program.  I am just hitting my hurdles but dont see this trend able to continue into the coming months as hurdles start increasing.  I am contemplating looking for other positions.
cons: The hurdles for production and huge, and prospecitng is extremely difficult.  Cold calling is impossible with do not call lists.  No one responds to mailers.  Seminar success is very low and those that do want follow up drag their feet.  You starve for even small accounts.

review_title: Brilliant people stifled by incompetent, insecure, and indecisive senior leadership.
job_title: Strategic Marketing Executive in Charlotte, NC
pros: Decent pay, limitless resources, good work/life balance and genuinely nice people to work with.
cons: They don't care about customers at all. If they could earn an extra $5 by foreclosing on someone, they will. They chase short term goals at the expense of long term strategy, which makes sense since every senior leader is more concerned with internal politics and saving his/her job than actually building the business. The corporate culture is a classic "nice-guys-finish-last" environment where any executive who's actually concerned with growing his/her teammates or fighting for the customer gets fired or forced out in favor of the loud mouthed executive who rules through fear and intimidation.

pros: The company offer great benefits and from the start you accrue time off. Met great people while working at the financial center.
cons: The job is not what its cracked up to be. The market sales managers are just sales people who need to sale the job in order to hire and to keep employees in these positions. We were told everyday that its not a sales job, that everything we do is for the clients but in reality we were being pushed to meet our monthly sales goals. We had targets to hit and a certain amount of calls to make a day. Not at all the role of helping people like they made it seem. Also there is no room for advancement. They rather higher from the outside or use temp agencies for corporate positions. Working at a banking center is extremely slow due to the foot traffic dropping every year. It truly felt like a waste of time working there.

job_title: Commercial Credit Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: A lot of opportunities to learn
cons: Dishonest. Told us we would only go up to 3 million in exposure.... immediately changed as soon as we started working. Gave us goals after just randomly selecting people to be promoted one year, a lot of people did twice the work and carried two pipelines only to find out at the very last minute after being told by managers we deserved to be promoted that the criteria had changed for promotions and we needed to be high performers for another year to get our promotions. Very deceitful and deceptive. Most strong workers have gotten outta here, others of us were caught off guard when we did not get our promotions that were promised. Place is going downhill fast!

pros: I loved my coworkers and the customers.
cons: Management was insane and made employees cry daily.

pros: Lot to learn ang gain
cons: Slow, conventioanal office culture space

review_title: Bank of America is not the place to be employed with
pros: The ability to move to another department.
cons: This was overall a horrible place to work for.

pros: The company has outstanding benefits, mental, dental, vision, life, 401k, employee discount programs etc. You get discounts on your phone bill, concert tickets and tickets to theme parks to name a few.
cons: The best part about working there was the benefits and the discounts you get are about the most fun you'll have working there. Horrible management. They hire people that are no where near qualified to be in management, that have no social or people skills. The pay is low. There is never any money in the budget for raises and promotions only come if play teacher's pet to upper management. The goals are absolutely ridiculous. If you work here, you will be forced to push products down people's throats, most of which they don't need. I've seen lots of unethical practices done just to make those goals. Be prepared to work crazy hours, most likely not the ones you are hired for, crazy overtime, become forced to come in on your days off and shipped off to whatever understaffed branch they feel like sending you to when it's convenient for them. It is an overly stressful environment. Do yourself a favor and don't even bother applying here.

review_title: If you have a high stress tolerance...
job_title: Fraud Analyst II in Kennesaw, GA
pros: The benefits were pretty good when I first started working there . Overtime pay would keep my check looking healthy.
cons: They got to a point where they were completely stopping with rewards (incentives) so people stopped wanting to come to work to take verbal abuse for 8-10 hours depending on your shift. Oh and they started making crazy changes to the work schedule so if you haven't been there for 2 years or more (regardless if you're meeting the metrics or hitting your numbers) you would have to take a late shift 2-10:30 or 3-11:30 before I left they were making everyone share desks and I heard recently they were laying people off

review_title: Good employer but risky if you are looking for long-term stability
pros: If you are competent, there are many opportunities to perform engaging work and thrive. The bank also has good and supportive programs for minority workers and the LGBT communities. However, like any other enormous corporation, much depends on the line of business you are in and the culture of that line of business.
cons:
Bank of America is struggling right now to deliver its products and services as cost-effectively as its competitors (i.e., Wells, JP). Because it is less efficient than its competitors, it frequently and publicly resorts to layoffs to achieve its financial goals. While this is good for shareholders, it's not good for employees or contractors. Top performers are not immune from these cuts, either.

The bank's technology division is not nearly as diverse as it should be, generally favoring white european males at the highest level of the organization. Minorities, while abundant in lower level jobs are less visible at the mid- or  senior-management levels. There are many female executives in the bank's technology division; most of them are white.

At the most senior levels of the technology division, the bank seems to prefer to hire people from outside the bank rather than promoting from within. Former Goldman Sachs employees are especially popular with bank leadership right now.

pros:
Associate discounts (Museums On Us, YMCA, Lynda.com, etc)

Offer reimbursement for professional development expenses and memberships

EAP program

Company is large, so employees can spend their career at this company and find a variety of roles and challenges that allow them to continue to learn and experience new things
cons:
Worked here for ~20 years and BofA became progressively worse and worse to work for over the years. The amount of hours employees are expected to
Work are outrageous. They have slowly taken away all benefits: No pay increases for those making over a certain $, no flexibility (horrible place to work for working parents: no understanding nor care of work / life balance), health insurance coverage less and less. Management treats employees horribly. No one cares about their employees or their hard work. Management only cares about how they can continue to get ahead while taking credit for their teams’ work. Employees constantly fear losing their jobs because of annual layoffs. Constant change and reorganizations result in work never getting done and no continuity in career planning or progression for employees. Company no longer offers parking allowance, employee daycare or flexible work options. Horrible.

pros: The pay is really good. Bonuses can come up to be almost about the same as what salary would be making your paycheck double sometimes. It's a great place to work because of all of the recognition from management. The motivation of other employees is not as good as what might be expected of large corporations. I would really like to see more employees being more willing and able to give more to the company than what is occuring now. It would be much better to see more employees being recognized for all of their hard work. Overall I feel its a great place to work.
cons: The motivation of other employees is not as good as what might be expected of large corporations. I would really like to see more employees being more willing and able to give more to the company than what is occuring now. It would be much better to see more employees being recognized for all of their hard work. The pay is really good. Bonuses can come up to be almost about the same as what salary would be making your paycheck double sometimes. It's a great place to work because of all of the recognition from management. Its still a good place to work.

review_title: Bureaucratic and overly burdened by process - employees don't have a face
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: They will give you praise for a job well done and work will be recognized, at least in the verbal sense. Not too hard to build a good reputation here if you are hard-working and friendly. Will have more momentum and opportunities with the acquisition of Merrill Lynch - BofA's corporate culture has started to absorb some of Merrill's qualities and will make it a potential powerhouse for Wall Street in the future.
cons: They pay much less than the current market - salaries are totally undercut here. Tend to focus on building a ridiculous amount of processes instead of employees. Very bureaucratic and too many layers to push through - one can feel like a very small cog in a large wheel at times. Too many "cooks in the kitchen" and your opinion/responsibilities can be diminished. Management does not always have the appropriate expertise or background and do not effectively manage employee's expectations, resulting in miscommunication and frustration. Tendency to "overpraise" and not focus on negatives/improvements. Feeling of respect and "family-like" culture at Merrill was lost with the acquisition.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in East Providence, RI
pros: I worked for BOA for over 4 years. I loved their technology and any positive changes that helped their customers better managed their accounts. I loved the idea that I can submit a feedback on the "watercooler", and changes are made as a result. The best part of working for Bank of America was my teammates. I miss them all. While I was there, I was going to school full-time, and they were very flexible with my school schedule.
cons: The 2 reasons why I left Bank of America is because, first, after I completed my degree in Economics, I wanted to advanced within the Bank, but I was not successful. I was told I did not meet the experience requirements (I got the same job with a competitor that was willing to train me). Second, Bank of America pays very low. I was hired at $11.75. I left making $12.85. Today, I make twice that much with their competitor. I never complained because I thought it was a company I could retire with. I came to realize, Bank of America does not really practice its values. They are only on paper.

review_title: Absence of Professionalism on a Grand Scale
job_title: Policy Writer in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Very well paying, if not, overpaid position.  Great cafeteria.
cons: The company is top heavy, populated by many experienced executives who are unusually devoid of professionalism and the ability to effectively and competently manage their assigned departments. Like many mammoth corporations, Bank of America has managers who live thousands of miles away from the departments they oversee. The department I temporarily worked for had several employees who were being paid in excess of $50 an hour but who had little idea of what they were doing. Luckily, several had "friends" in management which ensured their continued employment. The manager who I worked under, had her office in Canoga Park, California. Though she had an amazing vocabulary and an impressive resume, she was incapable of providing guidance, responding to concerns, implementing training, and comprehending information sent to her in writing. And though it was evident to many employees that she was ill-fitted to oversee staff (clearly did not possess people skills), her superiors seemed incapable of exacting corrective measures.

pros: Good Pay, Good Learning tools for doing your job, many positions available to transfer to or advance your career.
cons: Poor organization, no individuality or approval authorizations - you often have to contact mediation teams, other 800 phone numbers, and email teams to get things resolved for customers.  This can be very frustrating since nobody is authorized to fix issues from within your office.  BofA is very much about levels and authorizations.  It tends to operate like a giant government agency.

job_title: Senior Business Control Specialist in Richmond, VA
pros: Able to work remotely, great benefits, decent amount of paid time off, flexible schedule, great team and great people. I adored those I worked for and with for years and was able to take advantage of BofA's library of courses and learning opportunities. Made some great connections both personal and professional.
cons: It's very difficult to move up or get promoted, you deal with difficult and sometimes unqualified upper management, there are indiscriminate layoffs, constant reorganization and fear of being moved or laid off. Some of the executives were not at all in touch with what their teams were working on or what they had accomplished. This was difficult as you get moved almost constantly and have to re-explain yourself and your role and contributions. Half the time the executive didn't care and eventually you were moved again.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good base salary and bonus based on performance. Bank customers not happy with low interest rates with savings accounts and CD's are often willing to open brokerage accounts to try and get better return.
cons: Micromanagement and being pulled in many different directions. Responsible for both banking and investments. You are basically a personal banker that can open up investment accounts. If you are in a good location, a high traffic bank with people that have money you will do fine. However, most people today use online/mobile banking and rarely come into the bank. They use antiquated financial planning software- you can simply google better software then they provide. Constantly changing metrics for bonus that have eventually become nearly impossible to meet. Must open about 25 investment accounts per quarter to meet minimum expectations. Very negative management, constantly sending out nasty emails threatening disciplinary action for every little thing. Software often doesn't work therefore you get in trouble for not doing something that you were supposed to do. Pretty much a misereable place to work. Only 1 person I know has lasted 4 years. Mostly hire young people out of college who don't know any better.

pros: I've really enjoyed working at Merrill Edge. I've worked here for over 3 years at this point. Of all the places I've worked, this has the most opportunity for progression as well as increase in pay. You don't have to knock on doors, you don't have to hand out fliers or brochures. As long as you work hard, put in the time, and make the necessary amount of calls, you will make >$100k in a year to a year and a half. It seems unrealistic, but it happened to me.
cons: The service and back office support is very lackluster. I'm a very aggressive, client-centered advisor, so it is frustrating when my back office will not help a client meet their objective. The back office is less than supportive, and in most cases, are not empathetic to the client's needs. I understand there are protocols and procedures, but you must make adjustments when working with high net worth clients.

review_title: Overall a solid company that could become stronger by weeding out mediocrity
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Clackamas, OR
pros: Big company, good benefits, some talented people.
cons: Big company with lots of fat.  No accountability or consistency in loan processing centers.  Management doesn't support their most valuable asset (their people).  Rather the focus on shareholder benefit and extreme profitability is too high a priority (b/c senior management holds stock options, where most individual contributors do not).  Management has an entitlement attitude - from National to Regional to Local - and believe that their job security is most important.

job_title: Senior Quality Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: In a non-branch environment you do not have the pressure placed upon you when it comes to pushing products. Your position is specific to the department you are in, and your performance is based on the quality of the job you do. In these positions management encourages personal growth and advancing oneself. Onsite managers are open to the associates ideas and concerns, and they will work with you in problem resolution-personal or in ones performance.
cons: Since the Great Recession of 2009 job security is much less certain. Many areas in the mortgage section continue to be downsized due to still tight consumer loan qualifying, especially for refinancing. Departments which used to have 125 to 150 auditors now have 10 or 12. Other departments are moving associates to other area or laying. Until the economy improves for the consumer looking to buy or refinance, this section will continue to run lean or decline.

review_title: Ok, good place to get licensed
pros: Starting in CORE 1 unlicensed, your only real job is to pass the series 7 and 66.  There is some on the job training, and online classing but you are basically studying ALL THE TIME.  Good place to break in, put Merrill Lynch on your resume and either grow from within or join another firm.  A great launchpad or beginning of a career in the financial services industry.
cons: Company has a stick 120 day policy to complete both the 7 and 66.  My U4 was delayed, and I was finally able to take my 7 on day 100.  Materials were not provided for the 66 until passing the 7.  I passed, and then had only two weeks to study for the 66.  I missed the exam by 2 questions and was terminated.  I though they would give me once more shot, since the compliance department acted so slowly, but that was not the case.  Management will not work with you at all, or transfer you to a different department.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in Norfolk, VA
pros: pretty good benefits and great perks ... I learned a lot about credit cards  and mortgage loans
cons: After 17 years of  services .. My unit was sold to a new company but we still did the same bank of america work.. Pretty much we became contractors for bank of america .. there was a layoff in two years ... so that was very hurtful ..  I know business is business..  But wow!!

review_title: Typical large corporate job, if you're in good with the right people your career will go well.
job_title: Assistant Vice President Credit Derivatives App Support in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits comparable with other companies in the industry. Company large enough where you can make innumerable lateral moves. Moving up the ladder will take great political skills, many late nights, and an iron clad liver because most of the important meetings during untie happened during happy hour.
cons: Like most companies if you're in a support role you're under appreciated until there is disaster that could've been avoided because you were warning them many many months in advance. There is lots of redundancy in roles which leads to constant layoffs, but there is so much churn at the senior management level that it seems as though they will never get to a point where there's not excessive waste this leading to the constant massive layoffs. And for those who may be thinking the layoffs were in response to the housing crisis in my first week at the bank well before the crash two people on the team I was hired to work on wee laid off. Layoffs are as much a part of the culture as the "free checking."

job_title: Operations Fulfillment Team Leader in Fontana, CA
pros:
- They have good benefits for all the employees
-  Nice working facilities with excellent technology
-  Atmosphere is great in some locations that allows you to work as a family
cons:
Company has way too many Chiefs and they are all not on the same page. This creates too much stress on associates.
The goals that associates are given are way out of reach, causing associates to never meet goals and/or bonus
Management needs to ensure that when they are placing managers in the different lines of bossiness. These managers need to know how the jobs are completed and the complexity of these jobs.
Associate positions should have salaries for what they are are completing and the job descriptions provided. Not giving them more tasks without increasing there compensation accordingly.

review_title: Be pepared for stress and no work/life balance
job_title: Mortgage Team Lead in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: Good Medical Benefits and fairly good salary, bonuses were fair.  My direct boss was great - fair and a great mentor.
cons: Most employees work the system and take advantage any way they can.  Advice and Counsel is afraid to fire employees until it's so obvious they finally do it, but the action has to be  egregious.  Employees are treated far better than middle management.   Upper Management changes incentive plans in the middle of the year which always favors B of A and not the employees.  Site leaders at our site were very, very political and if they didn't like you, they made sure you knew it.  Plenty of stress, no work life balance, upper management could care less.  Many nights was at work till 10 pm, started at 8 am.  It became expected.  Negative press about all the financial penalties (in the BILLIONS) has caused many people and customers to despise B of A and they didn't mind telling you.

review_title: Good to work for though heavily regulated
pros:
Generous PTO for Band 5 and lower employees
Great parental leave benefits for new parents regardless of gender
Very inclusive towards the LGBT community
Matching 401k.  5% match per paycheck and a yearly 2% contribution around bonus time, not performance based
BoA is now stepping up to provide employees with continued job training that's actually relevant to their jobs
cons:
In 2015 we laid off a large chunk of our workforce.  For years every department on the tech side was dealing with a skeleton staff and too much to do as a result.  Getting anyone's attention for mission critical issues was challenging to say the least.  It's starting to get better as of 2018.
There are many employees that simply don't know what their job is and were never provided with appropriate training to do it.  An effort needs to be made on a department by department basis to resolve this.  
Still a lot of training that has no bearing to what we actually do.  My job is on the tech end and I have absolutely nothing to do with reviewing customers' accounts.  I don't need training on money laundering etc . This mandatory training is a waste of time for many employees

pros:
- Unparalleled flexibility with scheduling and working from home
- $5k and a premium mortgage to all associates
- $1k to design your own home office and $150 a month to make sure you have a top notch internet connection
- Facilities are swank depending on where you work (i.e. 1 Bryant Park, parts of the Corp Center, Hearst)
- Depending on where you work, you will meet some extremely intelligent and amazing people that have worked all over the world and the Fortune 500
cons:
- Like I said, DEPENDING on where or who you work with makes a huge impact on the job. With 250-300k employees, you are bound to have amazing managers and associates on one team and a god-awful manager and incompetent associates on another. And even that could be influenced by your own personality and qualities you think are positive in a manager...
- Core compensation could be improved and HR practices could be softened. Those guys have ice running in their veins at times...
- Echo previous comments, the rewards and recognition and any sort of team building or associate engagement activity has been wiped out completely after TARP. Maybe we'll see some green-shoots in a year or two...

pros: Good benefits package, 401k matching, and other resources that you would expect for a large company. BOA is a huge place so you can create the opportunity to network with most anyone at any level in any line of business. You are limited by your ambition.
cons:
It seems that most MBA programs outside of the investment bank are poorly structured. This is true for the CB program. You are not an integral part of the office you join (unless you have prior underwriting experience) and there are no real goals/expectations for you. Developing a skill set proves to be difficult as you are viewed as a temp. Probably the most unappealing aspect of the program is that it does not feed into a position. You are responsible for finding a full time position within the bank by the time the program wraps. Given the current market its nice to have a job, but the program leaves a lot to be desired from a career standpoint. Would not recommend to others.

From a networking standpoint, the sky is the limit. But if you would like to pursue an opportunity you dig up things can get sticky. You must get permission from your current boss to apply or be considered for any position within BOA.

review_title: A good place to work if you have a good manager
pros: It is a very big financial company. The pay is good, compare to some small companies.
cons: I have worked for multiple managers. Some managers are very nice and really take care of their associates. But I had a very unhappy experience when I worked for one manager, who do not know how to manage people. My manager is always at least ten minutes late for our one on one meeting. During our meetings, my manager always picks up or calls out for other phones, checks and writes other emails, never focus on our conversations. Besides, many times I got a new assignment, which is not in my business as usual job responsibility.  But the instruction was just one or two sentences in email, and need it ASAP or by the end of day! Those assignments actually are big assignments or a project, which at least need one week to finish from end to end. So my dissatisfaction is that I was overworked and my manager does not know how to communicate and manage well.

review_title: Excellent benefits, pay is little below market, telecommuting, hard to advance, you are a number.
job_title: Senior QA Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits are top notch as 4 weeks vacations, a lot of holidays, working from home, great flexibility, military friendly, they pay full time the 2 weeks of reserve AT.
cons:
Extremely highly regulated, poor project management, project managers are temps that don't know people and applications that are managing, no room for movement to other departments (at least in my unit), no training is provided to expand knowledge, never worked less than 9 hours per day, too many foreigners, mostly from India, working like robots create a serious work/life management issue. It's a big corporation, you are just a number. They hire and you fire you at will. Again, this is my experience in the Global Operations and Technologies in the mortgage and insurance. 
Salary is below the market rate, however the benefits can offset that.
They keep "re aligning" the company, with a lot of lay offs and I personally changed manager 5 times in two years, harassed by one, not a stable place to work for sure.

review_title: Overall, great experience but felt no room to advance.
pros: Team and associates worked so hard and loyalty to the bank.  Knowledge and skills developed here were great for own life and future career.
cons: No work life balance in retail and no room for advancing.

pros: Stable hours, good benefits (insurance, 401k, free bank accounts, employee support).  You can wear casual clothes (no shorts or flip flops tho) and no need to worry about tattoos or piercings.
cons: How much support you get and how much you like your job will depend on how much your manager likes you.  Also your raises.  And the fact that they try to sneak in different skills for the associates without telling us and gradually changing our group (say your hired skill was "Tier 1" but then they start slowly adding "Preferred" and start calling you a "Preferred gate" but without the band jump and pay raise?  Pretty low.  If the gate is changing, just say so!  Train the employees and give them their deserved raises for their skills!

pros:
I have heard some teams are good to work on, will help you to improve yourself. 
I used to enjoy working here, looked forward to going to work.
cons:
I used to enjoy what I did here. I loved to create and design software. I am good at it. Several years ago our management structure changed. I as taken off coding and asked to lead the others. Not to be their manager but to tech lead them. This was ok for a short time until the managers were giving me their governance stuff to do while they would start designing and giving code advice.  The SVP level and below decided they should be deep in the details of all the projects, micro-managing all the aspects of them.  
I have learned other software languages to see if I could find another area in the bank to move to. It seems here, the only way out/off the team is to leave the bank and maybe come back later.   
I thought the managers were supposed to help you with your career here ???

review_title: Great employer, not the role for me
job_title: Telephone Sales Representative in Belfast, ME
pros: Excellent benefits, training, room for growth, decent pay, bright people
cons: Decent pay if you're willing to work for it. Unlimited over-time. As a seasoned sales consultant I feel the goals were unrealistically high, you'd have to work overtime to make the highest tier. Keep in mind you take call after call, no longer than 10 seconds in between calls! I shouldn't have to work like a rat chasing goals to be achieve top tier. I couldn't even get to know the colleague who sat next to me. You're in that cubicle with two 15 min breaks and lunch, other than that you work like a dog. And it better be perfect because the slightest mistake is a fail. After training you're thrown to the wolves, think you can sale anything? Try selling to a client who thinks they're calling in to make a payment! Call too short? Fail. Not enough calls? Fail. Surprised they don't fail ya for forgetting the period at the end of a sentence.

pros: Good working hours, good location
cons: Terrible management, Cut-throat company, no training

pros: Working at Bank of America was the best thing that I decided to do while going to college. They were very flexible in working with my school schedule. They also had a tuition reimbursement plan that I decided to take advantage of. The hours are great. The work load was not hard, being that I was a professional teller. They have a good corporate culture. Upper level management took the time to come into our banking center gave us great feedback, Also at Bank of America, the dress code is just business casual and at times we were able to wear jeans on Fridays.
cons: One of the main things that I would recommend to Bank of America is to not be understaffed at their banking centers. I worked at an extremely busy banking center and we were always short tellers. People were continuously waiting to be served and we were  never given more tellers to help out. Also recognition for excellent work ethics would be great to have, There should be some type of fairness in allocated whether a teller should work in the lobby or drive through. I think that referrals are implemented too much to achieve when customers want to be served quickly,

review_title: Operational Risk at Bank of America
pros: One of the best reasons to work at Bank of America is that for corporate jobs, employees are highly encouraged to work from home a majority of the time. This is not required by any means, but it is not only available as an option but also welcomed as a choice. The management in this position are highly flexibile, focusing more on getting the work done than if an employee is fifteen minutes late on a given work day. And taking time off is never an issue.
cons: If you do decide to work within a corporate office, it might be mostly empty due to the popularity of working at home! Also, new hire protocol is a mess, and even after getting settled in a given position or team, system access and software needs fluctuate. This often results in drawn-out attempts to obtain whatever access or program one needs due to a lack of written procedure or knowledge of who to contact for what.

review_title: Bank of America is a good place to work.
pros: It is the largest bank if not second largest to today’s date. Well compensated and benefits are good. I was a teller there and I loved working there but be careful tellers handle thousands of dollars in cash, checks, deposits etc. Great working environment supervisors and assistant manager always there to help you if you need it.
cons: Because you are working with thousands of dollars either in the accounts or in cash you must be careful because if anything goes missing over a large amount for example $25 and up is red flagged so they keep their eye on you and if it happens more than once you will be disciplined. Any mistakes made can cost you dearly because in the banks eyes your dealing with their money and the bank doesn’t want anything to happen to their money.

pros: I really enjoyed working for the company, to a point.. I was sick and tired of being forced to sell products to customers, and it didn't matter about the people, just the sales. They tried to say that we were bettering the lives of customers, but it's not true! It was all about the bottom line and getting more sales.
cons: Well working for a boss who hadn't been with the company very long, wasn't good at her job and hardly knew what she was doing, translated to me not getting the best when it came to training. The bank failed an audit and shortly after my son got very sick. After I used a PAID/EARNED sick day, she decided to fire me and she LIED about her reasons. As much as it has eaten me up, I've decided I'm better off not being with the company and I don't want to fight it or work for someone who would lie to get rid of me.

review_title: Great place to launch your career
job_title: Foreclosure Specialist II in Westlake Village, Optional[CA]
pros:
Fairly predictable and job security is fair depending on the market and economy. They are very selective who they hire. 
Large company, deep wallet
Generally tolerable atmosphere for a corporate office
Lots of work
Generally an atmosphere of respect and commitment to excellence, at its best
cons:
High expectations but little incentive or reward other than fear of losing your job.
Timid, bland, and politically correct culture distracts from true professionalism
Management structure is backward and gets in the way of itself. Is anyone there interested in the values being promoted, or is it all just an empty facade to avoid further scrutiny?
Not for everyone. Conformity is their most cherished value and overrides everything else, whether loyalty, professionalism, honesty, or work ethic. None if that matters if you haven't cozied up to some upper manager. 
Also, don't expect to be treated like a responsible adult when you make an honest mistake, or God forbid use more than half of your allotted sick time. The best of wage slavery, but little room for growth unless you're inspired by office politics.
HR is probably run by spyware, analytic software meant to rate employees without their knowledge or consent, and very, very small minds.

pros: Holiday pay and no work
cons: Work environment is really bad

review_title: A very unhappy place to work
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Getzville, NY
pros: I would have to say the best reason to work there is the benefit package you get. You also have to option to purchase a week of vacation which was nice.
cons: Job growth in customer service was very poor and they were always changing polacies and made everything very scripted. They also have an occurance policy as far as sick days which I couldnt understand. They would not accept doctors notes that proved you were really sick. Also I was in customer service on phones and I got sick and lost my voice and they told me if i couldnt talk I couldnt do my job so they counted in against me. They wouldnt give me something else to do so I could stay at work. I almost was fired because of losing my voice. People were scared to miss work and came to work sick and then got everyone else sick it was horriable.

review_title: Bank of America is not a bank of opportunity.....
pros: The company has a great benefits package and compensation base structure.  The size of the company allows for company perks such as the discount program which is awesome.  If you get in the right cliche you can advance rapidly with little effort.
cons: The company is suffering from corporate inbreeding and poor management.  The opportunities internally are offered to the "in" crowd which often results in associates filling roles they are unprepared to fill.  Their incompetence filters down into a massive tangle of red tape as you try to secure approvals and obtain decisions.  The leadership  feels unprepared to make major decisions that may topple their "in" crowd advantage which often leaves a subordinate to go it alone.  If the decision is bad (due to lack of information or an inappropriate level forced to make a decision) you can bet the associate will be downsized next round.  Bank of America is very political and back-stabbers run deep through every level of the organization.

pros:
The "name". Everyone knows its a "big bank" and that makes people assume its a good place to work.
The benefits are good compared to most companies this size. Ofcourse, you must work one year to fully enjoy most of the additional benefits, but the basic starter benefit package is good and there are other little perks to enjoy.
cons:
Managers in the banking centers don't require much but a high school degree and while education level is overlooked adequate training is not administered. 
Feedback on performance is unhelpful since many managers are not competent enough to develop a strategy for employee career development.
Many people tend to get "stuck" doing the same job for much longer than they want to.
Many employees get lost in the "big bank" where they are unable to communicate effectively with leadership and vice versa.

job_title: Assistant Vice President Programming Consultant in Chicago, IL
pros: Good benefits, 401-l match and may allow additional time-off to be purchased.  Somewhat flexible hours/location so long as work gets done.  Comfortable office space with good co-workers.
cons: Does not promote from within, serious lack of communication/alignment between groups, damage from Countrywide purchase ongoing with staff reductions and those left working multiple roles.  Staffing got so bad that my group had to resort to shift rotations to cover all of the hours and weekend work went from every six weeks to every other week at one point.  The investment bank employs a suspiciously large number of H-1B's in technical roles despite there being several major universities in the immediate area.  If you're talented you won't be recognized or have anywhere to grow.  Very impersonal outside immediate group/LOB.  No contact from HR after notice was given, didn't receive a copy of final paycheck, appears they took money out for benefits despite dropping my coverage immediately.

review_title: Not enough incentives for employees and too much upper management bullying.
pros: Offers good health benefits and retirement. The employee discount program is great as well.
cons: work-life balance isn't great and neither is upper management. There isn't much room for personal growth, especially starting off as a teller. There are limited raises in pay.  You are lucky to get a raise once every five years. The management was horrible, because there was a lot of bullying, put downs and power trips. Some managers didn't practice what they preached.

review_title: Great company,  great benefits, constantly challenging.
job_title: Financial Center Manager in New York, NY
pros: The company prides itself in providing great benefits, sound financial products for internal and external clients,  and a secure and inclusive environment.   The company is ever changing with demands from clients and regulators alike.  It's a job that will keep you always learning, thinking, developing and honing your skills.  In addition to all this, development and ability to move within the company to different lines of business is a great way to retain talent within.  You could be a teller for 6 months and then decide you want to apply for an analyst position in a different sector.  I could go on and on about the pros, but I may run out of characters.
cons: An ever changing list of priorities and demands can be daunting for those who find change difficult.  There is a lot to learn and keep up with considering regulations that all associates need to know and follow.  Compliance can be nerve racking but if you follow the processes in place, all will be good.  The metrics of every position can be difficult to decipher and can be frustrating when your performance appraisals are being presented.

pros: Very good benefits and work-life was favorable, but varies from manager-to-manager.  Lots of opportunity to learn new things and if you are a very good performer then you will be recognized for it and compensated fairly.  I learned a lot that will help me excel in my future positions, both what to do, what not to do and how to treat others in order to get them to work harder.
cons: Some managers are very good and supportive of your career.  Others feel that demoralizing you and belittling you, even in front of others, makes them look better and is how you get people to work harder.  There is a lot of favoritism and cliques within the bank.  They encourage you to challenge status quo and think outside the box, but if what you are challenging is managements point of view then you are seen as not being a team player.

pros: Co Workers are very helpful
cons: Management does not help at all

pros: Good Company for because they provide good benefits to their full time employees. Another reason it is good is because they work around your school schedule and are understanding when it comes to taking time off for personal reasons. It is a very friendly environment to work in and the people who you work with are usually friendly and respect you. I also liked Bank of America because they have many rules to protect their employees and their privacy. Managers are good because they understand and defend their employees when customers erbally attack their employees. Bank of America is a good company to work for.
cons:
Limited Opportunities for Bonuses meaning that they hardly give out bonuses for their employees especially when it comes to their tellers. They give out great bonuses for Management; however, for their tellers and personal bankers the bonuses are not great which discourages the employees from reaching their potential at the company. Which leads to employees leaving the company for other banks and look elsewhere for better opportunities.
Pay Isn't Great compared to other banks and other comparable positions. They start the teller out around $8 bucks and hour and give raises every so often of about twenty-five cents which isn't much at all.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Financial Center Manager in Granada Hills, CA
pros: Benefits are phenomenal - including health, 401k , life insurance, paid vacation based on seniority , sick pay and stock options. Up to date with technology and competitive in the market with the products and services offered. Fast paced environment , reputable/ well known company. Job opportunities are endless.
cons: I wish the company invested more time and money training their employees . Not just new hires but all the associated in order for them to gain new knowledge and skills so they are better in their current role. Investing money in developing their associates & having a fair compensation structure would be two key areas to improve.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits and 401k, good coworkers, well known brand name.  Good commute. Can't think of anything else blah blah blah
cons: BOA is the new Wells Fargo in terms of high pressure sales.  Managers never commend employees but always criticize.  Goals are too high and unrealistic and pay is too low.  Expected to work  all saturdays so quality of life sucks.   Morale is low since tellers and bankers are expected to constantly sell  to repeat customers meanwhile they are expected to encourage clients to bank online so that they will  have even less customers to sell to!  Extreme micromanagement.  No job stability.  Will terminate employees  if unrealistic goals are not met for a few months.  Their probation period lasts 12 months so if you have a few bad months and get written up, you are expected to make goal for 12 consecutive months.

pros:
It’s a job. 
Ability to be pretty independent.
Great start if you want get into a career in finance
cons:
Turn over rate is high.
Not a lot of job security.
Your lively hood is dictated by random clients.
Clients can be very rude.
You are only scored on a few things so if in a day you are not opening new investment accounts or submitting referrals you might as well stayed  home that day.
90% sales.
The back office can make it feel like they don’t even want you to open accounts some times.

pros: Hours where in my perview
cons: Customers sucked and where annoying

review_title: How to get somewhere without knowing what you are doing.....
pros: Great benefits, large company with a very recognizable name.  I did learn a lot about the retail banking business, having come from an investment firm prior to joining Bank of America.  However, I was raised in a home with parents who had advanced degrees (MBA and Master's), and was taught to run a business much differently and efficiently than it is ran at Bank of America branch levels.  It is good to see that people get promoted based on how long they have been with the company, but do not give the job to somebody who is less qualified just because they have been there longer.  It is a business, and if you want it to run as efficiently as possible, you need to hire people with real management training.
cons: Very incompetent management, from branch managers to market and region managers.  They may have been managers in a different industry, but that doesn't mean they know how the commerical banking industry works.

review_title: The people you meet bring you a lot farther than the company.
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Miami, FL
pros:
- Between the customers and your fellow employees, you will meet some of the most AMAZing people in the entire world.  
- They provide health care to part-time employees.
- They offer a pretty decent 401k.
cons:
- No training.  Or if there is, it is very limited.  It is basically a hands-on learning environment.  
- The management do not feel as though doctors appointments are a necessity, even if someone was to have a bacterial infection.  The center I was at also seemed to frown upon the people that were pregnant and/or have other obligations in their lives.  Like their children.  Work is a lot, but is not everything.  If you want to receive, you must give.
- Very pushy with sales.  It also seems to be getting worse with time.
- The communication follows a military type of style.  From Senior Management down.  Although things may be communicated, they should be communicated in an easier tone so that by the time they get to the little people they aren't being stepped on and stabbed five times over.

review_title: Great benefits, stressful job, good pay
job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Greensboro, NC
pros: Competitive pay to other banks, great benefits (16 weeks maternity/paternity leave, childcare reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, etc), good bonus potential.  Working for a company that is recognized throughout the world, for better or for worse.
cons: Highly stressful job that continues to get more and more stressful, with the downsizing of staff.  Continual reduction in teller hours, increasing customer wait time and decreasing customer happiness, increasing the stress on individuals in the center.  Many positions are expected to be on a cash drawer, so they are reducing tellers and essentially paying bankers and managers to be on the teller line, while telling everyone that fewer tellers are ok.  Fairly easy to move up within the company, provided there is room.  Branch consolidations have reduced the number of open spots and created staffing jams as managers are relocated, so upward potential is stagnant currently.

review_title: Financial Center Operations Manager Leadership Development Program
pros: Plentiful opportunities to learn and grow in the banking industry. Always surrounded by great managers who only want you to learn and become a leader.  Various opportunities to attend networking events especially in larger cities as well as several opportunities to attend community service events.  In addition, three weeks of paid vacation!  This being a program that caters to recent graduates it definitely is a great way to start you career as a developing professional.
cons: The first couple weeks can be overwhelming but soon you become acclimated to the environment.  Like any corporate driven company you are expected to perform you can see this with other employees who may look stressed at the end of each month/quarter. This is a position where you work in retail so you will definitely have some clients who give you attitude.

pros:
- Pay is decent. 
- If you are willing to work full-time and have good sales skills with a focus on actually helping bank clients, you will receive promotions pretty quickly. 
- You acquire a lot of paid vacation time, and tend to have vacations every three months. 
- Teammates are often friendly, and like to have company events that enables the financial center's team to bond.
- If you are good at referring clients to bankers, you will be noticed by your boss's boss, and awarded.
- The bank is not open on Sunday.
cons:
- There are some angry customers that come through and take out their stress on you as a teller.
- You sometimes deal with abusive people who will say demeaning things to you if you speak with them too much. 
- Sometimes financial centers get really busy because everyone seems to want to make a withdraw at the same time; therefore, long lines occur.

pros: Large company with opportunities to do anything you want in Financial Services
cons:
1) Company has become a social experiment worrying more what color, nationality or sexual orientation someone is versus them being competent.
2) Company is too big - government is right it should be broken up - the left hand has no idea what the right hand is doing.
3) The senior management has become a bubble of incompetence - they keep hiring big money senior execs from consulting firms and laying off the low level employees who actually help customers and do work.
4)They have forgotten about their customers and employees both of which are the lifeblood of the company.
5) Operationally the place is a mess their data, systems, processes are a disaster - my last boss called BAC a dumpster fire - he was right.
6) BAC doesnt like people to know - but they are self insured - BCBS manages their plan but BAC is gunning to make a profit of employees health insurance.  The insurance is HORRIFIC - covers nothing high deductibles............

pros: BOA invest in their employees and they have a lot of opportunities. From career development to education, benefits and mentoring has to be by far the best experience I have had working for a company.
cons: I worked for the company over 10 years invested a lot into my in role development, went over and beyond the call of my work requirements and even did extremely well  in my role. When I decided to pursue other opportunities within the company and they did not go as planned very few people stepped up. There was a disconnect between my contract and the recruiters, therefore I was overlooked for positions that I qualified for. I really felt undervalued at the end of the day and I poured myself into this organization.

pros: Benefits package is very good: few places offer 401k AND a pension, so my hat's off to them on this point.  Telecommuting option is very helpful for those with a job that lends itself to remote work (it's practical for many back office positions, but of course,not possible for branch associates).
cons:
1) The bank 'officially' encourages associates to speak their minds without fear of negative sonsequences during its annual Associate Satisfaction survery.  However, don't fall for it.  I made the mistake of giving an honest opinion on what was supposed to be an anonymous survery.  Despite the fact that my criticism was done in a professional manner, it was traced back to me.  Nothing done on the internet is anonymous.
2) The bank is determined to ship every possible IT job to India.  Many of those that still remain in the US are being staffed by H1B workers who rotate between India and the US as their visas expire.

review_title: Company does not care about their associates OR their customers. Management just cares about themselves
pros: Benefits are the only good thing about this company
cons: There is no help for associates and now all the team lead positions have been eliminated!! Quality metrics are too harsh and quality reps just look for errors to give lower scores.. The customer is not the top priority... the top priority is to give associates low scores so they can go on corrective action and be fired...The associates with tenure, perfect attendance, and excellent at their jobs are severed so new hires can come in make a lot less money.. How is this even fair!!!  Terrible bank to work for and it will only get worse!!! Glad I am out of there and now hear from associates how stressed they all are and how unhappy they are as well

review_title: Great experience within banking center, bad market management
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in San Diego
pros: Great benefits, pleasant co-workers, good titles
cons: Overly sales driven.  Market management fails to address the fact that banking centers within different areas and regions have different clientele and therefore should have different sales directives.  Market tries to push one selling strategy on all banking center, whether it meets the needs/atmosphere of the banking center or not.  Then, when it doesn't work, they move on to the next selling strategy which is completely different and centers with a regular clientele end up confusing and frustrating their clients because bank expectations are constantly changing.  As a result, high pressure is added with no realistic directive to achieve company goals.  Banking centers are generally understaffed, so employees are overworked and underpaid, yet the necessary overtime to complete tasks is hard to get approved.

review_title: If you like a lot of change in a company....
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II
pros: Excellent benefits and pay. I was grandfathered in for pay, but if you're coming in new, the money is NOT worth the pain you endure each and EVERYDAY
cons: EVERYTHING. Entire line of business/site changes in the blink of an eye, hundreds of employees laid off at a time... they're all about work/life balance right? WRONG- schedule changes that don't work with ANYONE'S lifestyle, especially if you have a family. Gone from mortgage, which is not micro-managed, to a CALL CENTER where it's micro-managed for EVERYTHING you do (don't be a minute late to work, from break or lunch). And also be ware that customers are able to verbally abuse you until a manager is available (far and few between).

pros:
Cannot recollect anything on work front.
Year end outing and some leadership meets at expensive hotels.
Perks are Ok if not great.
cons:
No personal growth. 
Forget about being getting promoted even after working for 5+ years.
Work life balance is screwed up in few projects.
High level of uncertainity as bank is doing very bad on financial front.
Its hard to move across departments. No respect or decency when we apply for internal job postings.People interview as if they are hiring some outsider. No value for wahtever you do within the bank when applying for IJPs consider what would be the value outside.Mostly junk and production support work.
Incase you get an offer even though as permanenet employee treat it as a contract job.
Do not join BACI unless you have no other offer or you are comfortable searching for new job even after joining.
HR is non exisistent.

review_title: Circus Circus!!! Stay Away, Clowns on all levels!!! Former Core 1 FSA
pros: None, this place will have you question your overall existence on every aspect!!!
cons: I wish I would have seriously listened to all of the reviews before accepting this position, all of the reviews are true as to how horrible this place is. Many of the workers in the call centers are lazy, low self-esteem, poor health/eating habits and poorly groomed individuals that settle for over the phone interactions because they don't have the courage to conduct business as REAL ADVISORS do!!! This is fast-food style transactions, once again not advisory, the managers are jokes with no real people skills and many of them can't even hold an intelligent conversation with a 5yr old!!!

review_title: Claims Analyst II - Small Business/Corporate Credit Cards
job_title: Claims Analyst II in Buckeye, AZ
pros: Benefits: 401(k), sick days, vacation,
cons:
The bank doesn't proactively tell people their cards will be closing. They send a letter to the customers' address, when most people don't bother updating their information and it creates upset customer calls. The bank is going through a major transition and doesn't inform anyone of what is happening. There is a high number of people quitting the bank and they don't care. They will offer internal people low salaries, make it hard to meet goals to ensure you don't get payout, and make it hard to transfer or find another position within the company.

I would only recommend if you are looking at getting your foot in the door, looking for a decent part-time job, or something only for 1 year. I would not recommend for anything else.

There is a reason why their stock continuously drops. 

I worked overnights at the call center and I had a very hard time to flip my day upside down. That was the biggest drawback for me personally.

pros: Anyone complaining about this job has never done real work. What other job can you make 6 figures and work 40 hours a week? Anyone complaining about this role needs to go work in fastfood for a few weeks and then write a review. I have worked physical labor, I have worked 60 hour a week jobs, I have worked the worst of the worst for 25% of the pay. Those complaining are entitled babies who expect life to be handed to them on a platter. This is a job where You get to legitimately make a difference in peoples lives and make a nice living doing so. Yes, you have to know how to talk to people and just being a "hard worker" will not cut it, you have to have a high emtional intelligence and know how to relate to people, which is easier said than done, but for those that "get it" the job is cake. But anyone saying this job is tough, simply didn't know how to do it.
cons: You work in call center. You develop relationships you lose based on the nature of the business.

job_title: Client Specialist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: It used to be a great place to work but now the only thing that is good are the benefits.
cons:
High turn over rate, continually add more responsibility to the job without adjusting pay, constantly micromanaged and given contradictory information on policy & procedure.
Over the past few years it has changed from a fun and energetic place to work, to a place where employees are excited for the people who get fired.  The general consensus is that they are trying to get rid of all the long term employees by either firing them or making the working conditions so unbearable that they quit so they can hire new employees at a lower rate. They also don't allow employees to discuss their pay because they don't want people to know they pay women less than men.  I had a medical emergency at work and had to be taken to the hospital via ambulance. My manager was more concerned about the fact that I didn't have remaining sick time than the fact that I could have died.

review_title: Most BIASED company I have ever seen
pros: Good Immigration System , That's the only good thing about this company.
cons: I can't speak for the whole company but my team was one of the worst and most biased team and management I have ever seen. I was a part of Benefits Online team . They do not spend even a penny on their employees. Their bonus system is complete crap and you can't even buy a donut out of it. My Director(Manager's Manager) has used the "F word" to me several times. He has some favourites in the team who believed in boot licking and saying YES to everything he said to whom he used to prefer. My manager was one of them. My manager was not at all open to any suggestions and they just want someone who will say YES to whatever they say. My manager had his favourite employee too who used to lick his boots and boss over the rest of the team. If you are a person who likes a job with no progress , no fun and are someone who can YES to everything what your Manager says  and take all the crap and abuses then this is a good place for you.

pros:
Work was easy, hours were consistent 8:30 - 5:00.  When department was LaSalle Bank, it was better, but Bank of America came in and basically halted all employee friendly perks like tuition reimbursement, raises, bonuses, etc.  Became a bad place to work. 

Everyone was always worried about being laid off. Not a fun place to work.
cons:
Department was too slow to react to the problems facing the industry.  CMBS industry was bad but the departmenr refuses to acknowledge this. If they would have acknowledged it a little sooner and dealt with it, they could have made some changes that may have been helpful.

Also, manager promotions were entirely based on tenure and had nothing to do with management skills. There were 3 or 4 managers who had no ability to relate to their employees and thus, were not respected and caused more problems than there needed to be.

review_title: Great place to work for such a large company
pros: Great benefits, flexible work hours, ample opportunity for learning and the ability to move between departments after one year of service. Most peers are a joy to work with.  The current CEO seems to be making progress with improving the company but has his work cut out for him trying to repair the damage done by the former.  There seems to be a genuine effort to make the bank a better place to work despite the current economic environment.
cons: Executive management is detached and separate from the mid-level managers and employees.  They are mostly hired from the outside and typically last about 2 years.  As a result, we're subjected to constant re-orgs and useless departmental name changes.  Real organizational improvement is slow.  There are a lot of inefficiencies and bureaucracy due to the many mergers and increased government regulation.

pros: Benefits are great. Can't beat the amount of paid time off. The company is doing some very good things on the retail banking side to prepare for the future of banking. I think they will be ahead of the curve in 5 years.
cons: Extremely threatening culture. Miss your sales target one month, immediately go on performance management (coaching, verbal, written, final, term). Compliance defect regardless of the situation, immediately go on verbal or written warning. Very blanketed consequences without taking into account why something happened. Managing a center is very difficult because staff is being cut which makes it very difficult to delegate and effectively manage the business. If someone is falling behind on a certain metric, they are placed on an "outlier call" where nothing actually gets done. You just report numbers daily with the hope that intense micro managing forces you to figure out a way to improve that metric. The calls never discuss best practices or actual ways to improve the metric. This can be a very slippery slope (Wells Fargo)

review_title: Call Center Agent- what you expect!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Utica, NY
pros:
15$ a hour, 80 hours sick time, 80 hours vacation paid. 
401k, medical, vision, dental, legal etc. BOA honestly does have a lot of programs for their employees. They know we have a hard job and we are the ones that talk to the customer & make them money. Soo yeah they help us. Oh & you can make extra up ( up to 700$ ) for good performance! So yeah plus overtime! It’s make money! But can become overwhelming so balance is key!
cons: It’s customer service! That’s a hard job at any company. Customer can be rude, mean, demanding etc! It’s hard to locate help! Pay can be better for the way we are treated. But they honestly do try to help! So everything is okay. I would recommend.

pros: Bank of America is a great company with amazing benefits. I worked there over13 years. Childcare reimbursement, was my biggest gain.
cons: Unfortunately, managers have favorites and they usually seek  these for promotions even if they are not fit for the job making it extremely difficult for everyone they work for or with. Although career opportunities are there, you are left in the dust to people who don’t deserve the position at times due to friendship and not work ethics. 3 times I was promoted was not due to the immediate manager but due to the regional manager that noticed my work ethic and saw my potential when he visited my branch.   They focus too much on sales to the point where customers don’t come first.  Staffing can also be a big issue, it’s always short staffed and yet you are still expected to not only meet your goals but exceed them which can be stressful. Again, all about numbers and not great customer service

pros: Ive worked for many different companies and have learned to expect to meet a manager or two that are fantastic while the others are good but nothing to boast about. So far at Bank of America every manager I have had the chance to meet and talk with, at the branch and market level, have been outstanding. All the managers are motivated and believe in their teams and how they perform. They show genuine concern for their employees and their customers and always ensure that they do everything they can to make both happy. So far it is the best work environment I have ever worked in.
cons:
Although it is a great place to work it is hard to move up out of college. They don't have clearly identified positions for college graduates. The management is mor than willing to work with you for advancement but are just as lost as to where to go as a college grad or how to get there.

 Bank of America's "career development" site is extremely good and helpful but inaccessible to branch employees. You can only access the site from the Bank's computers but working at the branch doesn't allow you anytime to actually explore and use it.

review_title: I love the benefits, the time off, holidays, vacations.  It is a great place to work.
pros: Benefits, holidays, vacation, sick time.  It is better than most companies.
cons: Performance is huge.  If you don't perform, or if you are not good at customer service this is not for you.  Also, adherence will take a hit if you have to use the restroom.  Sticking to the times of breaks and lunches is important.  This is not a position that an active person should consider.  I found that out really fast.

job_title: Mortgage Processor in San Jose, CA
pros: Like most reviews I see. I really liked the people I worked with for the most part. When you are face to face with someone on a daily basis you learn to compromise, collaborate, and produce results.  I learned great information around mortgage and what it takes to get through that process and how the various components impact a home purchase.
cons: 1 year waiting period before able to have any matching to 401K.  Training and development is extremely frustrating.  Lots of time and energy spent on a rather disjointed and almost useless information. At least in the way it is facilitated.  Expectations unreal based on high pipeline with old tools and software.
