Tools and issues are a know issue yet nothing seems to be pressing to resolve the issue to assist in better productivity and client satisfaction.  Conflicting information between how the client is informed and how they are actually treated in regards to expectations and process.

review_title: Was a teller for a little over a year. Co Workers were the best. Branch Manager had no clue on how to run a Branch.
pros: Schedule was pretty good.  Co workers were very helpful and we pretty much had each others back no matter what.
cons: No incentive for tellers!  Understaffed! Branch was located in area were not many people would get approved for credit cards,loans, and other services. Management would make it stressful and didn't care how fast and accurately you would help costumers, they wanted sales. Of course its what most banks would want sales, but you cant properly sale products with a 20+ people line complain that we are slow. Shortly put, if you choose to cross sale costumers would curse you out and get inpatient. You decided to try to knock down this monster line that was steady all day and you would hear from management.

review_title: Working at BofA was a nightmare: it should be dismantled.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: It was a horrible experience that I will never have to face again -- that is the one positive!
cons: What was I thinking?  These people were unethical, paranoid, back stabbing, unintelligent, racist, and habitually did illegal or immoral things. Every day at work was stressful drama and intrigue as the bank was caught in one scandal after another. The office vibe was panic, chaos, and cya.  The ironic thing is, the so-called senior managers ( all poisonous hacks) all drank the cool aid and thought the place was stellar!  Here was a corporation destroying communities and lives, and all anyone could think of was whether they would get a bonus or not.  Despicable. Everything in the CRA reports is manipulated or fabicated and needs to be investigated. Redlining and hiring practices need to be investigated for law breaking. Harassment claims all over the place, in every department. If you meet anyone who works at this hell hole -- walk to the nearest exit and wash your hands: it is that slimy.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in San Jose, CA
pros: Large financial institution with access to marketing resources and training materials. Plenty of mentors and colleagues who are willing to help you find answers if you're willing to ask and show a genuine interest in succeeding. I understand that my experience was not the usual experience and that I was fortune to have an experienced and involved Manager/Mentor. Lots and lots of concept based training materials you can read through. Excellent pay if you're one of the lucky Loan Associates that starts off in a strong financial center.
cons: Low base pay (minimum wage), but at least you have a few months of non-recoverable draw (as an MLA) which I'm told is not the norm in this industry. Once you've passed the non-recoverable draw the base rate then counts against commissions to be paid. This means that if there is no business being written, you run the risk of going into deficit. In a sense you could end up working for free.

review_title: Dont work for this company - you are just a number!
pros: Benefits are good. And pay for some positions
cons:
no staffing
no ones cares, handle it on your own- if you are manager tellers whatever your role no one cares you have to figure out how to survive every single day. They keep cutting people's jobs left and right and the few people left in the branch take all the swearing and outraged clients. Can't blame clients because everyone would be upset if they see a line out the door every day and 1 teller and 1 banker in the bank. The manager gets all the yelling and screaming

review_title: Well-recognized company with a big name/ mission and not a big opportunity to get compensated for the job well done!
pros: Well known company name/ brand recognition, wide geographical presence allows to relocate without looking for a new company, good technology/ IT platforms, many different lines of business to work for, and a reasonable medical and dental coverage...
cons: The company is too big, and an employee is just a number that can be replaced for less expensive one; very conservative compensation ( salary base is on the low side compare to the industry competition, and ever-changing, cumbersome incentive plan ) - definitely not a place to make decent money!!! Not a very good place to balance work and life - in order to get results and a good performance review one needs to put aside their family, kids, loved ones and other interests...

review_title: Morale = low... physical buildings, facilities = good...
pros:
steady work, because people don't pay up to date on their credit cards...
buildings are clean and new...
flex schedule (40 hours/week)...
co-workers are good, hard working, regular folks...
approximately 10-15% of the managers haven't drank the Kool-aid. They are a pleasure to work with.
cons:
managers say one thing, do another...
every month your 'flex' schedule will be dictated to you in some way...'Thank you for your flexibility'...
management style - use fear in varying degrees in many instances, then use fear to discourage workers from speaking up... (fear of: loss of employment, being written up, being put on warning, etc., all while saying they want 360 feedback)

review_title: All in all this is a good company to work for.  If your a driven used car sales person stay in Retail banking other wise
pros: Benefit package, Paid time off, lots of advancement, paid education, lots of internal education,
cons: overworked.... demand lots of results in a depressed economy.  They  are still in the 90's where people came in to get checking accounts and personal loans and Heloc's.  We arent loaning $$ anymore and our economy needs it !!  Very difficult to get approved in a timley manner for a first purchase, must have stellar credit

review_title: I love working there, but you have to have time to move up within the business.
pros: great pay, you have to have 6 months experience before any promotions.  You do get paid vacations for 2 weeks. Also you get holidays off, and paid as well. It is a very precautions job, and you have to constantly be paying attention. It gives great rewards and discounts in some other places, and the managers are great with you.
cons: You have a very limited schedule, and don't chose your own. The only bad thing is that if you just started working there, you do not get treated like the rest. You get the last pick on vacations, and you have to wait at least 6 months to be able to apply to higher promotion, even if you have excellent referrals ,and results.

review_title: The worst employer do not use as bank also
pros: good insurance that's it. Nothing really good to say.  You'll be replaced as soon as they can get tax breck from hiring you.
cons: Run away as fast as you can.  I was not made to lie to people.   When unable to help a customer.  Was pretty well told by manager.  Tell them you'll call them back knowing I could NOT call them back. Customers mad and scream at you.  Sell sell sell but don't get credit for what you sell.Then tell you may have to let you go because your not meeting goals. Take complance test by them giving you answers so they look good.  People try to remedy a problem but you can not help them. managers make up  things just to get customer off phone. I cried with what they want you to do. Everyone is unhappy working there.  REALLY.  I cried because I am a good customer service rep but they would not let me be one..AT ALL.   Not a honest bank at all. pull your money out.

pros: The company has great employee networks and self training tools.  They have a great program call MyWork that allows employees (depending on the type of work you do) to work from home full time or partial.  Banking privileges are sweet too.
cons: The pay scales are kept secret.  You are not allowed to discuss salary or bonuses.  When you apply for a position you don't know the pay range.  Many times you end up being offered a position and without an increase because the your current salary is considered to be within 'range' of the position you applied for.  Lower level employees are not eligible for end of year bonuses.  They can only receive salary increases.

review_title: Marketing Jobs Offer Power and a Decent Payday
pros: Individually the people are all nice to work with abnd highly respectful. Nobody is looking over your shoulder and nobody cares when you come and go as long as you produce. You can actually work here and hardly ever physically come into the office. You get decent budgets to supervise and have descretion, it makes you feel powerful. Plenty of opportunity to prioritize the work as you see fit.
cons: You gotta like conference calls. If you like politically correct this is the place for you. Learning is done during lunch and learn's and you bring your own lunch...sometimes you get cookies. Title promotions usually mean more responsibility with no additional pay. Highly regulated, and although most of the workers are all honest and reputable, they wind-up paying the price for the few big execs who took the money and ran the componay stock to near zero.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Pennington, NJ
pros: Paid a base salary with full benefits to study for the series 7 & 66. Works class benefits . No cold callig the company provides you with existing client leads in the form of campaigns as well as customers calling in! You have a base salary and have the opportunity to say you are a financial advisor at one of the most prestigious firms in the world. If you have good phone skills you can be very successful here yoj get what you put into it. The job is easy yes you have to handle service issues for clients but it's an opportunity to convert service to sales .
cons: Compliance is pretty strict but it's in the best interest of our clients .  Also the metrics are a pain to keep track of which senior management is aware of and it seems like they are making strides to improve it. Some FSA's don't like cross selling products but I personally find it advantageous when we can offer our clients a broad range of financial services .

pros:
-Very flexible work schedule (no strict 9-5) 
- Branch partners are great source to drive sales traffic and respect you in your position long as you "educate," them in the small business banking world ..leads etc.
- Access to quarterly events to meet other key individuals within the bank network
cons:
- Management:  Very political. Will treat you like a "number," not a human.  
- Opinions:  don't count and will not listen
- clients:  Bank doesn't really care.. you can voice your opinions over and over, but management looks the other way. all about "numbers," 
- Advancement: good luck lol.  1 promotion in 5 years.  speaks "numbers,"  
- Structure:  none
- Goals : will double year after year since the bank is trying to squeeze maximum profitability out of each banker and avoid hiring more. If you don't meet your goals, all eyes on you and you'd be out quicker than you think.
- Favoritism: lots of it..  if your a great a** kisser.. this is where you want to be! Only the best a** kissers will stay a bit longer in their positions (even below goal threshold) 
- Asking for a raise?  Those are the forbidden words, try asking and see the response... even after 4 years.. they'll change the topic so quick before you can blink

review_title: It's not the worst job you could have
job_title: Financial Center Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
The hours are still pretty decent and paid holidays is another perk.
Health care I feel is reasonable considering the rising costs. 
Pay is good.
cons: Corporate, corporate, corporate.  I feel this place is run like the government in some ways.  There are so many layers; by the time you are at the field level you realize the people making the decisions are so far from being connected it's not even funny!  Like most big companies you talk about what the customer wants and then it's sell sell sell.  The staffing levels are a joke, customers and employees know it,  just not the employees who make the real decisions.  My work load goes up,  lose employees and we add to what we were responsible for.

job_title: Senior Fraud Claims Analyst in Newark, DE
pros: Name recognition, Vacation, PTO, health benefits, confident pay is on time.
cons: Under pay versus competitor banks. You don't need experience and education for a management or officer, or AVP or VP role you only need to be friends with your boss and they should be friends with their boss. They don't listen to their employees, and the Band system is seriously in need of replacement. There is no true path to success at this company.

review_title: Great job for personal/professional growth, but hard sales goals.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Plano, TX
pros:
-Branch managers and assistant managers are great at every location I've worked or helped at. They are understanding.
-They company is great to work for as a whole. Bank of America even provided $1000 bonus to employees that have make less than $100,000.
-Starting pay for Customer Service Representatives/Tellers here pay more than other commercial banks. $15/hr starting pay.
-There is definitely room to move up, if you are focused on your numbers. Many different routes you can take to move up, but you need to be motivated.
cons:
-Sometimes you may have to work 6 days a week
-Sales goals are sometimes hard to meet
-If you do not meet your goals, you can get a verbal warning and then a write up
-Stressful at times especially with overbearing customers that feel that they deserve extra special treatment over others. Will have customers yell at you for things out of your control, but you will get used to it.

pros: Bank of America has excellent vacation and time-away policies.  Including holidays and sick time, new employees have a total of 5 weeks off, plus the ability to purchase an additional week.  My managers have always been very lenient with the work-from-home policies.   They offer a good benefits package with healthcare including dental, medical, and vision, plus both a 401(k) and a pension.   Annual performance reviews match annual bonusses, as well as company-wide bonuses if the stock and/or net profit is sufficiently high.  The management team generally lets you do your job without interference.   The first level managers are all former developers, and so understand what difficulties might be had without needing detailed explanations.
cons: Developers are on-call 24/7.  The pager can be the bane of ones' existence, especially during peak processing times.   There is a lot of red tape to get software migrations to production, which is both depressing and productivity-reducing.   There is a lot of mindless and pointless training required by the government because they're a bank, even if you have nothing to do with banking customers.

review_title: Just another brick in the wall.
job_title: Non Trading Analyst (IT Support) in Chandler, AZ
pros: My team and others I work with in IT Support have alot of hardworking and talented people. Good pay and great benefits. Managers are good and care about your work/life and career aspirations. Work is fulfilling and I get good sense that I really help and are appreciated by the people that are out there bringing in the revenue that funds my paycheck. But the off-shoring to India has done away with alot of US based support and our work load has dropped and my former customers dread calling India for IT support. Over all a decent place to work.
cons: Too much support has been pushed to India. My former customers are very disappointed in the service they get from India. There is no philosophy of hiring from within and no mentoring to bring people up to a higher level support team. If you do not meet ALL of the qualifications listed in the internal job postings and/or KNOW someone, good luck on that career advancement. They hire too many outside contractors and this erodes the corporate culture. If you want a strong IT org. and foster corporate culture and memory, hire from within!!!

review_title: Good place to learn, but like many big companies everything depends on who your boss is
pros:
Great paternity package granting significant time off to fathers
Tuition reimbursemnt paid for my undergraduate degree
Lots of training is provided, but mostly web based
I have learned a lot from many great bosses I had over a 13 year career
cons:
I have had some terrible bosses who expect quick results whether they are sustainable or not
Much of the leadership team for the Sacramento area are incompetent and blame those below them for shortcomings caused by their lack of communication.
Office politcs make for poor performance evaluation, how can a regional manager give a store manager a did not meet performance when all the goals were acheived and the regional manager meets with you once every 2 months.

review_title: pro and con a general review
job_title: Client Service Associate in Hopewell, NJ
pros: Huge Company with opportunity in many different lines of business. Terrific benefits, an appreciation for work life balance. Aware of its presence as a huge US and Global employer and is a responsible corporate citizen as CSR accolades indicate. A business focusing on in its 'core competencies' building a stronger balance sheet and improving internal processes and integration of resources. The industry has been hard hit but BAC ML is taking a strong positive direction despite headwinds of the global economy. The footprint of BAC ML is appealing because there are offices and branches all over, not limiting the area which you make a home.
cons: I am too new of an employee to start picking apart the cons. In this environment where it's not a given for many that they will be employed I think the bank does a great job of offering an attractive overall compensation and benefits package as well as a comfortable culture. One drawback is the base pay is below what I have seen at competitors but the last I compared similar roles was in 2007 pre financial crisis.

review_title: Enlightening as to what banking is all about....
pros: The FT benefits are great, many to choose from.
cons: Unethical practices to say the least

review_title: Get to meet a lot of new people but they require too much for paying so little.
pros: They have a lot of great benefits. As a student working part time they reimburse you for going to school. While the reimbursement process is a huge hassle, you can get a lot of your tuition bills paid off. I collected over $7000 in tuition reimbursement. I was very satisfied. You also get to meet a lot of different people. I still keep in touch with some associates with the bank and it has helped me secure other opportunities.
cons: A lot of micro managing. Management keeps asking the lower end of the retail stores to do more than what should be required. For example, they are totally trying to get rid of their bankers so they are forcing the tellers to learn how to open accounts, close accounts, create wire transfers, etc. That simply is not a teller's job. They are also trying to eliminate tellers. As a teller I was required to tell the customers about our ATM's which can do deposits, withdrawals, etc. So basically I was getting paid to tell customers not to use tellers for their transactions but to use the ATM.

review_title: I didn't feel good about myself working there...
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: BOA is a huge company and there are certainly many terrific people working there.  Most of the people I worked with were as smart and pleasant and professional as anywhere else.
cons:
I don't feel that leadership cares about its customers.  There was a sense that they had plenty of money to pay off lawsuits, so who cares what they did.  While I was there, they had serious discussions about creating a new charge for all banking customers - to cover penalties they faced for their actions during the mortgage crisis - but cancelled when it became a PR debacle.  Coincidentally, a family member applied for a mortgage while I worked there - not my department, I wasn't involved - and they strung them along, got them to pay a $500 application fee, kept them waiting for 6-8 months, and then turned them down.

It's an extremely political environment.  If you're ever faced with the dilemma of doing the right thing or choosing a side, just be sure you choose the right side.  Doing the right thing won't be an issue.

review_title: Fantastic benefits if you can stand the work environment.
pros: Great health insurance, good salaries, and more vacation, sick, and personal time than any other company that I (or any of my friends) have worked for. If you want to volunteer, there are coordinated activities. if you want to learn, there is tuition reimbursement as well as a variety of computer based learning courses available. There are also advancement opportunities if you're willing to take the extra step.
cons: This is contradictory to the "official" values, but upper management appears to be deaf to the needs of the people on the ground floor, and it seems like each team is trying so hard to shine that they're unwilling to work together. "Too many cooks in the kitchen" sums up every project, large and small, and the results of each project and meeting is a change to the current base of knowledge for the department. This leads to a fluid structure and it's hard to tell day-to-day what information is still accurate.

review_title: Needs to better implement strategic changes.
job_title: Personal Banker in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Good benefit package including Health Insurance, Child Care Reimbursement and Tuition Reimbursement programs.
cons: Bank of America is trying to take a leading roll into changing the way people bank from a traditional banking environment to a self service technology driven experience. This goal has cause BOA to bite off more than they can chew as they have not executed an effective implementation strategy rather they are trying to railroad their customers into adoption by depleting the banking centers of tellers. This in turn creates a very high tension and adversarial environment between the employees and the clients creating a poor customer service experience for the client and limited sales opportunities for bankers. Everything is a fire drill and mid and upper management has been slow to react in taking a corrective action. If BOA doesn't figure out the direction they want to go they will bleed customers and talent.

review_title: It all depends on where you're at.
job_title: Manager, Property Preservation Escalations, Officer in Simi Valley, CA
pros: If you are in a division that is considered necessary, you have no worries at all about job security.  The benefits are great.   And like most large corporations, there is usually ample room for growth.
cons: If you end up in a division that is potentially going to be cut, you will work under the umbrella of layoffs the entire time.    People that are valuable to the company are not moved so good talent is retained.  Pay raises are small, often not keeping up with cost of living increases.  Title promotions are handed out like candy, diluting management and creating weaker teams as talent leaves.   Pay from unit to unit can be vastly different.   One group may get modest checks each payday, and a yearly bonus, but another may get 4 figure bonuses each month, along with 5 figure bonuses at the end of the year, which can create tension when someone moves from one group to another.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Generally speaking It is a stable job, and with benefit as health insurance and 401k match up to five per cent
cons:
Needs a lot of time to be spent for this job, life/ work time can't be balanced. On the job description it only says Saturday could be asked to work, actually it would require you to work almost every Saturday, so it is kind hard to have regular weekends  direct sales manager will constantly give relationship managers( previously called personal banker)  pressure on sales. Micro training on you through the branch manager as well. not only do your  sales jobs but also help the csr to reduce their traffic for daily routine
A lot of conference call and meeting required, so far this job is asking employees do more and more work, but the hour pay is not changing at all

pros: The bond created with the coworkers in your branch.  When left understaffed day after day it truly takes ‘one team’ to get through each day.
cons:
- micromanagement at its finest 
- manage through emails 
- ridiculous outbound strategy that leads to close to zero appointments
- ‘improve financial lives through the power of every connection’ ... if there is a sale to be made, otherwise call customer service or set an appointment for an inconvenient time so they don’t come back or go to another center
- Market leaders are relentless even if you are a top performer, every day, every hour, they want recaps, nothing is ever good enough
- Nothing better than getting feedback from a Market Leader who has never observed you work
- two, hour long sales calls every week with constant rhetorical questions and number shaming individuals or financial centers  
- understaffed close to 100% of the time
- work 6 days a week, every single week

job_title: Relationship Banker in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Co-workers (not management or market leader) and benefits. 5 pm when we get off!
cons:
Pressure to sell the moment a customer walks in, forced to analyze their accounts and finances so you could sell them products, corrupt practices in order to get an incentive, incentives for referrals caused employees to manipulate customers, customers angry at BOA and come to bank and let you have it, very high stress makes it impossible to perform at your best, I saw management lie to customers, was told I would work 2 Saturdays a month - its every Saturday. I was also told incentives were easy - they are not. From the beginning they woe you with how great BOA is. They do that because the turnover is so high. The Academy training is awful!!! It's all online and some doesn't even apply. Straight computer training for 6 weeks - information is thrown at you. This is not learning!
Please beware and do your homework. I will never bank here and I will tell everyone I know how corrupt and UGLY this bank is. This bank will take advantage of you every step of the way he the name of money. Culture doesn't exist here - it's a grind with low morale and regard for the company.

review_title: A good bank to work for, if you want to work for a bank.
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: There are some great people that work at BofA.  The corporate vision is clearly stated and there is very little ambiguity as to each employee fits into their role.  They have a very strong benefits package and the starting wage is decent.  BofA also like to promote from within and spend a lot of time developing associates, so someone with a desire to pursue a career in banking and a clear idea what they want can advance very quickly through the hierarchy.
cons: This is a massive corporation and it can often feel that way.  There is a lot of talk of  "360* coaching," but it is clear that the directions come from the top and flow downward.  The business focus regularly cycles back and forth from being focused on customer service to serving the bottom line.  The working environment can vary greatly from branch to branch and can depend upon who is in charge.

review_title: Great pay and benefits, low stability
pros:
-Excellent pay
-Reasonable workloads (I don't work more than 45 hours a week, on average ... though this might vary from manager to manager)
-Lots of vacation time
-Lots of holidays
cons:
-Very little stability.  It's common for the department to reorganize every 12-18 months.  You're likely to have a new manager/team/role soon after you start.
-Low long term stability.  Banking - as an industry - is really struggling, and I'm not certain it will improve.
-Low focus on customers.  It's not about designing great products and providing best in class service.  Most employees just talk about "how can I get this group of people to open more accounts?"

review_title: Some Management just doesn't care (Merrill Edge)
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Lincoln, RI
pros: Customer service area as a whole are very nice people.  Enjoyed working with clients.  Compensation was on the high end for new employees.
cons: Poor Management ,  for a customer service area management did not care about the customer.

review_title: Technology and customer service needs improvement
job_title: Personal Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Paid holidays including Columbus Day was honored by this bank. Also, the weekend hours are better than others...Saturdays they close at 2pm. However, this didn't help improve the overall customer satisfaction for the company itself. I really liked the Recognition Rewards Program that they implemented. It's nice to know that recognition could be in a form of points that could be used towards an online shopping mall exclusively for Bank of America employees.
cons: There are huge areas of improvement in being organized as a company. The bank itself typically would not have a unanimous answer for certain inquiries made by clients specially after the 2007-2008 housing market crash. I also wished that dress code was strictly implemented. Not necessarily having employees wear uniforms but a straightforward manual regarding what's professional and what is not.

review_title: Great Conpany , Great Hr/ Pay & Commision Plus Benefits . Tough Sales
pros: High Energy Atmosphere , Great Hr/ Pay , Competitve Place , Consty Having Contest To Win Prizes Like Lunch On the Boss ect. Very laid back call center , great career opportunities within the company . Will help with coaching if needed on sales . There always willing to help .
cons: Selling Balance Transfers & Direct Depsoit to credit card users , customers are transferred to you because the bank seen a opportunity & the sales part comes to place . Strict 30 min lunch 2 15 min breaks depending on shift . Hard core sales . Once in position can't leave current hours as you must work with the company for a year to move around unless you will have to quit & re-apply .

review_title: Great benefits and salary but very difficult to meet quotas
pros: Very generous pay and bonuses. As a mortgage underwriter I worked long hours but was paid for the OT. I received raises yearly, and bonuses at the end of the year and for other reasons.
cons:
The industry has become extremely difficult due to government regulations which  make it too time consuming to cover all the bases multiple times on every loan. The company has to go way overboard in every area to avoid being sued or fined by the government as "examples". . This translates to checklists for checklists for checklists which is extremely unproductive and actually counterproductive.

The company requires way too much training in areas that are not relevant to the position they hold. This slows production and prevents quotas being met.  Train in areas that are relevant to the position and/or the person's particular areas of need.

pros:
Many opportunities to grow within the company with several different paths based on your skill set, experience and desires.
Pays pretty good for top performers.
cons:
Lack of proper training with extremely unrealistic expectations for all associates. 
Associates are unable to have sufficient amount of time to train and enhance their skills.
Success is only possible when you sacrifice your personal life and self completely for the bank.

review_title: It all depends on location and management
pros:
Paid training 
Knowledge of retail banking 
Ability to earn bonuses 
Great coworkers.
cons:
Pay is far below industry and they try to make up for it in benefits that are still not that great 

Training is subpar. They hire people who've never been in retail banking and 80% of the training is computer based. Almost zero sales training. Once you get out on the floor you feel you know nothing and will make mistakes. Entire training class had similar issues . 

If your manager and branch manager want you to succeed, you will. If not, good luck. 

All in all, if you've never been in retail banking it's an okay place to start , but the lack of communication, organization,  staffing and penny pinching that this bank does in my opinion make it almost impossible to stay.

review_title: Great place, people and research/information.  Look closely to make sure you fit the culture and you will love it.
job_title: Financial Advisor PMD in South Bend, IN
pros:
The Culture - Excellence, Thorough, Affluent Centered, Do it all
The People - Very smart, respectful, helpful...they are still my friends
Benefits - Good and comprehensive, large installations have lots of on site perks
Compensation - Great starting pay with vacation time earned early, lots of bonus opportunities
cons:
Technology - So big that they just cannot keep up much less get ahead

job_title: Consumer Card Collector I in Kennesaw, GA

cons: The call center line of business is limiting within itself, which is to be expected, but it makes a bit worse when your'e on the phone listening to people that are either depressed or infuriated by either their situation or something we've done. The programs we have for our customers are very limited, which makes it hard to care about the customer's situation - mostly because you already know the conversation is going to end up in them having a nasty attitude or hanging up. I honestly consider myself to have quite a thick skin and dont find myself emotionally ruffled by each person i speak to throughout the day, but i can say that the job definetly will take a toll on the wrong person. I think the best collectors are the ones that are extremely emotionally detached from their jobs and who have no problem delivering a very difficult message and then feeling like nothing even happened.

pros: Paid vacation, paid sick leave, you buy up to 5 extra vacation days, benefits start on day one. Start pay 15.00 hr, later shift 16.20 hr.

If you are fulltime don't get the late shift from 4:30pm to 1:00 pm because you will not be getting your 40 hours. work from 3:00 pm to 11:30 pm. or earlier if you can so you can get your full 40 hours.

review_title: 25 years experience in Credit Card Collections and Default Mortgage
pros: Good benefits, some managers adhere to core values and try to make it a good place to work.  Large company so there are opportunities for advancement, but you need to seek them out. Continually challenged to do more with less, which means they have to cut personnel to hit target numbers but no plans on where the work will go or how it gets done.  Executives brought in from the outside to make deep cuts and typically adversarial approach.  Lack of clear compensation structure and decisions for bonus made on judgement of manager as well as funding cuts from executive team on bonus pool.   Hi pressure to not take time off, work through vacations, etc.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good exposure to senior leadership and plenty of opportunities to make job connections during your rotations.  Strong bonus, compensation and benefits upon accepting the position. cons: You're brought in at a salary that will not allow for any negotiation upon graduation from the program.  Many hiring managers will try to appease you with a title change to keep you happy. You're on your own to find full-time placement once you graduate the program, limited support from the program to find a good fit. Feedback is not incorporated into making the program better, cost pressure on the organization is reducing size of program YOY.

review_title: A place with opportunity for hard worker
pros:

I have heard from other teammates that they are passed on a promotion with someone who does not qualify enough. 
The benefit is pretty good, with 401K matching up to 5% after 1 year...and 4% pension contribution (before it was 2% for me, then 3%...now anyone who starts will automatically get 4% matching)...health benefit and dental with health savings account of $600/year (which will be discontinued in 2011)...helped me saved a lot of money when I had to go to the emergency room!
cons: there's a lot of changes with the bank and a lot of time the changes does not get down to the other lower level of associates...compensation could be better, seems like a lot of incentive has been cut or lowered...does not have the newer technology compared to other states or even other banks down the road

review_title: Great experience until I worked in the banking centers, than you are worth less than dog food.

pros: The benefits are great. Options to further your education in any category without restrictions.
cons: Unethical behavior. Mistreatment of associates. You are expendable. Not paid for the 70 to 80 hour work weeks. Not paid or recognized for success.

review_title: MRT is not what I expected
pros: Decent benefits that include tuition reimbursement, retirement benefits, and generous vacation time.  Some lines-of-business offer flex time and work-from-home options. Most of my colleagues are great to work with and the Bank offers comprehensive on-the-job training for new associates.  There is room for advancement and I have witnessed several instances of rapid promotion within my group.
cons: Be aware that not all sites offer all the same perks.  Pittsburgh MRT associates cannot work from home and have no flex time available to them.  The job is report-driven and the expectations of what we do change frequently. It can be very frustrating to work in an environment where the rules change constantly - oftentimes without fully understanding the ramifications of the changes on our daily lives. Many associates are frustrated with the lack of autonomy and flex-time. MRT is comprised of a group of highly educated legal professionals and should be afforded the level of professionalism and flexibility that we were promised when we were hired.

job_title: Director de Operaciones y RR. HH. in Boise, ID
pros: I started out as a Teller and I was able to move up to a Sales & Service Specialist. I loved the people that I worked with and the customers. The company offers great benefits and products. cons: There were times when I felt like I was being pushed to sale products that were not a good fit for our customers. There is some downsizing in the company. review_title: Worked for Merrill Edge, not terrible but not good
pros: Huge company with a large amount of job choices.  The company is involved in almost every aspect of the financial industry.  Merrill Edge had decent bonuses for their most basic financial reps compared to their competitors. Great place to start a career in financial industry, and great place to be if you can get to the executive level.
cons:
Their lack of specialization causes many of the processes to be poor unless you get a job high enough that you don't get directly effected by inefficiency, the jobs typically are extremely frustrating. 

Internally at edge specialty team moves didn't include a raise.

 Also the timekeeping was annoying, they didn't actually cheat employee's but you actually have to physically work 40 "non Holiday" hours to then be eligible for overtime.

review_title: The single hardest but most rewarding job I've ever had.
pros: Unlimited earnings potential. Long hours but flexible schedule.Best technology, financial planning tools, research and analysis on the street. Widespread company recognition. Sense of personal achievement. Exciting. Your job is to find, close, and simply be around money. Nice business cards. Sweet logo.
cons: Very little useful sales training or training in general. Computer. Phone. Figure it out. Sink or swim. Constant competition. No one wants you to succeed. Like in prison join a gang (team) to survive. They say 1 in 10 make it but after two years here it looks like less. Hurdles are outrageous. Learning curve is steep. Everyday you need to be on your game, even in the office. Time flys by. Don't get stuck being a cold caller because then your just a free intern for your group until they cut you. Enjoy the rush.

pros: Not many that I can think of
cons: Cons – Unless you come from a wealthy family or have an existing large net work of wealthy prospects you will fail the program. You will be expected to cold call all day in an age where cold calling is passé . The program is designed for failure, very few PMDs graduate. Production goals increase dramatically after about a year and quarterly thereafter and are nearly impossible to meet. The company hopes that any clients you bring in with assets will be retained and divvied out to veteran advisors after you are fired for not meeting production goals. Micro management to the extreme is the norm. Been in the program for over two years and only one PMD has graduated. Seen many come and go. After graduation if you have clients with less than $250,000 assets you will not get paid on their accounts. You can be fired at any time with little or no notice. You may have to sign a form stating that if you are with cause or quite before two years are up after receiving your production number you will have to repay training costs which are considerable. Stress levels are extreme. No work life balance. You are expected to work long hours with no overtime pay or additional compensation.

pros: In the various technology roles I've held, I've had the opportunity to work with some talented people who work hard and are dedicated to doing the right thing.  This is in contrast to a lot of the negative publicity the company keeps receiving because of poor decisions made and directions the company has gone in the past.  Benefits are in line with the rest of the industry, and I've always found my management to be flexible with work location when I've needed it.
cons: There's recently been a lot of swirl in many of the departments as part of the company's plan to simplify its business model, to the point where employees now equate the simplification process with layoffs.  This has created a lot of fear and despondency since you don't know if/when your group or entire department might get arbitrarily cut down by half.  The mentor program and performance review processes are really lacking.

review_title: Eh- a great company over all but a lot of micro managing in the contact centers.

You're told to do a job and have rules but, although you're dealing with fraud, your bonus depends on that angry customer who maybe upset about their account being in shambles and not your service to them directly. They didn't give anyone any warning or more training. We were telling customers about their credit cards that we weren't even properly trained on. And then when we would ask management, they would get mad at us like we were not entitled to ask anything abut the job we were hired for! New management took over and it went down hill. They no longer cared about their employees and treated us like numbers. It was like a sweat shop there. Horrible management. I quit because of stress and headaches. My happiness is too important for this sweatshop.

pros: Good salary and benefits. I guess you could say that there is a lot of opportunities to grow within the company, but that’s only if you get brainwashed into believing that the company really cares about helping people.
cons: Bonus structure has a lot of flaws, if you don’t hit 100% of your goal. you don’t get a payout. Recruiters lie to you and tell you its a 3K to 6k per quarter payout, but in reality, that’s not accurate, they somehow want employees with integrity, yet their recruiters don’t. Relationship managers are treated like they are children, they actually just get told by everyone in the financial center to do things, even tellers. Managers are so insecure because they don’t really know how to do the job and they tend on throwing others under the bus to protect their necks, it’s a pretty pathetic atmosphere.

review_title: It all depends on your manager
pros: Train you to get your licenses, working in a branch gives you access to leads, if you have a good relationship with your branch everyone can kill it. Average to above average benefits. The amount of time for maternity and paternity leave is unheard of. If you have a good manager, it can be a great place to start a financial career. Working as an FSA should not be a long term career goal though.
cons: Some managers can be good, but the majority only view you as a number. If you have a bad manager, they will micromanage and be a slave driver. If you hit 80% to goal they threaten you. If you hit 100% to goal, they say the expectation is 150% to goal. If you hit 200% to goal, they don't acknowledge it. Some managers can also test your ethics asking you to do shady stuff. If you tell them no, they will tell you that you wont hit your numbers.

review_title: Management needs leadership education and rating reviews.
pros: Large company, has good benefits, and decent work hours. It makes it a good place to work if you have a family and would like to be home at a decent time of day. Also, work stays at work, there isn't take home responsibilities, leaving your time at home free for your family.
cons: Some managers don't have people skills, leadership abilities. They run things by intimidation. I have seen managers screaming at employees over trivial things, because they do not know how to lead positively, so they make people fearful for losing their jobs. In this economy, employees will not speak up against bullying in the workplace.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to be rewarded for success.
pros: Bank of America gives you the opportunity to truly step up and excel.  There are a lot of very smart people there and they reward success.  The work / life balance is generally very good, but it depends on your manager.  The benefits are very good with paternity leave as good as maternity leave.  The processs and procedures are in place and everything can be found on the intranet.  Reviews and talent planning are formal and happen regularly.
cons: It's a tough environment that doesn't reward people just for showing up and getting their work done.  There are no cost of living raises, only raises for performance.  In management, there is a lot of movement and when a new leader moves in, you may be put on an "internal job search" because they have eliminated your job or given it to someone else.

pros: My team was really friendly, hardworking, caring and would go out of their way for other team members. No working after 7(at the latest), holidays or Sundays! Discount using Working Advantage (I had 20% off on my phone bill). You get to create relationships with regular customers and help everyone. Company works with schedule changes/ limited schedules. Great associate banking program and benefits.
cons: Very big emphasis on making numbers but horrible training program, if they expect you to sell shouldn't they at least teach you how? High stress environment, passed down from managers, makes even the most calm and collected employee annoyed. Managers pick favorites, hard to move up even if you are a hard worker. Strict regulations - constant need of manager approval. Working with a lot of people who don't necessarily want to be there or make banking a career, no serious career vibe. VERY inconsistent policies (as far as coin deposits or who can do what) from bank to bank. My branch really babied the tellers and gave us very limited freedom/responsibility.

review_title: This employers claim of embracing diversity is a complete Sham
job_title: Senior Operations Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Some extremely smart people. Good work culture in some divisions.
cons:
I have had some very good managers in this company but I hate to say that there are many elements in management in this company that are  involved in & set an example of cheap politics, complete lack of transparency and above all completely insensitive of peoples ethnic backgrounds.

Expectation of loyalty from employees, by the management should accompany a behavior that exemplifies the promotion of diversity, good language, purposeful use of tools provided by HR for professional development,  none of which was I a witness to in bank of america.

Jokes pertaining to ethnic backgrounds are common and senior management thinks its cool. Very sad experience.  Malicious use of language is common as well. This is particularly common in IVM.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in Fort Worth, TX
pros: 3 weeks paid time off and the ability to purchase extra time off. The benefits were really good.
cons: The bank expects their employees to take the fall for their poor image. The expect you to meet their customer satisfaction goals, but you are weighted on the question in the survey Are you overall satisfied with the bank, so if you provided excellent customer service but the customer just hates B of A overall and marked a 4 you would receive 0 for that survey and can potentially be fired. It is very stressfull enviroment and heavily micro managed. If you are looking for a company to grow with, this is not the company. Unless you are a manager's pet. The managers dodge escalation calls or pushback by telling you to tell them a manager is not available and tell them this and then tell me what happens. If you care about your mental health this is not the job for you. At one point almost half of my department was out on stress leave.

review_title: One of the best experiences I have ever had, and I would mostly attribute it to my department manager and his higher ups
pros: Random perks the company has with an online points system, depending on your boss you will have freedom to be the best employee possible but still feel welcome to ask as many questions as necessary. Also, there was a true sense of having a team - we had pot lucks, staff meetings, and training courses that truly brought everyone together
cons: If a manager does not know the task their associates are doing, they tend not to learn it (there is a sense of "I'm a manager I don't need to learn that"). Managers should be more humble and willing to learn/teach, like the Department Manager was.

pros: Many job categories at Bank of America which allows employees to learn new skills. Mortgage loans, retail management, investments, trusts, etc. Vacation, sick time and holidays seem to be above industry standards. Big company that is recognizable. Pay seems to be in line with industry standards.
cons: With all the mergers and acquisitions there is discontent of employees from each company (Fleet Boston, Merrill Lynch, Countrywide and so on) Management has "good old boys" mentality. The company changes business models often which lead to more layoffs. Not sure if they have clear direction with a plan in place. Layoffs are done without looking at performance. Seems to be random but it is more up to manager's discretion. Years of service and loyalty is not considered when laying off employees.  Unfair treatment of some employees while others are protected. Some work environments can be hostile depending on if you are working with employees from a different legacy background. (Bank of America, Fleet Boston, Merrill Lynch, Countrywide)

job_title: Business Control Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: BofA has great employee benefits and great opportunities for advancement. There are many volunteer opportunities and employee groups to be a part of.
cons: Unless you have an amazing Manager, you'll have to do your own leg work to find a path for advancement. The resources are there however no one directs to toward an advancement path. You must determine where you want to be and then do the research and leg work to get there. You'll have to create your own and stay on top of learning, training, and asking for opportunities to do the work in the position you hope to move up to. The opportunity for advanced work (above your position) is not always given or even considered.

review_title: If you don't mind being an underpaid, unknown, tiny cog in a giant machine, work for Bank of America.
job_title: Vice President in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: There are no glass ceilings for women.  Women hold very high offices in the company.  BofA is very supportive of work/life balance and promotes opportunities to work from home and work flexible schedules.  (This is not true in the local branch offices where customer service during "store hours" has to be supported)
cons:
TOO big.  Employees are truly only numbers.  All personnel functions are outsourced so if you have a personal issue that you need to address with the Personnel Dept (such as sick leave, or retirement planning) you cannot talk to a Bank of America employee.  You end up talking to an insensitive outsider.  Very frustrating, but it's one of the byproducts of growing too big.  
Also, all advancement opportunities are in Charlotte now.  To get noticed by the topmost levels of management, you have to live in Charlotte.

review_title: Frustrated by being seen as numbers only, not as a person.
pros: The best reasons to work for BOA are the benefits. They offer full benefits to all 20 hour employees. Vacation and Sick time is part of that too. The benefit pkg, is the reason why I stay. The hours are good too for my family.
cons: As with any large co. They are ultimately concerned with the bottom line. Therefore, being that we are now in the 4th quarter, they are realizing that they are over budget is some areas. So where do they cut? In the employee's hours! They cut 4 peoples hours in our center, myself included, and I can't afford it! The workload is still the same, but we are expected to do it with fewer hours, and people. The real kicker is, we have to increase "customer delight." Make your employees happy and the rest will follow.

pros: I have worked with some of the best people in the consumer banking industry and have also learned a lot from them.  I started out as a teller, but was soon given responsibilities that tellers were not supposed to responsible for.  I was also given a chance to learn from the corporate consumer market leaders, which helped me learn some career advancing skills... which brings me to the cons.
cons: It has been a while since I have last visited my branch, but for the years that I was there, tellers are not allowed to sit.  The corporate market executive believes that when tellers sit, they all of a sudden cannot and will not provide great customer service.  Which is complete... bull.  Career advancement is rough.  Some people get stuck in the same position because corporate just don't see the talent that they have, as they do not visit enough.

review_title: Great company overall, yet some annoying flaws
pros: I got promoted to manager, was given a raise every year, and received a cash bonus.  The ability to grow and earn a decent living is strong with this organization.  Insurance and 401k match was great.  Co-workers were fun.
cons: Well, they shut my office down, which is stunning since we outperformed many branches that stayed open, so that is a huge Con.  I wish they could have lowered the salaries of upper management, lowered our bonuses or stopped raises INSTEAD of getting rid of employees that added value to the company.  Their technical systems were outdated.....when you have time sensitive material, EDGE (the loan system) can be extremely annoying.  Can be a bit "micro-managed" at times.

pros: It beats working at McDonalds
cons: Senior management is arrogant. Ken Lewis runs this place as if it were his personal empire instead of a shareholder-owned company that is successful because of its employees and not his "leadership". Many of us own stock in the company, and his personal hunger for Merrill-Lynch caused him to pay far too much for it. That has hurt our stock and this acquisition will probably hurt our compensation and possibly our positions.

review_title: The firm is formidable in its technology and resources.
job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The Training Program for Financial Advisors is comprehensive and thorough and the firm is quite inclusive in truly promoting diversity. The Firm is really serious about its fiduciary responsibility to clients and has set up programs and policies that align the advisors actions with the well being of the client. The technological resources and platform for investment research are unsurpassable.
cons: The firm has a culture of control and regulations which can feel limiting at times. The firms boasts of having the finest training program in the industry but that appears hyped and overstated. There is very little face to face instruction and attention. Trying to process the myriad email communiqures from the firm is exhausting and overwhelming.

review_title: Great Company wth lot's of Opportunities
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Overall the company is solid, the strategy is in place and the company  finally is making huge improvements to change it's reputation. lot's of associate benefits and opportunies to grow, best products, processess and systems in place.
cons: After being with BOA for almost 10 years, i would say the root cause to why many people leave is how the CMM treat their Managers.  As a Manager, we always aim to create a great culture, environment for our associates to be happy.  We all know that happy associates produce results. But there's a huge disconnect from upper management, they are too focused on results, themselves and their own careers, they want to hold you accountable to everything but never make time to even visit your store to support you or your associates.

review_title: Bank of America killed my dreams....and my hope for a future...
pros: Large bank that will probably be around for a long time as it is very financially stable.  Good benefits package and pay.
cons: Too many impossible to reach goals and not enough focus on doing the right thing for the customer versus the banks pocketbook.  Too much emphasis on making associates rush through their phone calls in X amount of seconds and rushing the client off the phone to save the bank money - they call this 'efficiency'.  Because of the pressure put on the associate to get off the phone, many times the service the customer receives is unsatisfactory.  Also too much preferential treatment given to the wealthy clientele while the average customers are treated like crap.

review_title: This is what you can expect.
job_title: Escalation Advocate in Simi Valley, CA
pros:
Slightly better than average pay
Good benefits
Plentiful reference resources for policies and procedures
Diverse front line workforce
Some retail discounts for being an employee (Verizon, Hertz, etc...)
cons:
Constant uncertainty about job security
Unclear and conflicting ideas and direction from upper management
Little to no increase in pay with no bonuses for years due to "insufficient company resources" while upper management gets at least a $5k bonus and our CEO receives $10+ million in bonuses a year. 
The family and friend system is extremely prevalent with regard to promotions and hirings. This is unfortunate, because as I am sure many employees would attest to, the best person for a job rarely gets it.

review_title: Don't get sucked into a black hole...
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
- 4 weeks of paid vacation
- Base salary with unjust bonus structure
cons:
- Monthly Assessments and Exams
- Constant performance pressure from bank and investment channels
- Responsible for banking and investments sales
- Must rely on referrals from bankers. More times than not, referrals are not received.
- Despite having series 7/66, you will work as a "Banker"
- They are all about credit cards, credit cards and more credit cards (98% banking products)
- Suitability is not a factor, they want you to sell a bank product to every client. Regardless of need
- Mandatory huddle every morning or they will write you up. 
- Very boring, little stimulation throughout the day
- Feel like walking on eggshells at all times 
- No Job security, at any moment they have the ability to fire and will leave negative impact on U-5

pros: Job and income stability plus bonus opportunities.
cons: Management has some unrealistic expectations for most locations and you cannot earn a bonus even if you reach 99.9% of your target to goals.  It also takes too long for some of your production results to be posted towards your goals which can cause you to lose an entire quarters worth of bonus pay.

pros: There are a lot of opportunities for involvement within the company and this can lend a hand to advancing your career. Overall, great corporate culture, very professional. This is a company that promotes being engaged in the community and this makes Bank of America an excellent place to work! Almost everyone at this company is very friendly and there are also great benefits too!
cons: No real down sides except that there are a few people that are managing others that should not be managers....think they may need to vet their screening process as to who has direct reports and who doesn't. It is not an unbearable place to be, even with some of the less qualifies management.

review_title: Work Here if you want your performance and incentive based off customer surveys
job_title: Small Business Fraud Client Servicing in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits package, 3 weeks paid time off, easy job.
cons: Unfair incentive opportunities. All incentive/performance ratings are based off of survey's that customers rate you. And if you do everything correct and are as nice as possible to the customer, there is also no way to dispute surveys. You can have excellent adherence, excellent average handle time, excellent everything but if you get one or two bad surveys, there is nothing that can be disputed. Surveys are worth 65% of performance ratings too! The work environment also needs to be more laid-back(can't have purse on top of desk, cannot wear non-closed toed shoes, cannot access any websites on work computer). Bank of America's known for "acting responsibly" and the performance ratings for the Small Business Fraud Department are not responsible or fair to employees.

review_title: Moderate place to work- high politics across various teams in Hyderabad.
pros:
>Nice workplace, Organised and vision focussed
>work life balance
>Company HR policies.
> Transportation.
>learning resources.
>Company is known for its values.
cons:
>Mid-level Managers(Managers, Seniormangers, AVP's) are totally partial, never care for the talent,
>No, employee retention.
>poor hikes, even hikes are not at all proportionate to the work it totally manager wish you will get lot of surprises.
>No encourgement in Career growth(No transperency)  
>Only during the external surveys the management recognises the "EMPLOYEE".
>If you are work great and if manager doesnt like you personlly he/ she will not support you in any manner rather they always try to decrease you if you give them a chance,
>In some cases managers will even forget the company rules and negotiate with the high level management to support some employees and favour them a lot professionally and personally.
>some times you will get doubts weather you are working in a political party. Politics are toooooo high. 
>No work from home, Dress code is forced to follow.

pros: They were flexible with work/life balance.  Was able to work part-time when necessary.  Was also able to switch my hours when I needed to.  Benefits were good.
cons: They were very unrealistic with how they trained people.  They were very rigid and seemed to stay with a script that wasn't reality based.  They would do role plays that everyone knew would not work, but they pushed the script anyway.  It was as if they only listened to consultants that had no real life experience with real customers.  They should have listened to employees more. They also pushed Customer Service Reps to  sell bank products too hard - It got very stressful.

pros: Meet people who become life long friends.  Schedules are sometimes flexible when you're going to school and working simultaneously.
cons: They don't care about the customers just making their numbers but put all the pressure on the tellers.  They constantly threaten our jobs saying if we don't meet unrealistic goals we get fired. Most of these banking centers are understaffed to the point where the branch manager or their assistant has to open a box.  Promotions are based on favoritism and take a long time to actually get to the next step.  Management has to know how to listen to their employees and give the right amount of authority to the right people (i.e. Make sure SSS's don't think they are the branch manager and always try to have their way)... My overall experience was horrible here in less than a year I was transferred to 3 different banks with 1 hour of notification.... THATS RIGHT one hour before my shift ended I'd come to find I would be going somewhere else.  I am NOW FREE FROM THEIR CHAINS AND COULDN'T BE HAPPIER! IF YOU GET A CALL FROM A RECRUITER RUN AWAY! go to a credit union instead those places are genuine with their customers!

review_title: Difficult to move from Retail to Corporate
pros: Working in retail banking, you gain a lot of experience in character building through meeting and working with different types of people. Dealing with difficult customers helps one understand how to leverage customer/relationship building tactics to appease an angry customer. These skills are valuable in strengthening personality traits and can be used in any industry.
cons: Below average salaries that don't make up for the type of work that is expected. Bonuses and pay increases aren't substantial enough to keep an employee there. Additionally, upper management assume that employees want a career in retail banking and thus don't provide the tools necessary for career growth. Some even lack the knowledge in how one can move from one area of the company to another. Very difficult to move from the retail side to corporate if that's where your interest lies.

pros: I loved working at BOA! BOA was vary face paced and the employees were a great joy to work with. You had to be very detailed ordinated and able to work under a lot of stress. At BOA you could learn lots of other responsibilities if you were willing to step forward and take charge in learning. I loved being able to learn new things and doing several daily tasks that weren't just in my job description. If you showed that you were willing to be a leader and learn different things there was opportunity to grow within the company.  Best place I were worked!!
cons: Only cons were having to sell produces while working in the drive-thru window a lone and having to meet a referral quota.

job_title: Service to Sales in Nicholson, PA
pros: Management was friendly,yet not always helpful
cons: This is aa incorrect title. It should be Sales to Service. Customer Service Rep is required to sell another credit card, Balance Transfer or Direct Deposit on each and every inbound call. Many cardholders are upset and feel pressured to get another BOA credit card everytime they call in for a service call. Associate is told to max out cardholders card when there is a request for a Balance Transfer/Direct Deposit, resulting in a negative effect on their Fico score. Many cardholders do not understand how payments are applied, and in reality do not get a true 0 % on these transfers. Rather than distort the truth, and hurt the cardholder, I made sure they had a full understanding of what they where getting into. Consequently my "numbers" suffered.  We are told that calls are randon, this is not true, they have the ability to route the calls, which may negatively affect the associate......Extremely HIGH Turnover,  my class of 28 ended with 3 people including myself making it for a year. New Classes every month - good luck new hires, you will need it. Schedule can be changed at any moment...Goal setting not realistic, management input on how to achieve goals, always the same, never tailored to the individual.... Beware

job_title: Banking Center Manager in Tampa Palms, FL
pros: Great training. We were required to complete it immediately. Challenge is management did not always provide  adequate time to complete it.
cons: Upper level  management says that they are concerned about your development  and are interested in your feedback.  However that is just a façade.  And the main challenge is that you have supervisors upper level management who themselves do not know what they are doing.  They rely on others who have been in the job that have more experience to show them what needs to be done.   If I was you I would not even apply.  Don't waste your time going there where in the end you will be stress every single day and the support is not there for you.  Career opportunities are available however make sure that you know how to brown nose and you know how to work the system in order to move up the ladder hard work is not necessarily the Avenue or the path for success.

review_title: You will learn hear many stories on the phones. You will get many upset people you can’t help.
pros: The people were pretty kind. Though it is a very male culture. It was not hard to make friends because you’re all in the same miserable boat.
cons: Upper management put pressure on management who tried to be nice. Always pressing for time on the phones, it’s good to buy us food but everyday it seemed they didn’t want us to leave, period. Their products are so bad they can’t keep people off the phones and their platforms are similar. Get your series 7/66 and leave. Learn how to be rejected and please help those who need financial advice; don’t churn them like the bank seems to push. Don’t act like someone in debt is worthless. Preach customer service and simultaneously teach associates to get them off the phone when they don’t play financial dice with a 2X year old.

review_title: Great if you like what you do
job_title: Operations Consultant- Wholesale Credit in Charlotte, NC
pros: Fun work, great management and people , Decent pay and benefits. Depending where you are it may be difficult to move up but, you can always move across departments and a job that suits your skill set and a department that promotes from within
cons: Crazy workload and lot of stress and Pressure if you don’t know how to manage it. Also, it is Hard to get ride of useless employees and slackers once they are in. The company hardly ever  fires anyone.  They care too much for public image and lawsuits which is good for job security but the free riders make everyone else pick up the slack and abuse work from home, sick days, training, and don’t contribute at all nor care for the low performance and horrible reviews -no shame- leaving the motivated employees with their mess to handle.  Everyone knows it, nobody can do anything abt it

review_title: Bank of America, where your career dreams die and you and your customers learn a new level of disrespect.
pros: organized paid training, multiple locations
cons:
staffing levels and staff competence, lack of clear guidelines, GROSS IGNORANCE of HR policies and procedures, and prevention of access to even vacation time off for medical procedures... "we have too many people on vacation in the upcoming month"

telling customers that live paycheck to paycheck that their entire paycheck of $300 or more has been eaten up by $30 fees that would have been easily avoidable had someone actually taken the time to set their account up correctly and that you cannot refund them any of it is always a pleasurable experience

writing mortgages doomed to failure ($3500/month was a bit unreasonable for an income of $65000/yr) because the policies allow it and you have to meet a mortgage goal

review_title: Good if you're starting from scratch.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Detroit, MI
pros: Benefits, bragging rights of working for a world renownd bank and the largest in the U.S.,
cons: Poor Management, a very great manager left to a competitor because of the very low morale of the company. VERY VERY MICRO-MANAGED.  Management only cares about making the NUMBERs which is fine but they fell to realize that a banking center wouldn't "make the goals/numbers" if it wasnt for the entire TEAM. A banking center doesnt run on ONE person. Bank of America treats you like crap, black-ot dates for vacation and personal time, hiring freezes that makes banking centers run on only three people that should have seven, six to seven "check in" conference calls A DAY to see where you are at with your numbers and a "action plan" if you havent hit your goal. Back stabbing to get to the top. Upper management will like you 1st by your "apperance" and 2nd by your work needless to say if you are very attractive and appear motivated it'll get you far...

review_title: Great job for developing interpersonal skills.
pros:
Develop relationships with people in the community.
Significant tuition assistance for college students.
Sales and customer service experience.
Experience in a business environment.
Relatively competitive pay for a non-skilled position.
cons: Handling irate customers can be a pain, but try to view it as a positive because learning how to provide positive solutions to these customers will become a useful skill for the future.  To a large extent, your experience with the company will be dictated by your banking center manager. If s/he is a positive person you will have a great time working for the company and on the other hand a bad manager can ruin the job for you.

review_title: Stagnating because resources are not utilized to maximum efficiency
pros:
Good company benefits such as insurance and corporate discount.
Brand name that is well recognized on street.
cons:
Outsourcing has caused confusion and decreased quality of work in that you spend a lot of time looking for some one who can help you complete a certain task.
There seems to be a lack of interest in developing individual careers.  There is not much recognition and distinction between an outstanding and mediocre performance.  There is not a lot of mobility or room for promotion.

review_title: Legs cut out from underneath us...
job_title: Banking Center Manager II in Portland, OR
pros: Professionally ran. Fair treatment of teammates is taken seriously. Diversity, including diversity if thought, is encouraged. Good benefits. Competive pay amongst competitors. Good associate banking/lending benefits.
cons: Monumental changes made to incentive structure are rolled out and then continuously changed throughout the year. Incentive structure designed so that it's near impossible to fund. FTE/employee hours in banking centers cut back to bear bones, leaving absolutely no cushion for associate illness, promitions, vacation and LOA's let alone successfully running the day to day operations. Disconnect between upper management and BC teammates. Wasteful of paper and time spent filling out paperwork; BofA needs to go elecronic with forms and signature cards like most other national banks have years ago! Managers can't manage because they're busy doing what their cut emoloyees would have been doing. There isn't an incentive program for tellers, sales and service specialists and teller operations specialists; this leaves the manager and personal banker with resentful, unmotivated employees. Asinine!

review_title: Being a teller was an excellent first job, but it did get stressful
pros: BoA provides the following: great benefits, good pay, a sturdy foundation for college student seeking a job in the industry. Training is paid and thorough. You get discounts on certain things, like movie tickets. Their time-off policies are also fair. Your teammates are supportive and helpful (depending on the banking center).
cons: Scheduling was not flexible and you constantly feel pressured to offer products to the customer. You have to be overly friendly, which seems unnecessary and annoying to the customer. If you work at an extended hours branch, you will probably not have much free time. Every banking center is different and the banking center team may either work together efficiently or not.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Healthcare benefits from Bank of America are amazing
cons: They lure you in with statements like, "you'll earn six figures," "We are a new site so we're promoting from within very quickly," ect. and it's all a bait and switch. I have never been so micromanaged in my life, and I came from Wells Fargo so that's really saying something. We are using PassPerfect for our series 7 and 66, yet not a single person on our management team has ever used it. So, you have to email PassPerfect employees if you have questions. Constant changes, we've already had our scheduled training time changed 3 times. Very unorganized and stressful and it seems like they will literally hire anybody. The personalities in my training group and just awful. Only half the group can successfully handle small talk. Steer clear if you want to save yourself from total disappointment.

review_title: If you are in banking, this has to be one of the best places to be.
pros: Huge company (c. 300,000 people).  Very stable.  Top of the U.S. banking pyramid, having made many of the right decisions even given in the economic downturn we are in.  Strong work from home program; if you are not customer-facing, many of us can work from home full time which also means you can pick (at your own expense) any part of the country to work from.  When we get to the other side of this recession, the questionable decisions around some of the recent acquistions SHOULD look like having been great buying opportunities.
cons: Can have many of the impersonal side effects of a huge company in Corporate America.  The  work from home program can feel very isolating.  The career opportunities and face-to-face interactions are more numerous in Charlotte.  Customer service leaves something to be desired because although service can be OK while as customer is  a well-oiled cog in their machine, you are a spanner-in-the-works if the customer steps outside the routine.

review_title: This Job is Only good if you like to be over -worked
pros: You meet great people (customers)   And it's never boring.   It's always busy in the bank so the days go by fast. If you are good at your job you easily get promoted but if you are no longer the best the tables turn and they do whatever and say whatever to make u feel like a failure.   If you love banking and are ok with hearing crap all day long and like having 1 million goals then BOFA is for you.  Be careful, that you you are placed in a banking center that has opportunity once you are stuck in a lousy bank it's the end.
cons: No recognition, we are not treated like humans rather like dogs. If you love banking and are ok with hearing crap all day long and like having 1 million goals then BOFA is for you.
