Be careful, that you you are placed in a banking center that has opportunity once you are stuck in a lousy bank it's the end.

pros: BOA offers wonderful benefits.  The ability to transfer to different locations is a plus.  Great vacation time and personal/sick time.  The benefits are truly the only reason I am still with the bank after 5+ years.
cons: Associates that should not be promoted are and the ones who have worked for years and are great at what they do get walked all over!  Branch managers are often hired from outside the bank and cannot keep up with the day to day requirements for the banking centers.  They then create frustrating work environments for the associates that have to pick up the slack and continue to not get recognition for their hard work.   I constantly feel walked over.

review_title: Massive FI with complex matrix environment
pros: My internal business partners were great - very knowledgable, action oriented, and able to have fun at the same time.  Benefits were great.  They use their talent planning the right way with all employees.
cons: After over 20 years dedicated to the company, as a high performer and fast mover to an executive position, they didn't think twice at dropping me like a hot rock when times were tough.  They kept several people less qualified, experienced, motivated, and able when they could have retained me with a move down.  The corporation is so massive that events occurring in units outside your own can have a massive impact on your financial compensation.

review_title: Great company culture, bureaucratic processes can be frustrating.
pros: Great benefits, overall corporate culture is great. Leadership is cool letting sellers achieve goals by any means necessary, so you can make pretty good living if you have a cool leadership team.
cons: Intense pressure to sell.  Employees are bombarded with a relentless onslaught of pep rally-esque emails from all levels of management-daily, weekly and on "peak days," hourly-to sell customers blind, deaf and dumb. As soon as any random number of bankers begin to achieve the sales goals in place, executive leadership will revise the sales incentive plans to employ a random off-color algorithmic formula that must be met, based on volume, times customer visits, divided by Sunday and the color blue, in order to even earn a sales bonus incentive. Keeping the BOA sales incentive decoder ring handy can grown cumbersome.

job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Woodbridge, VA
pros: Benefits are amazing. I have never worked for a company with so many different benefits available to both part time as well as full time associates. From health benefits to tuition reimbursement, to corporate discounts, child care assistance and so many more. There are also tons of career opportunities available with BOA. You can almost go in any direction within the company given that you put in the time and the work to get there.
cons: Very stressful work enviornment. If you do not work well under pressure DO NOT work for Bank of America. Although each day is a new adventure it can be very stressful. For the amount of work being put on the Financial Center associates i would expect them to give pretty good raises but good luck seeing a raise other than the merit increase. Staff is being cut left and right also which leave the front line associates being yelled at constantly by customers because of lack of staffing which is not the financial centers fault but customer do not see it that way.

review_title: Get all you can on the way in.  Once you're here the compensation stinks...even if you exceed expectations.
job_title: Senior Vice President  in Charlotte, NC
pros: Lots of career opportunities.  Especially if you live in the right city.  The relationship culture is great if you are sociable and ambitious.
cons: Poor raises.  Unfair compensation structure.  Arrogant senior management.  You really need to fit the mold to be successful here.  There is not a lot of room for people with different styles to be successful.  If you are highly ambitious and comfortable being (ahem) assertive if you are female and a dick if you are male, then you will do well here.  Oh, and if you're a sycophant to your boss, odds are, he or she won't notice, or care much.  The bank, and we do mean THE Bank, is all about making your boss look good, then getting out and on to your next role.

pros: Have been with the bank for more than a year and so far I am so satisfied and happy with my work and career growth with the company. They always give chances to everyone and make sure that their decision will effect the majority of people and its a long term solution. :) There are lots of opportunities to come, I am excited what the bank can offer more to the employees.
cons: They become complacent when it comes to the company policies ( maybe the its the task of the HR) but what they set as an expectation during the induction training should reflect from day 1 to day N of the associate - e.g Dress code, Clean desk policy.

pros: I like my job but I also understand it is a sales based job. Some think it is not but the bank is a business and the bank needs to make money like any other business. It is very numbers driven which is fine if you get that. Good opportunity for advancement and quality people within the bank are all the pros. Switch to quarterly bonuses is even better then semesters that we had for some time.
cons: The compensation doesn't feel adequate compared to the hours spent. The ladder to move while it may be quick can sometimes be counter productive in the pay scale but opportunities are plenty and you can move quickly through the ranks. It is somewhat about who you know and how they can help advance you at times.

review_title: A lot of management changes, no sense of security to grow a career
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
- Good analyst program for people starting out in Sales & Trading
- As long as you are performing, can get promoted to Associate and VP easily enough. Getting to director is when the the time can increase.
- Expenses and travel perks if you cover accounts outside NY
-Bryant Park office is still new and a nice trading floor
- They are trying to do more diversity initiatives and programs
cons:
- In equities there has been so much change in top management that there have been RIFs to make room for current management's cliques. 
- Always fear and risk of a round of layoffs. 
- Very political and there are clear favorite groups/ people to align yourself with
-Bryant Park location close to Times Squares so can be annoying
- The balance sheet is no longer a pro, but a reason why businesses turn us down. It sometimes feels like a commercial bank, not an investment bank.

pros: Benefits, 40hrs only no overtime, semi-consistent schedule (depends on the branch you work at), lots of opportunities in the bank if this is your career path. 1 hr lunch break. Products and services mostly the same and in some aspects, somewhat better than other financial institutions. Of course, customers will come in and complain about how terrible boa is.
cons: The branch where you work at will really make or break your experience. Your manager, coworkers, customers. Very cs focused so depends on if you naturally like to work with a variety of people and biting your lip when getting yelled at is something you can handle. HEAVELY focused on goals. Days can be slow with no customer traffic. Work on Saturdays.

job_title: Business Support Lead/Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Many opportunities to explore career options and roles. If you're driven, there is opportunity for growth and advancement. I will recommend to friends that there are opportunities to explore but tread carefully.
cons: Layoffs happen about every 6 months to readjust the business overall and the earnings for the stockholders.  When these layoff events occur, no matter how well you do or how good your performance has been, if your number is up, its up and you will be let go.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Lake Worth, FL
pros: They pay you $60k salary and a quarterly bonus plan that averages $4-5k more a quarter if you're in a banking center with good traffic.
cons: You are NOT a financial advisor.  You are a licensed banker performing 95% banking (opening checking, savings, selling credit cards, upset banking customers and solving banking problems). You are required to place everyone into a managed account that hasn't kept up with the S & P 500 Index.  It has underperformed every major benchmark over the last 5 years, and you are told to recommend it to every banking client irrespective of suitability.  There is crappy training throughout the organization and the existing employees at the branch can make or break a new FSA.  It is a sink or swim organization.  The absurd policies and procedures that change on a weekly basis are a result of the never ending lawsuits against BAC.

pros: The benefits are hard to beat.  With 4 months now for pregnancy leave.  The attitude is to constantly look for a job that moves up with your career.  Not bad.
cons: With great benefits comes the entitlement crowd. Those employees that feel a day off is owed to them with all the pay and compromise that comes with signing up for intermitted FMLA.  When that is exhausted, then short term disability.   I have a coworker that has been on the team for almost 2 years now, and I haven't seen that person in two years, 3 months of days working.  That would not be consistent. So if you do not mind working hard to meet metrics next to an empty desk.  Sign up.  Or if you are the type of person that would rather say you work than to just sign up for full-time disability from the government.  Then this is the company for you.

review_title: Great company, but make sure you don't get stuck in a boring role that you're overqualified for.
pros: Stable, possible to do several career switches and still be with one company, very ethical company, very good overall compensation for good performers.
cons: Slow to change; hard to get things done across divisions; to move to different role in another part of company is a challenge if you don't have a strong network (you might as well be applying from outside the company);  you can get stuck doing uninteresting work that you are overqualified for; finance within the company is really just accounting/management reporting (the real interesting finance work is often done by the individual lines of business or by some total corporate analytical groups).

review_title: Better than a sharp stick in the eye.
job_title: VP, Product Management in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good work/life balance; Can stay within the company and move around from organization to organization for virtually years; full of incredibly talented, knowledgeable, impressive associates.
cons: Extreme political environment; You cannot use plain-speak when assessing a situation/risk/scenario-- anything. You have to use 1000 buzz-word/politically compliant phrases to say something that in a normal environment would take 50 words. People are promoted more on their likeability than there performance, also on how much power their direct manager has within their org - read: if your manager is not well thought of, you're not going anywhere either.

pros: Good benefits, stable job, good environment. Big company, big recognition among others. Good for your resume. Tough to get in
cons: BOA treats employee like a number and if 1 small policy is not follow you will get fired. If you help a co-worker you will get fired, if you don't follow policy and procedures you will get fired. Management is all over you, very controlling, no freedom to speak, you will get fired. Leadership will not give any opportunities or second chances, so watch your back everybody listens and you have no friends. Sad but true

review_title: Bank of America changed my view on the banking industry,
pros: Working for BOA or BAC as they like to be referred to allowed me to meet a lot of wonderful people(customers). I was able to build relationship that I carried with me after leaving the company. I was able to learn from  the financial irresponsiblity of others.
cons: BOA claims to be a company that works with integrity. I beg to differ. What part does integrity play in forcing workers to offer each and every product that they have to every customer regardless of their financial situation? I found it very upsetting that people living pay check to pay check were encourage to sign up for accounts requiring minimum balances of $300. I was very uncomfortable with selling products that would not benefit the customer but would definitly benefit the company,

review_title: It all depends on what department you are in.
pros: I have worked in the credit dept and the loss mitigation departments at bank of America. The credit department was tedious work but was well run and I was treated fairly. This review is not in regards to the credit department. BOA has good benefits and offers a lot of time off, more than most places. It was a good place to gain some experience.
cons: Loss mitigation was extremely chaotic as it was a new department. The department has lost 40% of its employees to other banks in the area due to employees being dissatisfied. Being undervalued is commonplace and once employees have had enough management will attempt to dissuade employees from quitting by saying negative things about the competition.

pros: Great pay because of my tenure. You get a lot of access to many great tools. The position is comparable to a Team Manager but without the HR drama, scheduling and corrective action issues.
cons: There are too many chiefs you have the line of business to support which you do not report to but support then a Project Manager who hands out what needs to be done who also is not your manager neither the line of business manager who you support and then you have your own Proficiency coach Manager who does not report to either. The communication between all three is terrible and puts most the work on the proficiency coaches which is fine if all three management lines were not saying and asking you to do different things contrary to each other. Communication is horrible you feel as a coach like the red headed step child in a weird 3 way divorce

review_title: A bleak and dreary call center posing as a legitimate investing job.
job_title: Senior Customer Service in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The insurance is a big plus. The pay is adequate. They pay for you to take the series 7.
cons: The company is blunt about not caring about you. There is no thought given to workplace happiness. The office is grey and bleak. It is a call center with the same turnover rate and the associated problems. There is no time to study for the 7 when you work 40 hrs a week, but if you fail you are fired. If you have been there for a year you are likely management. No one at the office is happy. You are constantly being updated on the list of things likely to get you fired or disciplined.

pros: Bank of America Home Loans has had issues with meeting closing dates.  A new fulfillment executive, along with a drastic decrease in refinance transactions, is changing that.  Mortgage Loan Officers have a marketing tool (LenderOffice) that efficiently and effectively regularly touches their past and potential clients and referral sources.  Contacts become the property of the company, though.  In other words, the database cannot be downloaded and taken with you when you leave.  Keep a separate list.  Originators that are allied with a banking center receive referrals from the Personal Bankers.  The company has a process to send referrals from the toll-free number to local loan officers as well.  It seems to be a good place to get business.
cons:
The company is very concerned with regulations and with the protection of non-public personal information (customers' SSN's, DOB's, credit reports, etc.).  This is understandable and admirable.  Just be aware there is periodic training on applicable regulations, and weekly NPI inspections.

Bank of America is a huge company with many layers and mid-level managers.  The culture doesn't fit with everyone.

review_title: Many Challenges but Great learning through solving these challenges
job_title: SCRA Project Audit Team Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: My Time with Bank of America was a wonderful experience.  I had many opportunities to grow and learn and show my abilities under the Great Leadership I had at times.  As an employee you are treated well and they are very understanding how happy employees and family are important to the growth of the company.
cons: At times not so open to keep everyone knowing the direction leadership is going.  Training is true on the job training.  You learn as you go.  Many System issues but your duties must continued to be completed with our without needed systems.  You must be able to roll with the process ebbs and flows of change that are continuous there.

review_title: If you're a career banker, how can you go wrong with this company?
pros: Lots of room for growth. Generally they promote from within. Or you can enter "The Kingdom" one of two ways, constantly apply on their Bank of America career site, or find the staffing agency that the department you are trying to work for is using for their staffing needs. Bank of America isn't on the high end of the pay-scale, but their employee benefits are among the best. Just be ready to play the corporate game, and you'll do well.
cons:
Bank of America is always affected by the market and economy and they won't hesitate to hand out pink slips. It seems to the norm around the company.

One of the most liberal company's I've ever worked for. Very bureaucratic, and very political. Network well and treat it like a game of survivor. In the end, "it's just business".

review_title: Great discounts and benefits but job sucks
pros: Great benefits, fabulous discounts & paid for holidays. They provide child care/tuition reimbursement (business degree only). You can work your way up if you want to.
cons: Lack of staffing means the branch is always busy. Customers are rude. Lots of regulations. You're expected to know products & sell to customers, like a retail sale job. They don't provide any product training, unless you want to do it on your off time. My manager said they used to be more in touch and cared about their workers but now it's nothing like that. I agree with her. I don't feel corporate really understands the day to day issues and how things work. They expect you to dot your i's and cross your t's yet they don't give you any staffing nor incentives to help you along the way.

pros: Great benefits. That's about it.
cons: Micromanaging is awful. Stress is astronomical for the pay tellers receive, pushing sales goals with no incentive plan like everyone else in the banking center gets. Banking centers are constantly understaffed and then tellers are blamed because they literally can't do everything at once. Managers break policy and expect tellers to do things that are flat out wrong. Tellers are the only people in the banking center with no internet access and no email, pretty much completely cut off from communication with anyone in the company besides direct manager.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Processor in Tampa, FL
pros: company benefits with insurance and time off
cons:
1) Managers will micromanage excessively.
2) The workload is excessive to the point that you don't have a chance to finish your work for the day. Only option is to pick up where you leave off the next day which is fine but then some managers will be abrasive and constantly criticize you for not finishing on time. It's mainly about what you didn't do as opposed to the good things you did.
3) Not a fun job at all - you will constantly feel disrespected and/or constantly hear complaints either by a manager, MLO, underwriter, or customer. 
4) Stress - your mental health will be effected and you can lose your mind.
5) The salary - the salary is low with what you have to put up with. It's not worth going through all the cons I listed with the salary you are given.

pros: Just like my headline, I have seen many of associates complaining about their salaries and to be honest with you, any where you go salaries are about the same. It all depends on your skill level, experience and your negotiation skill. FYI, I do have friends in Wells Fargo & WAMU/CHASE, and pay are all pretty much similar.
cons: Just like any other large bank, its pretty much the same. Hard to take personal day, in most of the case which it would exclude Monday, Friday, Saturday & 1st, 14th, 15th, end of the month for being peak day or pay day. Not to mention if the pay day lands on weekend, also include 2nd, 13th, 16th or even 28th of the month. Almost impossible to take sick day unless if you have doctor's notice, just because employee can't provide doctor's note doesn't mean he/she wasn't sick.

pros: Benefits are average, pay is average, it's really hard to get fired, mediocrity is rewarded, it's easy to "disappear" in the organization
cons: questionable management competence, regular lack of disclosure of key business info by senior management, lack of fairness in treatment of all employees (especially around legacy company employment)

review_title: Dysfunctional working environment with poor management
pros: The associates who work in the group are all intelligent and that is why they end up leaving.
cons: San Francisco location is in a silo with mixed interactions with the rest of the company in Charlotte and New York. Management either tries to micro-manage every aspect of the project or else they are incompetent and don't fully understand the issues (this is a quant group with some non-quant managers). Turnover has been a huge problem and they are constantly re-training new staff because anyone who realizes that there are problems with the group leaves the group / company. Management plays favorites with certain individuals and if you are not one fo those few people, then you might be underpaid or you might not advance in your career.

review_title: Overall, it was a great job for someone with no college plans.
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Jacksonville, FL
pros: They really train and allow the employee's to take control of their own career path. You can go as far as you want if you put in the effort. If you have a degree, you can go even farther.
cons: The company truly comes first, and they do have a lot of rules that makes no sense. They dont always share these new rules with the employees, so if you break them they automatically assume you were supposed to know of the changes. They also care more about the company, than the customers they service. I've seen the bank do a lot of shady things to people without thinking twice.

review_title: Like most jobs it's great when working for the right manager, terrible when not!
pros:
This can be a great job if you have a great manager.
The salary is great and you are able to start at a high salary and position with an MBA.
cons:
Working for Bank of America is not what it used to be:
Before it was all about promotions and large bonuses, now it's all about fighting to keep your jobs.
Mass layoffs now appear to be quarterly.
You are moved around to different teams a lot, many people have 3 or more managers per year.
Even people with great performance records can be laid off.
You can often be transferred to mean managers who don't appreciate your hard work.
Some departments are great, others are very cutthroat, it all depends on the executive in charge.

review_title: Poor Management in Pittsburgh, nepotism and age discrimination
job_title: Assistant Vice President-Foreclosure Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Coworkers are great and your peers work together despite management incompetence. The helping between coworker, not management, is how we learn. The information gathered is shared and taught to management.
cons: Nepotism and management friends are promoted and kept in Pittsburgh office and anyone over the age of 50 are not involved and are first to go on layoffs. The pay increases are not distributed fairly, they are usually across the board no matter your review. An excellent review may be made but you are told you are at top of salary en when you question senior management all they say is you should not be told that and will not give salary range.

pros: Great benefits, flexible work schedule and have great training opportunities.  Because it is a large company you have many opportunities to move into other positions and learn many different facets of the company.
cons: Merit increases have been minimal over the past 5 years and the bonuses have decreased as well.  The bank preaches a meritocracy but it is not.  Raises are decided before the reviews are given and good solid performers are laid off to increase the shareholders profit.  A lot of benefits have gone lean over the years such as stock options (ended in 2002) and the pension fund in 2013.  My advice is to get hired, learn as much as you can, then leave the company and get paid what you are worth.

review_title: They don't care about their tellers
job_title: Self Employed in New York, NY
pros: Great hands on experience. You learn to see the communities you work in different, and share a deeper appreciation for the small businesses. Great if you're a business or finance student. Fast paced industry so you learn to be quick and precise, especially handling money. Paid holidays! Discount program, cheap healthcare as well as a flexible spending account for co pay.
cons: You are NOT appreciated. You are used and forced to sell "products" (credit cards, loans, etc) to people who would do better without. You don't get bonuses, only personal bankers and higher ups do. You have to be fake and regular clients are on to you and they get annoyed after a while. Some people stay with the company for years since they don't have anything else going for them, causing them to do their job poorly.

job_title: Credit Claims Analyst in Middletown, DE
pros: Great benefits, decent pay, co-workers were fun to work with.
cons: Management often felt very disorganized, environment was not very inviting, and you often feel like you are just treated as another number, not a human being. There were often many technical issues with the computer systems/programs that would prevent associates from doing their jobs, yet you would still be required to take phone calls from customers until issues were resolved. There really didn't seem to be anything in place to aid in the advancement of employees (even though the idea was often promoted). Even failing to meet one aspect of job performance will disqualify you from receiving monthly incentives or posting out of the department/applying for another unrelated position within the bank (that you may be better suited for).

pros: I personally enjoyed my coworkers and the different types of people you meet during a work day. If you are a people person and have good interpersonal communication skills, this is a nice job, as this will help you with your sales numbers.
cons: Half way into my tenure as a teller, the company shifted their focus more towards sales than customer service, and that placed a lot of pressure on my bank. Seeing that my bank was placed in a location where we don't get many new acquisitions, our goals was just the same as a bank placed conveniently near a school and major tourist stop. The higher corporate folks didn't really care for that, which placed a lot of pressure on the employees, which created some minor friction.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Pasadena, CA
pros: The company in general is a great place to work for. Customer service representative are given great and informative training before hitting the floor. Atmosphere is great and people you work with are very helpful, friendly and become friends more than co-workers.
cons: Numbers the game. It doesn't seem to matter how much a person improves in the game. It's all about the numbers. Competition among co-workers is stressful. Management also seem to watch out about themselves then the people they are leading. There doesn't seem to be anyone on top who has your back. It's a feeling most co-workers seem have.

job_title: Relationship Banker in New Port Richey, FL
pros: Bank of America offers wonderful benefits, even to part-time employees, such as tuition reimbursement, childcare reimbursement, coverage of spouse/domestic partner, and paid vacation.
cons: The few times I called out sick, I was made to feel like I was slacking, and letting the team down. The day after, I was asked by one manager to read the texts on my phone to see what I was doing the day I was out sick. As a violation of privacy, I did not honor the request. When I expressed my concerns about this manager to upper management, the concerns were brushed off, and I was told I was the problem and "surely [the manager] wouldn't do something like that". The micromanagement from leadership is stressful, tiring, and demotivating. It's suffocating.

job_title: Human Resources Professional  in Charlotte, NC
pros: Because of its size, there are potential opportunities to work on interesting, large-scale projects. Coworkers tend to be engaging, helpful, and smart. Very strong and strategic HR function. Focused on business results and using data in decision-making. Good benefits package and competitive salaries.
cons: Requires a lot of networking and political shrewdness to navigate and get things done because of the size and complexity. Reorganizations mean that managers frequently change (so make sure you document all your accomplishments and make them known or you’ll get shortchanged at review and talent planning time) and more time spent on dealing with the changes than being able to focus and drive out transformational activities. Form can matter over substance so be visible.   As an employee, you may be viewed as just an expendable commodity

job_title: Mortgage Underwriter in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: The only positive factor I see with Bank of America is the amount of volunteer work done by employees + financial contributions to various charities.
cons: Management is so unorganized information changes pretty much every day.Some customers are required to jump through hoops others are not simply because the leadership groupd cannot get the policies and procedures straight.If your Bank of America customer service experience isn't all that great, it's most likely because management has the service associates going in circles.

review_title: A great place to work for as a part time teller because of the health benefits, paid vacation, and tuition reimbursement
pros: Great Advantages: Markets valued teamwork, cheerful and engaging employees, health benefits, 401k, pensions, paid vacation, tuition reimbursement, growth opportunities within the banking center, off and be paid on federal holidays, and volunteering opportunities.
cons: Growth from banking center to corporate rate is small, currently the job security is poor, demanding job for sales platform positions, constant changes in regulations and policies, too many conference calls, unnecessary paper work overload, constant negativity from the media which reflect on and directly affect front line employees that work in the banking center, and constant bashing from customers because of fees and more fees.

review_title: Some nice people, some horrible actors and get away with it
pros: The morale was very poor where I worked at the bank.  However, my contact with other associates across the bank, 95% of them were pleasant and positive.
cons: They allow African Americans to under-achieve, make errors, act up and at the same time reap the benefits and rewards of working for the Bank.  The Bank through their managers discriminates against people who are not in an affinity group: Black, single mothers, gay, disabled.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Cal-Nev-Ari, NV
pros: Decent benefits, hours are O K, some decent fellow employees. Other than that no, the hours are too long, expectations are too high, too hard to get a day off fir a doctors appt.
cons: On boarding is only as good as the manager in charge. You have to find all your answers in the online reference portal. Definitely do not ask as you will be told to consult Pro. It is ridiculous if you are new and have a customer in front of you. Never mind customer service, the manager hides in the back all day. We only have two tellers all day long and we are a very busy branch. They want to engage the customer, no matter if they are on the phone etc.  The only responses I get is why I am not a teller. Oh and they are only interested in business customers and people who are classified as mass affluent.

pros: Benefits, work from home, talented and dedicated co-workers.  That's all but for some reason you request 20 word min. here....what if there's not that many pros?
cons: Middle Management is worst I've ever encountered.  Won't stand up for anything for fear of being laid off in next round (which occurs frequently).  Mentality is "that's the way it's always been done".  Big push for employee moral is a joke.  All that matters to any Senior Management is higher marketshare, they don't care if you work 60+ hours a week.  When you're burnt out, theyll just get rid of you.  Work life balance is non existent for majority of IT.  Very hard to transfer to different area.  Company preaches about 'Managing your own career' but then rarely allows transfers

pros: Work with high net worth clients providing liquidity solutions to clients.
cons: No growth opportunity what so ever.  Banking advisors get yelled at by the mighty Merrill Advisor who are always correct and will always be protected its always the bankers fault.  Terrible lending process through PHH now moving to Bank of America's platform which isn't much better.  Get yelled at by clients regarding the process where you are just the middle man and most of the time in the dark.  Merrill branch management has no respect for the bank or the banking advisors as they don't feel there is any value provided.  Now banking advisors are going to become fully commissioned mortgage loan officers completely slapping in the face all the dedicated employees who worked so hard to make the division work.  No wonder the stock price is $13 per share compared to its peers.  Incompetent, unqualified management.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in East Providence, RI
pros:
Flexible spending  account topped up by the bank to use for anything dealing with health for the calendar year. 
Childcare reimbursement .
The option for voluntary time off.
The trade board where you can post your scheduled shift or part-of internally so thst other ppl qualified to do your job can pick up the hours so that you can have unpaid time off.
cons:
Aggressive  sales goals.
Management who do not know how to do the job or never have worked on the phones, yet they are telling you how to deal with phone calls. 
The ever changing  environment. Things constantly  change for the good and bad.
It's hard to move to a post off the phones once you have a post on the phones.

pros:
Flexible work environment.   Good respect to family related issues, time offs etc.
Ability to move around (internal job postings).
cons:
No growth unless you are in Charlotte or "know" people.
Whether you work hard or not, everyone will be "praised" and "recognized".  So, you can work hard if you want for your own satisfaction.  Because of the number of people,  hardly anyone has time to actually notice what you have done.  
If you give up on 'career growth' and happy with your salary and work environment, this is a great place.  If  you want to grow then, either move to Charlotte and be 'visible' or move on to a different company.  If you are at a stage in your career where you want to take a break from climbing the ladder and just enjoy a flexible environment... this is the place to be.

review_title: Working there was an OK experience
pros: I did meet some really nice people. The pay wasnt horrible but its not the best. They have holiday Parties, Give gifts on certain holidays and even have daily meetings with the whole site to recognize people who have met ofrexceeded production goals. They also keep you informed about things going on as far as promotions, new production goals, charities, and other opportunities.
cons: I think workers should be paid more for the amount of work expected. After a while you get sick of counting money all day. Sometimes management can be very two faced, they will smile in your face and talk about you behind your back. They are not very reasonable about taking vacation days, only one person in our department can take off so sometimes it left choices very limited.  Sometimes production goals were unreasonable and the bulletin they posted each month on the wall made everyone very aware if you werent meeting production.

review_title: Decent job... not ideal for college graduate
pros:
Benefits
Pay is decent
Qualified management
Good to see SOME friendly regular customers
Advancement opportunities
cons: I really don't like that they don't have more full time opportunities for recent college grads. There is definitely lots of micro-management going on at b of a. You are stuck in this position for a year before any type of advancement can take place. At the interview they make it seem like you wont do any selling but you will...although they are just referrals it can be a headache presenting the credit cards that customers clearly don't want. Like any customer service jobs there are going to be some really difficult customers that make you want to tell them about themselves (but you will also get some who make the job worthwhile). I was told that technically supervisors are supposed to observe us everyday which is insane to me. Micro-management at it finest. Finally part time hours are stretched over 5 days which can be annoying

pros: Benefits are great.  401k, health, dental, employee special programs, etc.  Also job stability for a average to above average performer is very stable (unlike Wells Fargo).  The bulk of decisions during our shrinking the servicings space seems to have been fair and trimming fat.
cons: Countrywide culture is still dominating the mortgage space unfortunately.  Pay decisions, position blocking for business critical employees, drama from the CW portfolio and HUGE system updates required.  The space is shrinking in the servicing space, so promotion, increased pay, and retention options are limited to keeping top talent.

pros: Competitive salary with good benefits, particularly days of vacation. A well defined framework to develop your work. Qualified and professionals peers. Good technology, not the state of the art but good business practices. I was laid off but my payment was fair.
cons: Too many intermediate managers that are competing between them without adding value to the company. Horrible desk position to work, desk behind desk, lots of phone conferences beside you, very difficult to be concentrated in your work place. Framework is very well defined but you have to find out how to adopt it because there is no induction, everybody expects you know how things are executed. You learn from your mistakes.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Wonderful people, well run (mostly) front line units and great educational opportunities.
cons: Lack of cohesive vision in the end state of the consolidation into shared services many of the technology and operational functions - some lack of transparency depending on where you work. "Old guard" (those there more than 20 years) stifling movement and high performers to encourage departures while they understandably try to find work for themselves and those who have not kept up and/or volunteered to take on more work in the last few years. Distinct separation of those who are legacy bank versus those who have more relevant exposure to working in a current business environment. Political acumen important but perhaps too important for a bank trying to keep up in this fast changing business environment.

job_title: Preferred Senior Sales in Lincoln, RI
pros: Up to 4 weeks time off. Hourly Pay. Good starting job for entry level sales looking for a temporary job until something better comes along
cons: Worst job I have ever had by a very large margin.  This position was a good idea at first as we occasionally dealt with preferred customers and had sales opportunitys. Then someone took over and made everyone absolutely miserable. The last two years we were all constantly threatened and Micro Managed and dealt with the worst service calls imagineable while our sales goals and stress went through the roof.. Highest turnover ever. I watched many good sales people leave,get fired and get replaced by entry level young agents. Management was horrendous. Call routing was rigged beyond belief as some agents everyday got great sales opportunitys which enabled them to make big commissions and reap praise. Others got horrendous calls all day with irate,broke tier one problem calls.Hundreds of ways for them to dock your commissions and be reprimanded.  Friends and Family of Managers were hired and promoted. Site leads were clueless. The company only cares about the almighty dollar and made this position at BOA the absolute worst job imagineable.

review_title: I have learned, loved and gained great transferable skills however politics along with discrimination took over.
pros: You meet some amazing people with the same goals and visions as you. Connecting and learning from others is the best part. The resources at the company level are superb as long as you know they exist.
cons: Corporate politics, discrimination and lack of resources caused burnout. Lower level managers have inadequate knowledge for their roles. Mid level managers do not listen to the voices of the associate supposedly due to tied hands. Senior leaders promote a good vision however it is not trickled down to the entry level associate.

review_title: Going downhill since (and because of) TARP but still a pretty good place to be.
pros: The benefits are really great.  As a company, it is very committed to career advancement, but it is not encouraged within the banking center.  There are also a lot of extremely talented people who are great at what they do and are a pleasure to work with.
cons: Training was very poor.  I was just thrown into particular areas (like the role of loan officer) with minimum training and without any idea as to what I was doing.  Although much of the job description involves trial and error, "just figuring it out" usually creates three times more work than what should have been involved.  There are also many aspects to the job that, though never clearly defined, bring completely different expectations from each member of management.

review_title: Not bad if you are willing to work hard.
pros: Lots of enjoyable customer interaction, many different opportunities to demostrate product knowledge, sales skills, and customer service skills. Good training, good access to leaders. Lots of branches, but of course that will vary by market. Great benefits, including tuition reimbursement, help with childcare costs, and good medical benefits. Great name recognizition.
cons: You have to learn A LOT to do well at this job. The training is good, but you must be able to come up to speed quickly to be successful in the early months/year of the job. Lots and lots of paper work...there is a form for everything. The bonus structure is constantly changing so you have change how you work on a yearly basis.

review_title: It's a good company to work for.
pros:
Medical, Dental, and Family Leave benefits are outstanding.
Plenty of paid vacation, sick days, and holiday time.
If you become long-term ill (3 months or more) you will have a job waiting for you once you are well.
A place for every level of ambition--if your goals are mainly outside of work, you will have time to pursue them.  If you want to dive in and scale the corporate ladder you'll have opportunity to do that also.  If you want to do extra work for your site, such as decorating, organizing birthday parties, helping with training, you can do that also.
Up to 5 hours per week paid to volunteer with United Way, Susan G Komen, or Habitat for Humanity.
cons:
Very large company, so there's lots of corporate hooey through the company intranet.
Employees who do not meet the standards in their role cannot transfer to a different one.
The quality of your work experience will often be dependent on your Team Lead.

pros: HR is on your side.  Once you are in, it takes an act of god to be terminated!
cons:
Everything else.  There is constant change and federal laws make it impossible to tell the truth to customers.  There is a reason BofA is so big.  It is because they rob, cheat, and steal in every way imaginable.  For example, after lay offs, they sent me a letter telling them i owed them for vacation time used.  I sent a request to send what they thought i owed in writing with a complete breakdown of where they got the figures that i owed them.  Considering i NEVER took vacation time until the end of the year, i was shocked.  They never responded with a letter.  3 months later, i received a letter stating they would waive the owed money.
If you like OT, there is plenty of mandatory OT!  10-12 hours a week!

review_title: Stressful, had a manager that ruled with a fist and drove off many good underwriters.
job_title: Home Services Specialist II in Plano, TX
pros: Good pay and benefits, opportunities for other careers are there too.
cons: Just look at the news, this company is not run very well =  lawsuits = company downsizing often.

review_title: Good or bad depending on manager
pros: Large number organization with lots of opportunities to learn about the company, network and move around in the organization. Incredible benefits. Great pay. Depending on where you work in the company, you have the opportunity to work on high-profile projects that affect large segments of customers, entire business units, regions or the entire company and ultimately thousands of employees. Very structured environment.
cons:
Incredibly political. Very little training provided in my unit, high learning curve for how the organization operates.
Minimal employee satisfaction survey results action ever acted upon in the area I worked (communications) compared to the divisions I supported. All divisions have different pros and cons.

review_title: Good team, fun technical problems, high stress.
pros: The team I am on is fantastic. I've stuck around primarily because of them. I'm not sure how it is at the rest of the bank, but the FICC eFX team was great. There were some challenging technical problems to overcome which were interesting.
cons: Production issues can be stressful due to the nature of the FX markets (you can lose a lot of money really fast). Also, the department in charge of running the datacenters (TI) are very ineffective. It takes 6 months to set up a web server, and 3 months to set up a new VM. Inefficiencies like that are infuriating. Also it's not easy to get a raise when you are first starting out and your worth increases in the market.

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: working at Bank of America does come with some perks including health benefits, company matching 401K contributions, lower cost life insurance for the employee and spouse or partner.
cons: I can't speak for the entire bank because its very large so I'm only speaking for the GCCIBT organization. GCCIBT is not a good place to work!. Salaries are not high as compared to similar positions at other large banks. Additionally management can not be trusted and is generally not very good especially the middle -> upper level management. Management does not stand up for their people and layoff's seems to take place every month. Additionally the department only hires offshore consultants from Indian companies and never hires "locals" even though they claim and even post open positions (they post because legally they have to).

pros: There isn't much good to say about this employer. They do have good insurance benefits. The pay for a full-time teller wasn't that bad. I was $13.50/hr.
cons: I worked 6 days a week with a half day off in the middle of the week; though I was hired for 5 days with 2 off you never know it. They want you to refer products at the teller line for the desk; but the words are scripted and I was spoken to every time I swayed from the script (I've been in banking for 14 years) plus you can't any bonus from your referrals until you've been there for 5 years. I could go on but I'm not; just a very bad experience every day; never received a positive feedback from mgment but did from almost every customer and the other employees I worked with.

review_title: Bank of America isn't for everyone, think of what you need: money? or experience?
job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Cerritos, CA
pros: In Bank of America you gain experiences very fast because they expect their employees to know everything, learn everything, and be good at everything. Working for bank of America helps on your resume because the industry knows, thats bank of America pushes their employees to achieve the best of out them.
cons: The strengths for working at Bank of America is like a double edged sword. The bank pushes their employees so hard but at the same time they refuse to pay proportionally for the same amount of work and pressure expected. In Bank of America, most of everything goes by favoritism, raises, promotions, or flexibility of work hours. The one thing Bank of America managers are good at is lying and cover it up with more lies, especially when it comes to promotion and salary.

review_title: Financial Reporting of Annual Plan, monthly forecasting trends, variance commentary for Operational Unit Partners
pros:
1) Limitless opportunities for Training
2) Solid financial institution with stellar C-level executives
3) Vertical / Horizontal career opportunities within the organization
4) Telecommuting / Work from home
5) Strong Benefit package to include Health, Vision, 401K matching, Pension, Matching charitable contributions, educational scholarships for employees, Tuition assistance.
6) Brand recognition / credible fortune 100 company on resume.
cons:
1)  Lack of leadership at the Middle Manager level specifically to the finance area; Managers are self-appreciation and internally focused on self promotion thus unmotivated in developing emerging talent.
2) Lack a systematic career talent planning systems for middle level leadership; Talent succession only exists at the C-level or senior level leadership and is not filtered down the organizational CFO reporting groups.
3)  Inconsistency across financial silos in financial tracking tools, deliverabless/tasks, and leadership focus for financial professionals.

job_title: Senior Mortgage Loan Officer in Plano, TX
pros: Bank of America provides a stable work environment and a great benefits package. The 5% 401k match is great as well! There are plenty of positions to transition to within the bank.
cons: The biggest down side in my opinion of working for Bank of America is that they are so big that you feel like you are working on an assembly line at your current position. Little to no recognition. It seems as if you are purposely left in the dark about the overall processes to limit the skills you develop to take with you elsewhere. Basically, since you master only one small aspect of the mortgage business, a smaller company can't count on you to bring much to the table!

job_title: Vice President in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They do give you the opportunity to learn a lot and there are benefits for various things such as purchasing electric cars.  It depends on your manager but if you get good management they do help you balance personal life with work life.
cons: Loyalty to employees is low.   They create an environment that doesn't push people to promote each other up but rather tear each other down to get ahead.   Review system only allows a certain amount of people on each team to get considered "Top" and "Average" and "Below".    An example of how this works is:  If you have a team of five people and all of them are amazing top performing employees... only two of them can get that on their review.    Annual increases to pay are less than the cost of living increases.

review_title: Outstanding growth potential with struggling compensation along the way.
job_title: Risk Management Analyst III in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Significant growth opportunity within the organization.  It is fairly easy to move up in the company after you have proven yourself and built experience in a role.
cons: Human resources controls most compensation increases; particularly when being promoted.  I have ran into more than one scenario where I'm significantly underpaid for up to a year because my managers were forced to increase my salary over time.  There are also mergers and aquisitions on a regular basis that always lead to internal movement to new positions or layoffs.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Sacramento, CA
pros: Health, Medical, Dental, 401k, Stock Options.  Base salary makes life a little more comfortable.  3 weeks paid vacation, 2wks paid sick time.
cons:
Way too many to list.  Some of the front runners would be:

-Poor compensation plan for commission (funded units/volume, if I fund $2 million worth of new business I am only paid out $2560, seriously?)
-Horrible processing times.  90-120 days to complete a refinance. 60-90 days for a purchase.
-Poor/non-existent direction from upper management
-Schedules change every quarter.
-Most of the day is spent following up with clients apologizing for poor customer service from processors and why it has taken 88 days to fund their loan.

review_title: Good benefits, Slave to numbers, opportunity for advancement.
pros:
Good benefits, including 401k, Health, Dental, Vision and Prescription insurance, vacation, sick time, multiple schedules. 

Advancement opportunities.
cons:
They encourage you to take on responsibilities outside of your core function, but then do not allow time to accomplish them, do not allow you to do it on your own time, and still expect completion.

They have multiple tracking systems, that may or may not work, if one of them does not work, it may take months for it to be resolved and it can negatively impact your reviews. It is a good idea to do your own tracking, and hope that at least one of the other systems agrees.

Payroll doesn't know their own policies for alternate schedules.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Bank of America has so many benefits, discounts, and career development tools it is a great company to work for. Some of the great benefits include great insurance rates with many plans to choose from, tuition reimbursement, Child care reimbursement, and discounts on thousands of everyday items and stores you shop at regularly.
cons: Depending on the outlet you work, whether it be in the Banking Center or in its offices, such as mortgages, Merrill Lynch, or supporting staff, there is the potential for micromanagement due to sales goals, quotas, times, etc. I only had this problem when working inside the Banking Center, but when I obtained a job outside of the Banking Center, it was pretty much smooth sailing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- great learning experience 
- opportunity to help people in their financial lives
- opportunity to earn great money (base + quarterly bonus) 
- clear road for advancement 
- most of the teammembers are nice, great people 
- a lot of support for new-hires
- great benefits and perks 
- pretty easy job once you get past the learning curve of the systems
cons:
- this position is located in a BofA bank branch which could get very boring if you're in a bad location
- systems you work with everyday are pretty old and inefficient 
- complex compensation plan that seems like it is designed to confuse people, not to mention it changes all the time 
- you will start to get tired of the fakeness involved in corporate life 
- you will be overwhelmed with compliance controls 
- you will have to do bank maintenance such as issuing replacement debit cards

pros: As the title says...the benefits arw great. Vacation (PTO) is probably the best of any employer anywhere. Co-workers are great. If you work in a Financial Center your co-workers start to feel like family.
cons:
It is nearly impossible to be promoted from within. Because turnover is high, BOA likes to stack their bench with "anticipatory hires" that they simply plug-and-play into positions as they open up. If you are lucky enough to be offered a promotion, they will offer you far less money than an external higher. With that in mind you are better off leaving, and then coming back as a new hire yourself. 

BOA's current strategy to increase revenue is to cut costs, staffing and hours; rather than offer competitive products. They want a lot of customers,  but they cut staffing levels across the board leaving not enough employees to handles the volume of customers it serves in a timely manner.

job_title: Relationship Manager in San Rafael, CA
pros: Friendly customers, coworkers, solid base salary and (uncapped) bonuses are awesome if you apply yourself and manage your time. Benefits are good 3 weeks vacation and 401k match after 1st year. Like all sales jobs you get what you put into it. It's awesome that bonuses are tied to customer satisfaction. We keep our customers happy we get compensated accordingly can you say WIN WIN! Bofa is a huge organization and there is lots of room for professional growth. Management wants you to win so let them know what you want and they'll help get you there.
cons: POS system is clunky and it takes forever to get simple tasks done. Internal departments are taking longer and longer to get through doesn't make sense to have the customer come in for assistance and we are both on hold for 20 minutes.

review_title: Don't Join in this company, career will spoil
pros:
1. Working hours is 8.5
2. No variable pay
cons:
1.  Politics will be there every where but here it's very wide open
2. HR is dummy, they are puppet in the hands of higher management
3. IJP's (internal job movements won't work only for name sake they are)
4. Onsite managers are puppets in the hands of offshore management
5. This organization is curse for freshers
6. No process followed either in Projects or Transport system
7. Management grow career wise and financially but not S/w engineers or Analysts
8. You will be compared with Lead Analysts performance duering Appraisal time even though you are analyst
9. Higher Management here concerns of only managers
10. Transport is worst , you will get frustrated with incorrect routing system
11. Infrastructure is pathetic (Food available in food court is pathetic, ffod court word is not apt)
12. There is no strict process to consider feedback of employees related to food and transport
13. Least cultural activities because there are hardly 30 freshers out of 10k strength

pros: Higher pay than other banks
cons:
If financial center management and or long time staff don't "think" you'll "fit" in to the "dynamics" of the community, the workplace, and their pre-judged notion of you is already negative, you can kiss away your employment because they will all be in on it for your failure.  
Zero respect in general from the financial center management and fcom. If they don't want you there, they will make and or create every attempt to push you out, and continuously make you uncomfortable with microaggressions so you'll leave.  
Their systems continuously crash while opening accounts
Give goals ( in  general are extremely high )increase every year with less foot traffic, and if you don't make them, you'll be written up with constant fear of losing your job. Then they make you go to these incentive meetings after work, or really early, that last for 2-3 hours, when they could have sent an email...
The few extra dollars just aren't worth the stress and havoc...

pros:
A lot of opportunity for personal growth if you are a self-starter and a go-getter that is willing to navigate their own way.
Good benefit package.
A place where you can literally work in almost any area you are interested in (good starter job).
Lots of training opportunities when you seek them out.
Recognizable and strong brand.
cons:
Individuals are hyper-sensitive and do not take improvement suggestions or criticism well (many people act like this is a game and not business).
Navigating your career can be somewhat bureaucratic and filled with politics due to the size of the bank.
Compensation package for mid-level employees is not that great.
All rotational programs are only tailored for entry level BA and MBA students (tenured associates are not afforded the same opportunities- as many organizations do- which is completely beyond me).

review_title: Some of the work is OK and some is horrid.
pros: For me, it is a job (I was unemployed for the previous 6 months), it is close to home, and in general the workload is not heavy. The organization is very large so if you wait long enough you should be able to transfer to another position should you not like where you are.  Also, because it is a large organization there is a great emphasis on and opportunity for training.
cons:
My facility is in a horrid location and the pay is lousy. I received an above average year end rating but only a 2% raise. My organization is run by former Army/Air Force/Marines, so if you are not of that ilk you do not fit in.
If you have are near someone (or yourself) has been touched by the Mortgage Crisis or Financial Crisis it can be painful to admit you work for Bank of America.

review_title: The Bank of America Merrill Lynch in India
pros: Good processes, Part of the Genteel legacy BAC culture still remains. Not very aggressive.
cons: Top management has no international experience, mostly from DSP the Indian Broker firm taken over by Merrill.  Poor internal growth opportunities and as people  in most  top positions, have been there for years creating barriers for growth for middle management cadres. No opportunities  for employees from support to move to business. Support staff especially Technology and Operations not treated well and provided very few opportunities for  learning and career progression.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: The breadth of accounts, perks, advice that you have as an employee are great. It great to work for a well known company, but on the other side of the coin, not exactly dinner conversation with those that have had a lesser experience (with a mortgage, for example)
cons: With the specific site i was at, there were always talks about closing because it was so small! Average employees at a call center in other cities in the hundreds, while we were <40. The way that you bonus is through surveys that are emailed to customer. the surveys don't have your name on them. so naturally, if a customer has an issue that isn't resolved over the course of a couple of calls in one day, you may have solved the problem and the customer was happy, but the customer will receive the survey and mark poorly on the individuals that got it wrong. Even if the survey says someone else's name or says "he" and you are a she (or vice versa), you must swallow that survey.

pros: Great work/home relationship. 4 weeks vacation plus 10 bank holidays and 10 sick/personal, couldn't ask for more but you can also "purchase" an extra week to make it 5, wow. If you are smart you can move ahead but you have to tow the line so to speak and not make waves. Show initiative though. You can really give back to the community and move up in the company.
cons: Not a lot but that is not that case in all departments. If you make the wrong manager mad or don't get along with certain individuals that can hurt you in the long run. They tend to underpay people that have been there for many years. They pay more to bring in outside help and then have the tenured people train that person. Kind of degrading when you think about it. This did not happen to me but I did see it done.

pros: The bank does have good products if you understand banking products, and their online/mobile banking I couldn't live without.  Many of my fellow co-workers are the friendliest, kind-hearted people that actually went out of their way to try and help customers with their individual situations.  However, the company's objectives and morals as a whole are very low.
cons: The Sales & Service Specialist (up until 2013) was mostly sales goal oriented.  We were given the same goals as our Personal Bankers, yet we did not have any type of incentive to meet our goals.  In my branch, with so many staffing cuts, I was playing the role of the Asst Manager, the TOS, the PB, as well as my own official role as SSS.  I found myself helping my PB out so that she could meet her goals, even though I was the one performing.  Even my manager would tell me to do this so that her Banking Center wouldn't be on the "bad" list.  Obviously I quit shortly after.

review_title:
Chester Location | BAML Operations

Middle Office/Back Office Roles
job_title: Back Office/Middle Office in Chester, England
pros:
Great opportunity for graduates, and those looking to enter Investment banking. 

Relaxed work culture, open floor between back and middle office. All managers and directors approachable with open door culture. 

Access to online learning courses for product/service. 

Great people and personalities. Very diverse work community.
cons:
Very little support for building your own career path. They promote internal movements however I've found politics can play a part. 
 
Projects are given from top down and very difficult to gain autonomous/creative space for improving a process.

Typical corporate politics, often producing 'favoured' members of a team. Recognition for good work often overlooked unless constantly in dialogue with management.

Pay grade is very low compared to the market. Even for a Northern location, I've found little to no increase in salary for years of service.

pros: Work hours were great, always got home before 6pm during the week. Enjoyed the people I worked with as well. Company benefits and pay were worth it too.
cons: Company is very pushy about sales which makes speaking with customers uncomfortable at times when we need to present sales offers that they have previously rejected already. Vacation scheduling at my branch was unfair as well since my manager took off the weeks with major holidays every year leaving the rest of the branch to pick their days around her. Biggest issue though was that the branches were cutting staff and mine in particular was steadily busy, making even bathroom breaks almost impossible especially during the lunch hours with only one or two of us working the line and the drive through at once.

review_title: A great place for IT professionals
pros: If you are an IT professional BOA is huge and you will have a lot of chances to learn new things.  They still offer working from home 100 percent of the time for some positions.  Most managers let you do your own thing and don't micro manage you.  Salary is fair but increases are low each year.
cons: Difficult to keep a healthy work like balance.  IT environment are huge but the number of people supporting them is limited, this results in weekend work as well as long hours at times.  You have to be prepared to know a little about a lot of things since you will not be able to work at just one primary role.

review_title: Review from a former employee of 10yrs
job_title: Commercial Credit Analyst in Brea, CA
pros: Awesome benefits!  Honestly they can not be compared to any other financial institution in their industry.  From matching up to 7% on 401k,  providing four months maternity/bonding time to providing reasonable health coverage prices, BOA hands down has the best benefits.
cons:
Although diversity and inclusion are apart of the banks mantra, its not completely honored.  I was the only black person on my team of 95% Hispanics. Diversity sure.....inclusion...not so much from my experience in the Brea, CA location.  

BOA is also slow to promote. It is alllllll about who you know. Networking will be your primary tool to grow, not your skill set.

Lastly, HR, they are not as supportive as they promote. Although the bank advertises that you can go to HR and report things however as soon as you do, you direct manager is made aware of it.

*Disclaimer* These experiences are not a reflection of the entire bank as a whole, I am only talking about the contact center location in Brea,CA.

review_title: Time to reevaluate the overall compentance of many of our mid level managers . . . very unrealistic!
job_title: Account Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Many of the benefits (health, vacation, etc.) are very good.  Many of my peers are very easy to work with.
cons: Mid level management is out of touch and unrealistic with expectations of their subordinates.  At times we all wonder if senior management is not being kept in the loop by the mid level management people regarding issues concerning the lower level staff.  Many of us have the feeling that management has no idea of what is involved with all of the work that we currently have and the work that they keep piling on us.  Eventually, there will be a point of diminishing returns with respect to the quantity and quality of the work that we produce ( we all feel that we are now at that point).

review_title: You love it or hate it, sometimes both.
pros:
They do offer many great benefits. However, if you are not using those benefits then what is the point? 
They offer tuition reimbursement for those taking, "business related," courses up to a certain amount           
each year.  Also, they provide child care reimbursement based on your household's income. There are 401K and pensions available. You start out with vacation and sick time as well. Many great benefits offered, but like I said whats the point if you are not able to use most.
cons:
The downsides of working at Bank of America would be feeling like your not appreciated. Another 
downside is they hire new employees at higher rate of pay then those currently employed(with no experience) due to competition in the area. Finally i would have to say their raises are quite pathetic, typically around .20 cents.

review_title: Teller is a great step to getting into the banking industry
pros: Bank of America is a great place to work, and I would definitely recommend starting out as a teller for those who are in college and want to get great work experience as well as a great job to put onto your resume. Bank of America offers full benefits to even those who are part time, and you are well taken care of in that sense.
cons: The cons of being a teller for the company is it is your job to refer customers over to the personal bankers to make sales, which you do not earn any compensation for. It is only the personal bankers who make the bonuses off the sales they make. The tellers so not got any additional compensation for the referrals they get.

pros: great atmosphere, very in depth training, if you want to succeed- you will - its up to you.
cons: some of the goals are a little unreasonable. that being said, if you follow the processes in place and can honestly say you are trying your best, then job well done and management will recognize that and work with you - manage you in opposed to manage you out.

review_title: Not exactly a strong pool of talent
job_title: Premier Client Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you are seeking work-life balance this is perfect.  A salaried position with bonuses.  You get out, meet clients, go to branches, have autonomy and you're off by 5.
cons: This part of the company sat just below Private Banking in advising affluent clients.  They had two ways of recruiting - finding outside talent or promoting people internally from teller as they worked their way up.  Needless to say, the outside talent was solid, the people promoted from within (making up most of the group) were some of the laziest and least knowledgeable people I have ever met.  They were clock watchers, with very little knowledge of finance/investments/markets outside of pushing a menu of products.  These people are handling investments?  Seriously?  They are off by 5, and believe me they aren't going home and studying up on the latest and greatest.  If you are looking for an easy lifestyle this is a great choice.  If you are intelligent, talented and passionate you will hate this place and you will feel the jealousy from your "peers" who worked their way into the position and are clearly compensated at a lower rate as well.  Take your talents elsewhere.

job_title: Operations Project Analyst in Plano, TX
pros: GREAT benefits.  The Bank provides enrichment opportunities such as language classes and personal growth experiences in volunteerism, as well as tuition reimbursement and free accounts.  Salary is in the median of the bell curve but they offer overtime and other benefits like partial day care reimbursement.   Work is routine and you know what you are doing in your role.  401k match is one of the best in the industry.
cons:
The Manager you have will make or break your experience.  I have had some great ones who let you do your work and I have had high-maintenance ones who are beyond A-Type Micro-Managers.

The culture is skewed to religious so avoid mentioning if you are atheist.  They are fine with MOST of the other religions.

job_title: Financial Center Operations Manager in Knoxville, TN
pros: It would be a challenge to find a company with better benefits when employeed for work inside of a financial center. I cannot brag enough about the wonderful benefits I receive as an employee.
cons: As you can expect with any corporation of this size, there are some disconnects. With having to consult with so many departments to take care of our customers, it is sometimes difficult. There is a lot that is out of the hands of the employees that work face to face with customers. Although we desire to help a customer, with their credit card issue for instance, we cannot- we have to get on the phone and rely on antoher associate to take care of the issue. Although it is the associate on the phone who has control of the situation, it is a direct relection on the associate who is sitting in front of the cusotmer. This has more impact than one might expect becuase customer satisfaction ratings have an impact of quarterly financial compensation.

review_title: Good at some things, not so much at others
pros: Just upped paternity leave to 16 weeks from the original 12 weeks.  Unheard of with many companies.
cons: Come in with the salary you want because if you want to get a decent raise while you're employed, not a chance in hell.  Basically, come from the outside, you'll get paid.  Stay at the company for a few years, and you'll be capped, and will make minimal increases until you leave again.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Pennington, NJ
pros:
Great corporate benefits (through Bank of America)
Good work life balance - work doesn't follow you home
Opportunity to make good money despite dealing with a lot of non sense
cons:
Over complicated, constantly changing compensation plan designed to to nickle and dime you out bonuses
Micro management - management will constantly harass you and track every metric imaginable to increase "productivity"
Very limited career opportunity - management is either unwilling or unable to help you move out of a phone-based sales role
Disorganized senior management with very poor communication - won't elaborate, but many other posts can give details
"Gamey" compensation plan doesn't reward good sales people but rather those who know how to play the game
No support from service team partners - job is advertised as sales but the majority of your time is spent in a customer service capacity

pros: There is no such thing - I had the worst experience of my life and I was constantly bullied by my team. My team lead considered is OK to shout at me at all times (in front of other people)while 'my manager' was being entertained by it. I felt humiliated on a daily basis.
cons:
MANAGEMENT MANAGEMENT MANAGEMENT
My own experience was terrible :
-people were leaving that team all the time. Someone even left after 3 weeks.
- Location - you are in the middle of nowhere
-HR- I told them about the way I was being treated and they just ignored me
- the team in NYC was extremely difficult to work with - they were always rude
- applied for lots of relocation jobs in London and 'my manager' made sure to give all the negative feedback to the hiring managers for me not to get a relocation
-they say that encourage people to move around to other teams-learn new skills etc- but this is just on paper (if your manager doesn't like you as a person you'd be stuck in the same team forever until they make you quit the job)

review_title: Sales people: Hone your typing skills!
job_title: Premier Client Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The people. The Bank has terrific long term and loyal employees who truly work as a team. The Banks overall benefits package, Health/vision/dental/retirement, is fabulous.
cons:
The Incentive/Bonus compensation program is constantly changing. It seems, as an associate who depends on bonuses, the Bank's Senior management spends countless hours figuring out how to pay us less.  As a result, each year and sometimes mid year, the program is reformulated and put into practice prior to the associate understanding  what their sales goals are.
Over the last few years the Bank has evolved towards a micro management system of tracking and data input. Sales people in any division, Investment/ Lending etc, are spending too much time entering redundant data instead of selling. This has caused wide spread frustration and low morale for many associates. Not to mention a drop in sales.

review_title: Mega opportunities if you work hard and prove yourself.
pros: Great health benefits and employee perks. Learned a lot about banking and how to treat customers during a 30 year career and had many different roles while working for the bank. Made a number of good long time friends from my many years with the bank.
cons: Aggressive sales goals depending on what line of business of the bank you work for. Bank had been laying off a number of associates to keep expenses down due to some questionable business decisions such as the Merrill Lynch and Countrywide Mortgage purchases which has contributed to the layoffs. The bank is on the cutting edge of products but needs to back it up with superior service to customers. I am tired of hearing they are the most hated bank in America!

review_title: Management is very shortsighted and there is no loyalty from corporate Bank of America.
pros: The facilities at Newark, DE are very nice. The size of the organization allows alternate career paths and opportunities for promotion. Paid time off is about the same as it is for most  large companies.
