cons: Bank of America is quick to turn it's back on tenured employees. A person may get promoted several times and take on responsibilities in new areas.  When the need for the new department is done the employees are simply laid off. These employees that have been great contributers to the organization and as such a valuable asset are not offered other positions. Loyalty seems to be a one way street. Additionally, working for Bank of America is strictly production centered. At lease at the mid-management level Ethical or not ethical, right or wrong the only thing that matters is hitting a number regardless of how it is achieved. As a result customer confidence in Bank of America continues to be the worst in the industry.

review_title: Work experience was average compared with other large corporations.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Plano, TX
pros: Not as political in the area that I worked compared to other large corporations that I have experience.  Pay and benefits are average.  I worked from home the 3 years I was at BoA which was a big plus.  However, less than 10% of employees are allowed to work from home.
cons: Work life balance is not good, especially for salaried employees.  In many cases people were not allowed to take much of the vacation that was allotted to them in HR policy, by local management.  They continue to lay people off and work the rest harder to make up for lack of staff.    Poor communications by many managers.

pros: Vacation Time, sick days, Tuition Reimbursement, Pay is great if you are an outside hire.... (May the Odd's be in your favor if you are a teller or an SSS) you'll make .75 cents more than your current rate to do what I do.
cons: Oh, I don't know.... EVERYTHING ELSE! This has to be the worst career move anyone can make if you have a new BCM who drank the kool-aid. You have people who only had to sell checking and savings accounts teach you how to deepen customer relationships.... but only with wealthy customers, they don't want the poor taking up too much of our precious lobby space. They are process managers, not people managers. most of the BCM's treat customers like they are invisible and they force you to work every Saturday unless you use PTO.

pros: Because it's a large company, there are limitless opportunities to move around. The talent level is very high! If you're lucky enough to get into a MyWork role, you get to work from home and that's great.
cons: If you don't like constant reorganizations and moving from one group of leaders to another, this is probably not the place for you. As new leaders emerge and take on higher roles, there tend to be reorganizations and changes in direction. You must stay flexible to succeed.

pros: Good training, nice work environment, good relationship with peers.
cons: $2,000 per month draw no matter where you live in the US. Any unpaid draw rolls into the next month. Not able to meet the draw and at about 5-$6,000 in the red they cut you loose.  All your hard work and training goes down the drain. Better be closing loans in a city with high home values. Underwriting at BofA is horrible. The left hand does not know what the right hand is doing.  Lots of rule overlays {stricter loan requirements) makes it hard to compete. High turn over in processing and underwriting departments. Horrible reputation in the community. Lowest commission in the industry. If you have experience and licensed, go work for someone other than a bank. Expect to work long hours including open houses on Sundays and one weekend per month doing home loan days at a branch. Not a job for anyone with a family. Hope you are single, live with roommates and no car payment. Not a job for a single wage earner with a family.

job_title: Claims Analyst II in Providence, RI
pros:
The actual position was fun and easy, I actually enjoyed what I was doing.
The management did not breath down our necks, we were able to work at our own pace, as long as we hit the metrics.
Great community and great co-workers.
cons:
The biggest issue was lack of communication.
The management was iffy and had no idea how to handle intense and huge changes. 
There was little room for growth.

review_title: Not the place to start a career
pros:
Salary, bonuses, work from home Fridays. It's a laid back environment depending on your boss and team.

Management seemed committed to turning around the business (shrinking it to deal with bloat and settling compliance demands). There was a clear message and lots of feedback opportunities.
cons: I was hired from an internship. HR didn't know where to but me so they dumped me on an unsuspecting team. That meant I got stuck doing support instead of development. The app was 10 years old and long forgotten by most. Only one person from my 5 person team was in the same office. Eventually the office manager was laid off so our office went unstocked for the rest of my tenure. My office buddy was not technical so I was left without a mentor. There are a lot of contractors so there isn't much sense of ownership. Restructuring of departments seemed constant. Like my team, all the (internal) clients were spread out. Offshore associates are hit or miss. Red galore

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: 3 weeks paid vacation, good health insurance, childcare reimbursment.  Decent Investment options for clients.
cons: Young managers with no experience or tenure in the Market, 4 different managers in 8 months with constant turnover.   They purposely route calls to different segments to give certain departments a higher probability of success. Caps on payouts, one call out of a 100 even no fault of your own can eliminate a significant portion of your commission.

review_title: Great benefits and great place to start a career; impersonal culture and not best work life balance
pros: Bofa is a great place to start a career and if you're a fit for the banking world, a great place to stay because there are a lot of opportunities to move to different areas during your career. There are some great people there. Benefits are awesome. Good company 401K match, match on giving, health benefits are solid, and time off is standard to generous.
cons: It's a very large corporation - definitely feel like just a number a lot of the time - and there are quite a few inefficiencies, but what company that size doesn't have them? For some it is a great place to be, but very political and very impersonal. Also, at a certain point in your career I've seen people have to leave and rejoin the company in order to get a pay bump. Work life balance on some teams is non-existent which is not healthy for anyone.

pros: If you’re located in an area with multiple lines of business, there are many opportunities to apply for positions in other areas of the bank and learn different skills.
cons: I now realize this is a toxic work environment. I regularly worked unpaid overtime and did multiple peoples jobs. No loyalty, employees are just a number to upper management, even if you’re a high producer in the middle of a project they will not think twice about laying you off. Pay is often  based on seniority not amount of work done. Training in some departments is non existent- AKA ‘figure it out yourself’. There are regular reorg’s, and employees are regularly switched to different teams doing completely different work and expected to be okay with it. During my 15 years with the company, I never received any disciplinary warnings, always received ‘meets’ and even the hard to get ‘exceeds’, and was laid off just months after getting a raise, and a title promotion.

pros: 401k, paid maternity/paternity leave, vacation time
cons:
Did away with MyWork program which they are still falsely being recognized for in recent articles/awards. 

It truly does not matter if you are employed there for a year or 20 years; they will lay you off regardless of performance. They encourage you to look during your severance period; however due to the MyWork program being disbanded it is difficult to locate a position or even work in a different office. 

Due to budgets/layoffs they are not backfilling positions resulting in associates being overworked and very fearful of management. 

The only time when senior management remotely took any interest in associate recognition & satisfaction is when the yearly associate survey went out. They would take an interest for a few weeks, encourage the survey and then act like you don’t exist anymore until they were rated poorly on the survey and would need feedback. Would never act upon it until the following year right before the next survey.

job_title: Personal Banker in Las Vegas, NV
pros: This company is one of the best and take care of their own that is top notch. The atmosphere is great and the potential to be flexible and expand one's horizons is nearly limitless. When they say they support you furthering your education and capabilities, they really do support you. Of course, this comes with the expectation for you to succeed with all the tools for success that they give you. Goals are set high, but it's a welcome challenge and atmosphere to all who have that drive to be great.
cons: If you're not up to the task of working, don't even bother. Bank of America will be a miserable place for you. There is an atmosphere of pull your own weight or sink atmosphere, and it would make those who just want a job absolutely miserable.

review_title: Loved my coworkers.....mixed feelings about company and policies
pros: Coworkers were absolutely amazing. I was a teller and everything was all about REFERRALS. Weekly meetings on how to get referrals. Tried to make it seem like they cared about the customers, but it was all so the manager wouldn't get in trouble from the higher up so they could get their bonuses.
cons:
Glorified retail position. If you don't like pestering people into signing up for products they don't need and don't want, then don't work here.
NO OVERTIME. So much so that the district manager would make us take any overtime we had (example 2 hours) and make us apply it to our lunch breaks. So basically we had times when we had to work overtime , didn't get paid and then they wanted us to spread it out over the week by adding it to our lunch breaks. Can't wait for the class action lawsuit paperwork for this BS practice.

review_title: BofA is a good company to work for if you love corporate america.  Lots of good benefits.
pros: 4 weeks vacation, 11 paid holidays, 2 weeks sick pay, 5% matching 401k, work from home, very good supervisors and managers or at least in my case, company takes employees concerns very seriously,
cons: Lots of BS type work and activities in addition to what you were hired to do.  For example volunteer work, lots of government compliance training, United Way heavily promoted, too many wasteful meetings when a email would have been better, lots of red tape required from everyone before anything can get done by anyone, lots of BS time consuming activities required by all levels of management, cyber security paranoia (and rightly so!).

pros: Full benefits for part-time employees and they have great health benefits. Part-time consists of 20hrs which is great for a part-timer like me. You get to work with a small number of people so it can be a nice close family atmosphere.
cons: Bank of America seems like it is moving most of its customers to Online Banking so they are slowly cutting down on teller hours in some banking centers which leads to a few tellers working through a lot of people. The process could be made better if everyone works flawlessly to help educate and pay attention to people waiting, however; that is not always possible. So right now basically it is a transitioning phase so if you are a teller be expected to do a lot of explaining and selling as well for bank products.

pros: You  can earn an okay amount of money for what you are doing, but you are really selling years of your life that you won't get back.
cons:
Everyone here is unhappy. The positive reviews you see are recruiters posting on glassdoor because the turnover rate is so high and they want people to keep coming into the "feeder" as other people leave.

Pay structure is borderline criminal- they make you track your compensation and if you don't challenge and let them know you should have been paid, you don't get paid, even if you can clearly prove that you did the work. 

You push people towards ME's "in house products" that make the company more money.  This screams conflict of interest.

Management doesn't care. At all. They want to keep their cushy jobs so they don't rock the boat, and contribute nothing. 


Service teams are horrible and combative.

Systems are outdated and frustrating.

Micromanaged daily, if you step away from your desk for 5 minutes to go to the bathroom you get questioned. I received a verbal warning for going 7 minutes over on a lunch break.

review_title:
Partiality, Upper level don't have a sense of management 
They just mismanaged folks having too much of attitudes
pros:
You just need to have some chill here thats it !!!...
No work load 
Good for those who just want a job nothing else from their life!!..
cons:
If you have direct contacts with tbe upper level people you will get a good CTC irrespective of your skillset!!!..
This thing happened with me I am a fresher 
btech passout and there is another person who is also a btech fresher but he has good contacts and relationship with upper levels So he got more than me even he hasn't any relevant experience. He is just a fresher but he has good relations with upper managements.

also they treat fresher as a stupid person so they don't even try to give any kind of learning exposure or opportunity .There are some folks who are working from some years,they simply thinks that they are real techi guy And no one can approach us and challenge us and no can ask for anything from us

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Experience working across lines of business in a matrix environment, global company experience
cons: Unreasonable work/life balance, the epitome of the "good ole boy" network, extreme lack of diversity at mid level management and even more scarce at the senior and c-suite levels

pros: Great benefits for health/401k.  Paternity/Maternity leave.
cons: Management can be pretentious and delusional.

pros:
• OPEN BAR at all corporate events
• Work/Life Balance? More like Work/Life imbalance! I cry on the drive to work everyday.
• The Employee Engagement Survey requires you to input your Employee ID...so much for anonymity!
• 6 Day workweek and No overtime (they have creative ways to avoid paying all that OT you will be racking up)
• Mobility? Yes! Backwards✅ Lateral✅ Upwards❎ 2 out of 3 isn’t so bad
• Short commute? I am literally laughing out loud! Just know that where you apply and accept the position might not be where you end up working. You’re funny...short commute lol
• When it comes to training, they value quantity over quality. I repeat QUANTITY over QUALITY.
cons:
• Not enough corporate events! 
• With pros like these who needs cons???

review_title: Wonderful position with great co-workers and some of the best benefits I've seen!
pros: I enjoyed almost every day at Bank of America because I worked with intelligent and friendly people.  We were always a team working together to achieve a common goal.  The salary was competitive and the bonuses were very fair.  The healthcare was top-notch.  The work schedule was very flexible with the ability to work remotely.  I also received four weeks vacation as well as bank holidays and sick time.  Wonderful employer!
cons: The only con, in my opinion, would be the lack of company sponsored events.  It would be nice to have a company BBQ here or there or some type of socializing event.  It would help everyone to get to know each other!

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: It's hard to come up with a pro relative to other banks, so I guess the pro is that it's too big to fail and won't go bankrupt any time soon.
cons: It started out ok, but once the financial crisis struck, its negatives really started to show. 1. Extremely siloed. The communication problems between different parts of the bank could have saved it billions of dollars. 2. They don't pay for performance. They pay primarily based on the group. One guy on the mortgage desk made the bank $400 million dollars but because it was a business they were no longer interested in (busted abcds), his bonus was only $40K. 3. There are no upward reviews, only downwards. If you get stuck with a terrible boss, there's nothing you or anyone else in your group can do about it.

review_title: Field FSA has too many demands and the job changes every quarter
pros: Good name of Merrill behind you; unique bank/investment platform; good benefits; higher than avg salary + bonus; 4 weeks paid vacation from day one
cons: Bad rep of Bank of America; retail banking and customer service is annoying; incredibly archaic and slow systems; very political and bureaucratic; job do's and don'ts change every quarter or so plus comp plan has changed 4 or 5 times in a year and there is high turnover in the banks, which mean you never work with the same people and have to start from square one constantly; high demands

review_title: Not a good place to work for if you have great work ethics and values.
pros:
Fun work environment with teammates, it really helps you get through the work day
Good benefits
Exceptional time off abilities
Bonus and incentives if you dont make any errors
cons:
Too many politics that focus on kissing up relationships than those who actually work
Management could be more knowledgeable especially if it pertains to the work they require of you
Parking is insane having to walk miles from the parking deck just to get to the office
Too much micromanaging, coaching every week is not necessary when doing well
Too much focus on sales and numbers but then not rewarded when exceed all goals
Good for short term environment but definitely no more than 6 months

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: If there is anything good about working here it is the perks.   They pay reasonably well, and they have excellent benefits.   However......
cons: Employees are requested to work a lot of overtime.  It is easy to get caught up in the money and not realize you have no recreational time.  The expectations are very high.   The company is disorganized.   There are a lot of directives but no direct supervision to speak of and very poor management.   They expect you to be an expert and hold you to the same standards as experienced employees.   The team wants to help but they are  too busy to provide adequate support.  I would not recommend working here.   Really cannot wait to leave.

review_title: Gotten much worse over the last few years - Look elsewhere
pros:
- Decent Pay
- Opportunities to move elsewhere in the organization (but the grass is never greener)
cons:
- Benefits are all slowly being taken back or withdrawn.  Used to brag about my benefits package, now I'm embarrassed.  Health insurance rates have gone through the roof while coverage has been pulled back.  Work from Home benefit being rolled back across the company.
- Culture is disorganized chaos.  Normal to spend 7-8 hours a day on conference calls and then have to put in hours of work after hours to actually get work done.
- Never any effort to thing long term, always just trying to put out the latest fire drill without a worry of root cause.

review_title: Put Up or Get Out Mentality
pros: Amazing benefits (3 months paid Paternity leave - unheard of!), 401k Match, Personal Bankers start with 3 weeks paid vacation, good pay, and potential for a good bonus check if you can meet the ever-increasing sales goals
cons: Sales goals that are consistently changing making them harder to meet.  From 2014 to 2015, the incentive plan was restructured so that what each sale you got counted for less, but the goal you had to achieve went up.  High turnover - creates an unsuccessful environment where seasoned employees are the minority.  Your manager can make or break you - if you get put into a financial center with a manager that doesn't know what he or she is doing, your career will suffer and be short-lived.

pros:
Great company with TONS of benefits: Medical, Dental, Legal, Childcare reimbursement
Sites all over the U.S. if you want to move around
Casual Dress Code
3 weeks vacation in your first year with the option of purchasing a 4th
401k Plan with 1:1 company match up to 5% of salary, company also makes an annual contribution to your 401k.
Lax attendance policy if you work in the call center/back office.
Easy work if you pay attention to what you're doing
cons:
Local management. The Tampa, FL site leader micro manages all of her managers to the point that they complain about it.
They make a practice of lowballing internal candidates moving into new positions with % salary increases rather than paying what the job should pay. For example I left Document Review with a salary of 43k- higher than most of my peers. If they were to hire someone off the street the company would pay 48-50k for the same job. They hired no one off the street in the 4 years i worked for the company.

review_title: Good company with some bad management
pros: It's a company with a very high goal. It tries to make it's associates happy. It's a very large company with a vision. It gives good benefits and good opportunities through associate discounts.
cons: There are people who dont deserve to be management in manager positions, and then there are those other people who deserve to be management or to advance and the incompitent people hold them back because their jobs rely on the people that have brains and actually do their job and exceed their performance responsibilities.
